column3: Screenshot partially black with the IE Driver
column4: The returned image only contains the part that is visible on the screen. The size seems to match the full content, but the remaining content is black. ![screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/918557/9986058/28fa17a4-602f-11e5-94b7-63c64e8de9ea.png)  Environment : Windows 8.1 64bit, IE11, IE Driver 2.47.0 32bit  To reproduce:  ``` var driver = new InternetExplorerDriver(); driver.Navigate().GoToUrl("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yelcho_Lake"); driver.GetScreenshot().SaveAsFile(@"screenshot.png", ImageFormat.Png); driver.Quit(); ```

column3: README of PyPI package is broken and needs update
column4: The Python implementation of the bindings for Selenium on PyPI has a README with at least two issues: 1. README **[is outdated](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/py/README)** (e.g. supported Python version 3.4 not mentioned but [declared on PyPI](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/selenium#downloads)) 2. README **[doesn't display properly on PyPI](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/selenium)** (the source code displays instead of the formatted text)  The latter is probably related to a syntax error introduced in [commit 3fc2db2](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/3fc2db275149748b21ea0370d3d3ace2df7c2676#commitcomment-13704294) (table markup, line 17). It may also be advisable to use the currently missing `.rst` file extension.

column3: Python Firefox RemoteWebDriver doesn't flush profile to disk
column4: The Python Firefox remote WebDriver does not flush the FF profile to disk. Thus, if the user updates the profile by calling `set_preference(...)`, the profile that is sent over is just an empty zip file, with no feedback that this is the case.   I'm curious if this is by design, as it can lead to some length debugging sessions when you are running the remote driver - locally, this does not appear to be an issue, as the preferences are kept in memory. Hence, you get unexpected results when you run tests on, say, a CI server via Selenium Grid. Locally tests that rely on settings changes will pass, remotely they will fail.

column3: Java: All searching interfaces are made generic
column4: The problem:  There are many Selenium-based projects such as Appium (java_client), Selendroid, IOSDriver and so on. They are used not only for the web/browser testing and they have their own WebElement implementations. Also there is probably need to re-implement all changed interfaces for some end user purposes.  Current design doesn't allow user to use their own WebElement subclasses without additional casting. It is annoying and makes code dirty. Any trying to avoid this causes problems.  This change is backward compatible with existing projects and will allow to create factories or user's customized Webdrivers and WebElements that return desired WebElement subclasses.   --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/seleniumhq/selenium/863)

column3: Update test for Chrome 44 stable release.
column4: The previous behavior was true for a release from the beta channel, but the bug was reported and fixed.

column3: HtmlUnitDriver alert handling doesn't handle confirms or prompts
column4: The new alert handling functionality in HtmlUnitDriver (`driver.switchTo().alert()`) only handles alert boxes, not other modal dialogs such as confirm and prompt. Other drivers handle confirm, alert and prompt. The test case below illustrates this.   I know that I can install a confirmHandler for the HtmlUnit WebClient, but that requires modifying the underlying driver and messages are difficult to retrieve.   ``` import org.junit.Test; import org.openqa.selenium.*; import org.openqa.selenium.chrome.ChromeDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.htmlunit.HtmlUnitDriver;  import static org.hamcrest.CoreMatchers.equalTo; import static org.junit.Assert.assertThat;  /**  * Handling of javascript popups is implemented inconsistently for HtmlUnitDriver, since v2.47.0  *  * @author barry  * @since 2015/12/13  */ public class AlertTest {      @Test     public void testAlerts() throws Exception {         testAlertsWithDriver(new ChromeDriver());         testAlertsWithDriver(new FirefoxDriver());         testAlertsWithDriver(new HtmlUnitDriver(true)); // test fails for HtmlUnitDriver     }      private void testAlertsWithDriver(WebDriver driver) {         driver.get("https://www.google.com");         JavascriptExecutor executor = (JavascriptExecutor) driver;          // alerts are implemented         String alertMessage = "error!";         executor.executeScript("alert('" + alertMessage + "')");         assertThat(driver.switchTo().alert().getText(), equalTo(alertMessage));         driver.switchTo().alert().accept(); // dismiss the alert          // but confirm messages aren't         String confirmMessage = "are you sure?";         executor.executeScript("confirm('" + confirmMessage + "')");          // "NoAlertPresentException: No alert was present" thrown for HtmlUnitDriver only         assertThat(driver.switchTo().alert().getText(), equalTo(confirmMessage));          driver.switchTo().alert().accept(); // dismiss the confirm          driver.quit();     } } ```

column3: Could the NuGet packages ship strong-named binaries?
column4: The major Selenium packages on nuget.org (https://www.nuget.org/packages/Selenium.WebDriver/) contain only the unsigned binaries, while seleniumhq.org has both unsigned and strong-named binaries.  Is there a way to provide the strong-named binaries in NuGet?  A separate NuGet package for strong-named binaries would be fine to keep the download size small for users of the existing package.

column4: The latest versions of selenium have commons-collections 3.2.1 bundled in. The particular version is reported for security vulnerability issue as given in the following links. http://foxglovesecurity.com/2015/11/06/what-do-weblogic-websphere-jboss-jenkins-opennms-and-your-application-have-in-common-this-vulnerability/ http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/topics/security/alert-cve-2015-4852-2763333.html  Can you take it on priority to upgrade the commons-collections library to the latest one?

column3: WebDriver upgrade to latest HtmlUnit 2.18
column4: The latest version of WebDriver is using the HtmlUnit 2.6 (org.seleniumhq.webdriver:webdriver-htmlunit:0.9.7376)  The latest HtmlUnit (2.18) supports features that are thus inaccessible to WebDriver (including WebSockets)  I tried unsuccessfully to override the HtmlUnit dependency but the wiring API needs adjustments  Any plans for upgrading HtmlUnit to latest 2.18 in WebDriver?

column3: WebDriver cannot type the opening bracket. "(" symbol.
column4: The issue has been raised based on the following comment: https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=1723#c35  Env: Java 1.8 FF 37, selenium 2.47.1.  The following test can reproduce the issue: @Test public void test1 ()  {     WebDriver driver = new FirefoxDriver();     driver.get("https://msdn.microsoft.com/ru-ru/library/windows/desktop/dn742442.aspx");     WebElement customField = driver.findElement(By.xpath("//input"));     customField.sendKeys("- ()-()-()-()-()-()-() -");     Assert.assertEquals(customField.getAttribute("value"), "- ()-()-()-()-()-()-() -"); }  Result: java.lang.AssertionError:  Expected :- ()-()-()-()-()-()-() - Actual   :- )-)-)-)-)-)-) -

column3: Screenshoot content sometimes cropped with the IE driver
column4: The InternetExplorer driver sometimes crops the content of a web page when it takes a screenshot:  ![screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/918557/10170317/3524e380-66cc-11e5-9caf-c2be6166c873.png)  Environment : Windows 8.1 64bit, IE11, IE Driver 2.47.0 32bit  To reproduce:  ``` var driver = new InternetExplorerDriver(); driver.Manage().Window.Size = new System.Drawing.Size(800, 600); driver.Navigate().GoToUrl("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurytios_Krater"); driver.GetScreenshot().SaveAsFile(@"screenshot.png", ImageFormat.Png); driver.Quit(); ```  This is due to the resizing that sometimes alter the size of the content. A fix would be to check and readjust the new size of the window and take the offsetWidth and offsetHeight for the capture. Here is a c# example:  ``` int docWidth = doc.scrollWidth; int docHeight = doc.scrollHeight;  var view = (IOleDocumentView)doc; view.SetRect(new RECT(0, 0, docWidth, docHeight));  if (docHeight < doc.scrollHeight) {     view.SetRect(new RECT(0, 0, docWidth, doc.scrollHeight)); } int screenshotWidth = doc.offsetWidth; int screenshotHeight = doc.offsetHeight; ... ```

column3: IEDriverServer frequently fails to click certain elements with default configuration
column4: The IE WebDriver frequently fails to click certain elements but reports no error so tests fail later due to false expectations. I understand that you'd like the defect wrapped up in a little box with a bow on it but that would take a considerable amount of my time when the solution I'm about to suggest has no negative repercussions and is incredibly easy to implement.  Setting the capability, requireWindowFocus, to true, fixes the issue so I suggest making this a default capability so people don't have to spend hours researching the issue online and weeding out less effective solutions like setting the nativeEvents or enablePersistentHover capabilities to false.

column3: Control flow stuck in 2.48.0
column4: The following scenario gets stuck in 2.48.0, but not 2.47.0.  Repo case:  ``` javascript var webdriver = require('selenium-webdriver'); var driver = new webdriver.Builder().   usingServer('http://localhost:4444/wd/hub').   withCapabilities(webdriver.Capabilities.chrome()).   build();  driver.get('http://www.google.com');  var getRandomText = function() {   return driver.findElement(webdriver.By.id('prm')).getText(); } var textPromise1 = getRandomText(); var textPromise2 = getRandomText(); webdriver.promise.when(textPromise1).then(function(actual) {   return webdriver.promise.when(textPromise2).then(function(expected) {     console.log('cannot get here');   }); }); ```

column3: FirefoxDriver: trying to upload an non-existant file fails silently
column4: The following code:  https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/6e1e6c1fed3674815c16048dbbd32cb0c1db84cc/javascript/firefox-driver/js/wrappedElement.js#L137  triggers a `change` event even if the file with given path does not exists an the `element.value =` is a noop. This can be confusing for application code and (with recent enhancements in IEDriverServer) is inconsistent with other driver implementations   PS. The W3C spec seems to be completely ignore the existance of ``.

column3: Fix the problem with adding of plugin into firefox profile. We tried …
column4: The fix  solves the problem with adding of plugin into firefox profile. We tried  create a folder, which was already created, because we create the folder during creating of file (if it's missing) and then we tried to create folder itself.  Error in my case: `OSError: [Errno 17] File exists: '/tmp/tmpu0hQBg.firebug-2.0.12.xpi/content/firebug/net/`

column3: Throw specific exception if element is not clickable
column4: The exception introduced with #1202 that is thrown when an element is not clickable unfortunately is a WebDriverException. It would be great if it could be a subtype of WebDriverException (or e.g. even a subtype of InvalidElementStateException. In cases where you want to handle those errors you don't want to catch all WebDriverExceptions.

column3: Treat a null response to getCookies as [].
column4: The Edge driver returns null (see https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/Feedback/Details/1872177), which is incorrect, but we might as well avoid the NPE in the client until that gets fixed.

column3: Update browser automation atoms tests for Edge.
column4: The Edge Driver might(?) not use the atoms, but the tests might as well pass.  This will require a Closure library update, to at least https://github.com/google/closure-library/commit/77358c86197dfbdcf0449bbeb37d2048ecd90cd9.

column3: Python Safari Driver Desired Capabilities should be changed
column4: The desired_capabilities.py file should be updated to have platform be MAC. The Windows Safari was EOL'd quite a while back. This just slows down the Java Grid and Standalone servers starting.  ``` SAFARI = {     "browserName": "safari",     "version": "",     # "platform": "ANY",     "platform": "MAC",     "javascriptEnabled": True, } ```

column3: javascript: error message
column4: The default error message when waiting for an element is not useful  ``` js var condition = seleniumWebdriver.until.elementLocated(css: '.my-class') driver.wait condition, 10000 // throws => Waiting element to be located by [object Object]  ```  Need to run `JSON.stringify` on the object for the error message to be useful

I had to switch selenium version due to the Browser version. But the same code was working just fine in selenium 2.47.1

column3: Ruby Feature Request: execute_script/execute_async_script accept hash/objects as arguments
column4: The `execute_script` and `execute_async_script` methods already accept most primitives (`string`, `integer`, `array`, `nil`). It would fully complete the set if we could pass hashes directly to selenium as arguments. I'm assuming they would be serialized to JSON by the selenium bridge, and then parsed on the JS side before being passed into the script as arguments.  With Ruby's built-in support for JSON serialization, it would be even better if selenium just serialized any unknown object to JSON (duck-typing on `#to_json`) and then parsing on the JS side.  hash example:  `driver.execute_async_script("foo.apply(null, arguments)", {a: 1})`  or via duck-typing  ``` ruby class Foo   def to_json     ...   end end  driver.execute_async_script("foo.apply(null, arguments)", Foo.new) ```

column3: PyPI package for 2.51.0 is broken
column4: The 2.51.0 package on PyPI fails to install because README.rst is not included in the sdist.

column3: Selenium "execute" does not work with FirefoxDriver when "security.csp.enable" is set to "true"
column4: The "execute" command discussed in this bug is in the spec here: http://www.w3.org/TR/webdriver/#dfn-execute-script ### STR 1. Run Selenium tests with a custom Firefox profile 2. Set `security.csp.enable` to `true` in that custom profile 3. Have a test that POSTS to `/session/{session id}/execute` with JavaScript it wants to execute ### Expected  `.execute` should run the script when CSP is enabled ### Actual  ``` 11:47:22.634 INFO - column3: TestNG version with selenium standalone jar 2.48.2 does not execute onTestFailure method
column4: TestNG version 6.9.6, current version included with selenium jar has a bug which got resolved in 6.9.9. I have created another issue with testng team, you can refer to the same https://github.com/cbeust/testng/issues/857. Could you kindly update the testng version to latest?  Thanks, Jinesh

column3: save_screenshot function shot 2 times pixel than real browser in Macbook and chrome
column4: test code  ``` python #!/usr/bin/env python # coding: utf-8  import cv2 from selenium import webdriver  print cv2.__version__ print webdriver.__version__ browser = webdriver.Chrome() browser.maximize_window() browser.get('https://www.google.com/') browser.save_screenshot('testshot.png') img = cv2.imread('testshot.png') print browser.get_window_size() print img.shape[1],img.shape[0] browser.quit() ```  _result:_ 2.4.12 2.48.0 {u'width': 1050, u'height': 777} 2100 1410  real browser ![qq20151115-0 2x](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4090783/11166931/8b03f608-8b87-11e5-93b6-5e39e735a0ef.png)  browser_save_screenshot function  ![testshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4090783/11166916/0f4ac3a2-8b87-11e5-9feb-04bec0ba98de.png)

column3: IDE: a subsequent call to open() fails with multiprocessed Firefox (e10s)
column4: Test case with two subsequent _open_ commands fails. The URL may be the same. The problem doesn't seem to be specific to the file being opened.  open | file:///E:/mine/tmp/case_e10s_2.html open | file:///E:/mine/tmp/case_e10s_2.html  (Change timeout setting to e.g. 1500, so you don't wait for a minute.)  ```     [info] Playing test case case_e10s_2     [info] Executing: |open | file:///E:/mine/tmp/case_e10s_2.html | |     [error] Timed out after 1500ms     [info] Executing: |open | file:///E:/mine/tmp/case_e10s_2.html | |     [error] modifyWindow: Window was closed!     [error] Current window or frame is closed!     [info] Test case failed  ```  Blank Firefox profile with Selenium IDE 2.9.1. Either - "E:\SW\Mozilla Firefox Nightly 2016-03-07\firefox.exe"  -no-remote -P alert - "E:\SW\Mozilla Firefox Nightly 2016-02-25\firefox.exe"  -no-remote -P alert   with e10s - multiprocessing - turned on.  Please, would you confirm this. Then I'm willing to report it in Mozilla's bugzilla.

column3: This fixes #498
column4: Support for all Number types in WebElement.send_keys(), instead of only int. Prevents TypeError from long type in Python 2.7 and is Python 3 compatible.

column3: Better feedback on NoSuchElementException by adding the locator
column4: Suggestion: put something like a `By#toString()` in the exception message.  I've implemented the PageObjects pattern using the PageFactory and I'm pretty happy with how things are setup right now, but one thing. Once an element can't be found (e.g. because the selector has changed in the implementation), a `NoSuchElementException` is being thrown, that shows a lot of information on the current state (driver info, duration, version, session etc), except for the element that was being looked up, and I have to look quite deep in the stacktrace to find out at what point the automation fails. I notice that especially people who didn't write the automation have much trouble finding out why it fails.  Any reason not to do this?  An example stack trace of the current situation:  ``` org.openqa.selenium.NoSuchElementException: no such element   (Session info: chrome=47.0.2508.0)   (Driver info: chromedriver=2.12.301324 (de8ab311bc9374d0ade71f7c167bad61848c7c48),platform=Linux 3.13.0-65-generic x86_64) (WARNING: The server did not provide any stacktrace information) Command duration or timeout: 45.04 seconds For documentation on this error, please visit: http://seleniumhq.org/exceptions/no_such_element.html Build info: version: '2.44.0', revision: '76d78cf', time: '2014-10-23 20:03:00' System info: host: column3: The microsoft edge driver executable window remains open after executing a test.
column4: Successfully execute script to launch google and verify google title. The edge browser close, however the Microsoft Edge driver executable window remains open. Use driver.close() the window remains opened. Tried driver.quit() get HTTPError: HTTP Error 400: Bad Request and the window did not close. Tried both - still get the HTTPError: HTTP Error 400: Bad Request. Code used: from selenium import webdriver from selenium.webdriver  import edge  from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By from selenium.webdriver.common.keys import Keys from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import Select from selenium.common.exceptions import NoSuchElementException from selenium.common.exceptions import NoAlertPresentException import unittest, time, re  class TestVersion(unittest.TestCase):     def setUp(self):         self.driver =  webdriver.Edge()          self.driver.implicitly_wait(30)         self.base_url = "https://www.google.com"         self.verificationErrors = []         self.accept_next_alert = True  ``` def test_version(self):     driver = self.driver     # open |  |      driver.get(self.base_url )     time.sleep(5)     # assertTitle | Google |      self.assertEqual("Google", driver.title)  def tearDown(self):     self.driver.close() # driver close closes the browser but the driver exe window remains opened.     #self.driver.quit() # driver quit cause an error ```

column3: Not able to work with multiple driver on Microsoft Edge
column4: STR: Create a test case having two or three open browser  Execute this test case when second open browser occurs it over writes previously opened (Edge) browser Expected: Two or three edge browsers should be opened Actual: Only one edge browser is available  ``` public static void main(String args[]) throws InterruptedException,         AWTException {     OpenBrowser2 op=new OpenBrowser2();     op.openBrowser();     op.openBrowser();     op.openBrowser();     op.openBrowser(); } public void openBrowser() {     System.setProperty("webdriver.edge.driver",             "C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Web Driver/MicrosoftWebDriver.exe");     driver= new EdgeDriver();     driver.get("www.google.com");  } ```

column3: IE driver - Does not get cookies from IE 10 or IE11
column4: STR: 1. Try to get cookies using IE driver with driver.manage().getCookies() or driver.manage().getCookieNamed(COOKIE) on Internet explorer browser .  The IE browser window then hangs and can be closed only by using kill process. 2. The above said methods were used with Chrome and Firefox and were working fine.

column3: Selenium 2.47 Python bindings - element not visible in Firefox
column4: Steps to reproduce: 1. Create a small script with Python bindings (I am testing a Django admin site) which should type text into some fields and then click on a save button at the top of the page.  Expected behavior: All elements are visible and Selenium can interact with them.  Actual behavior: After the text is typed into the text fields (a scroll down is automatically performed while doing so), the save button should be clicked (at the top of the page). However, the page gets stucked somehow, and it seems that the upper part of the page is not available anymore (the page source in this case shows no missing items).  This happens for me with Selenium 2.47, 2.46 and 2.45 and Firefox 37 and Firefox 39.  There are no issues with Chrome.

column3: [Java][Client]Driver command "[Get]/status" required session id
column4: Step to reproduce: 1. Start WebDriver server. 2. Execute command "[Get]/status" => throw exception "Session id not found".  I see this command in this document which doesn't require Session id ("https://github.com/seleniumhq/selenium/wiki/jsonwireprotocol")  Please help me to check this issue

column3: Javadoc not being released to maven2 repo for selenium-java
column4: Starting with Selenium 2.45.0, the javadocs for selenium-java are not appearing in the maven repo.  ex: http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/seleniumhq/selenium/selenium-java/2.45.0/  This is still an issue with the latest 2.47.1: http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/seleniumhq/selenium/selenium-java/2.47.1/

column3: exception thrown when running tests with no nodes registered on hub
column4: So as a little background we have a selenium grid provisioned in AWS which autoscales based upon the following metric:  {"configuration":["newSessionRequestCount"]}  so essentially the number of session requests which have not been allocated to a webdriver for execution. However - due to cost saving (we have no work happening for 12 hours a day) i attempted to take the minimum size of our selenium grid to 0 (and there are no nodes attached to the hub) - however when doing so i get the following error:  UnknownError: Error forwarding the new session Empty pool of VM for setup Capabilities [{count=1, browserName=chrome}] at new bot.Error (node_modules\protractor\node_modules\sel enium-webdriver\lib\atoms\error.js:109:18) at Object.bot.response.checkResponse (node_modules\protrac tor\node_modules\selenium-webdriver\lib\atoms\response.js:106:9)  I'm wondering if there is a way of toggling this error or statically defining capabilities so that when new session requests come in they are queued by the hub (as they would if the grid was oversubscribed), This would trigger some selenium nodes to appear in the grid

column3: C# RemoteWebDriver.GetAttribute() Converts Attribute Values That Are ISO DateTimes To Local Culture DateTime Strings
column4: Since updating to version 2.48.0 of the Selenium.WebDriver NuGet package earlier today, an assert on a test that I have has started to fail.  The test in question is asserting on the value of a data attribute which holds a date and time in ISO 8601 format (`yyyy-MM-ddTHH:mm:ssZ`). This format is being specifically used to account for differences in time zones so that tests can be run consistently and that times are correctly interpreted as UTC times by relevant application code.  Since the update the value returned by `RemoteWebDriver.GetAttribute(string)` has changed format. Where previously the call returned `2015-11-04T23:59:59` (the raw value of the relevant attribute) it now returns `04/11/2015 23:59:59` on my Windows 7 SP1 computer configured to use UK English.  I'm guessing the offender is [this line of code](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/dotnet/src/webdriver/Remote/RemoteWebElement.cs#L428).  If `commandResponse.Value` is a `DateTime` value, then the default behaviour of `DateTime.ToString()` is to format the date string for the current culture. My guess would be that something that has changed which is causing the value to be converted to a `DateTime`, rather than being left alone as a `string` (which is what it is, given attributes are just strings).  Either: 1. Attribute values should not be converted to any other data type and left as their raw values by whatever the underlying code that is fetching the attribute's value from the browser in the first place; 2. `Convert.ToString(object, IFormatProvider)` should be used with `CultureInfo.InvariantCulture` instead of `object.ToString()` so that culture-specific formatting rules (commas, decimals, date formats etc.) are not applied when `commandResponse.Value` is converted into a `string`.  There are similar calls to `commandResponse.Value.ToString()` throughout the code for this class (lines 83, 99, 428 and 465), so other methods in the `RemoteWebDriver` class could be similarly affected depending on the context.

column3: Webdriver Issues With Firefox since v2.48.0
column4: Since the 2.48 version of webdriver we are experienceing a lot of issues in the behaviour. - On the site we test there is a mouse over drop-down menu which opens when we try to click near to that on an element. WebDriver throws an WebDriverException because the elemet is not clickable at this point. (I see this is because a change). It's a really strang behaviour there is nothing on the code which triggers the drop-down should be opened. I am not fully aware how webdriver works and what has changed since v2.47 but we don't faced with this earlier.  - Besides we have a lot of failing tests because WebDriver doesn't wait for the page to be completly loaded. E.g. we want to check the presence of an error message after clicked on a button. In the 2.47 version it worked properly but know it fails.

column3: Sending keys to an Internet Explorer 9 / 10 / 11 file upload form causes the OS file browser window to open
column4: Sending keys to an Internet Explorer 9 / 10 / 11 file upload form causes the OS file browser window to open.  Python bindings Selenium 2.46.0, 2.48.0 IEDriverServer_Win32_2.46.0, IEDriverServer_Win32_2.48.0 Windows 10, Windows 7 and Windows 2012  Test example as follows;  ```         JS Bin                      ```  ``` from selenium import webdriver from selenium.webdriver.common.keys import Keys from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait  driver = webdriver.Ie() driver.get("http://jsbin.com/cunodo") WebDriverWait(driver, 30).until(EC.visibility_of_element_located((By.ID, "npkchooser"))) driver.find_element_by_id("npkchooser").send_keys("c:\\test_file.txt") ```  Please let me know what further information you require.

column3: selenium-webdriver/remote: SeleniumServer.start does not resolve
column4: SeleniumServer.start returns a promise that does not resolve if no option is provided to the `start` function. See below:  ``` javascript var SeleniumServer = require('selenium-webdriver/remote').SeleniumServer; var pathToSeleniumJar = '/workspace/protractor/selenium/selenium-server-standalone-2.48.2.jar';  var options = undefined; // Uncomment the following and the test will work fine.  // var options = { //   port: 4444 // } var server = new SeleniumServer(pathToSeleniumJar, options);  server.start().then(function(url) {   console.log('Never reached'); }); ```

column3: Capability Flag in IE Ignores Control Panel Mouse Setting
column4: Selenium version: 2.48.2 (selenium-server-standalone-2.48.2) Language: Java (1.8.0_66) IE Version: 9.0.8112.16421  This issue is only visible for users that have _reversed_ the mouse buttons in the control panel because they are using their mouse left handed.  In IE, when the user sets the Desired Capability flag to ".REQUIRE_WINDOW_FOCUS" and has reversed mouse buttons, Selenium ignores the control panel settings and issues the wrong click event.   To reproduce the issue do the following: 1.  In the control panel, reverse the mouse buttons. 2.  Create and run a script with the following code:  > DesiredCapabilities capabilities = DesiredCapabilities.internetExplorer(); > capabilities.setCapability(InternetExplorerDriver.REQUIRE_WINDOW_FOCUS, true); > WebDriver webdr = new InternetExplorerDriver(capabilities); >  > webdr.get("google.com"); > WebElement image = webdr.findElement(By.id("hplogo")); > image.click();  You will notice that when the click event is issued, Selenium issues a right-click event rather than the normal left-click.

column3: Selenium IDE chrome/content/formats/html.js has an incorrect regex
column4: Selenium IDE 2.5.0 (and potentially earlier) up to 2.9.1 (inclusive) and also current https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/ide/main/src/content/formats/html.js has an incorrect regular regex for commandLoadPattern.  Current source code:  ``` javascript this.options = {     commandLoadPattern:     "]*>" +     "\\s*()?" +     "\\s*]*>\\s*([\\w]*?)\\s*" +     "\\s*]*>([\\d\\D]*?)" +     "\\s*(|]*>([\\d\\D]*?))" +     "\\s*\\s*", ...  Bug: every \s should be \\s Change to:  this.options = {     commandLoadPattern:     "]*>" +     "\\s*()?" +     "\\s*]*>\\s*([\\w]*?)\\s*" +     "\\s*]*>([\\d\\D]*?)" +     "\\s*(|]*>([\\d\\D]*?))" +     "\\s*\\s*",... ```  I'm willing to provide a github pull request for this, if you indicate the issue as accepted.  This could be implemented together with https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/1546, which depends on this issue and it changes the same regex.  (Originally reported as https://code.google.com/archive/p/selenium/issues/6901. However, Google Code misformatted the suggested code fix in that issue.)

column3: Selenium IDE chrome/content/formats/html.js to preserve indented Selenese command names
column4: Selenium IDE 2.5.0 (and most likely the recent dev/trunk) allows Selenese commands (the 1st column) to be indented with spaces. It saves such spaces as  . However, when a user loads a test case, it doesn't parse such commands. They only show up in the 'Source' tab, and once the user saves the test suite again, they're deleted.  Indeed, one may argue that there's not much need for indented Selenese when having plain linear test cases. But even then a user can type space(s) left of Selenese by mistake. The test case works for him or her then, but it won't work when he or she reloads it later. Hence this is a bug.   Furthermore, Selenese can be structured through if/else, loop and script statements using SeLite, SelBlocks or FlowControl. Their users would greatly benefit from such indentation being preserved.  A fix is to change [content/formats/html.js](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/ide/main/src/content/formats/html.js) to use the following (incorporating https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/1636):  ``` javascript this.options = {     commandLoadPattern:     "]*>" +     "\\s*()?" +     "\\s*]*>\\s*([\\w]*?)\\s*" +     "\\s*]*>([\\d\\D]*?)" +     "\\s*(|]*>([\\d\\D]*?))" +     "\\s*\\s*",  to  this.options = {     commandLoadPattern:     "]*>" +     "\\s*()?" +     "\\s*]*>\\s*((?: )*[\\w]*?)\\s*" +     "\\s*]*>([\\d\\D]*?)" +     "\\s*(|]*>([\\d\\D]*?))" +     "\\s*\\s*", ```  I'm willing to provide a github pull request.  This depends on and could be implemented together with https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/1636.  (Originally reported as https://code.google.com/archive/p/selenium/issues/6903. However, Google Code misformatted the suggested code fix in that issue.)

column3: Can't click on WebElement
column4: Selenium fails with the error below when trying to click on the WebElement.  The driver does click on the element when the Mac Book Pro screen resolution is set to its max: 1920 x 1200 but fails when using the Mac Book Pro default 1440 x 900 or 1680 x 1050 resolutions.  I can't avoid but wonder if this is related to [Mac Book Pro Retina scaled mode](http://www.anandtech.com/show/5996/how-the-retina-display-macbook-pro-handles-scaling).    ``` org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: Element is not clickable at point (1194.9000244140625, 611.2000122070312). Other element would receive the click:  Command duration or timeout: 68 milliseconds Build info: version: '2.49.0', revision: '365eeb44deba2067b1761c8862ef21d55250e063', time: '2016-01-13 11:57:39' System info: host: 'mbp.locall', ip: '192.168.5.7', os.name: 'Mac OS X', os.arch: 'x86_64', os.version: '10.11.2', java.version: '1.7.0_67' Session ID: 99ed5a92-a255-f94c-8f2a-b1fe462d11c8 Driver info: org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver Capabilities [{platform=MAC, acceptSslCerts=true, javascriptEnabled=true, cssSelectorsEnabled=true, databaseEnabled=true, browserName=firefox, handlesAlerts=true, nativeEvents=false, webStorageEnabled=true, rotatable=false, locationContextEnabled=true, applicationCacheEnabled=true, takesScreenshot=true, version=43.0.4}] ```

column3: By.LinkText doesn't work with elements having text-transform:capitalize style
column4: Selenium fails to find elements which have "text-transform:capitalize" style applied. Please see the test case below. Selenium finds elements which have "uppercase" and "lowercase" or no transformations successfully, but fails on "capitalize".  Tested with Selenium v2.45.0 (C#). Chrome/FF, Windows/Linux  Example html:  ``` html                    Hello world! foo-bar-BAZ         Hello world! foo-bar-BAZ         Hello world! foo-bar-BAZ         Hello world! foo-bar-BAZ       ```  The transformed text looks like this:  ``` HELLO WORLD! FOO-BAR-BAZ hello world! foo-bar-baz Hello World! Foo-Bar-BAZ Hello world! foo-bar-BAZ ```  Example test:  ``` cs using OpenQA.Selenium; using OpenQA.Selenium.Chrome;  namespace SeleniumLinkTest {     class Program     {         static void Main(string[] args)         {             using (var driver = new ChromeDriver())             {                 driver.Navigate().GoToUrl("http://localhost");                  var upper = driver.FindElement(By.LinkText("HELLO WORLD! FOO-BAR-BAZ"));                 var lower = driver.FindElement(By.LinkText("hello world! foo-bar-baz"));                 var capital = driver.FindElement(By.LinkText("Hello World! Foo-Bar-BAZ")); // fails with NoSuchElementException                 var none = driver.FindElement(By.LinkText("Hello world! foo-bar-BAZ"));             }         }     } } ```

column3: Applitools Eyes - IE PDF - parameter not valid exception
column4: Selenium Eyes version: 1.52.0 IE version: IE 11 Selenium Web Driver version: 2.48.2 ## Problem general description:  when a pdf file is opened in IE and examined by selenium eyes an exception of parameter not valid is thrown.   basically the first test step is navigate that contains the location of the pdf file, using the eyes api we are calling CheckWindow() and the exception is thrown.  i believe the issue is the instance of the Selenium IE Web Driver.    this same operation works fine in FF and Chrome.  System.ArgumentException was caught   HResult=-2147024809   Message=Parameter is not valid. column3: Support for Windows 10 in Platform (.net bindings)
column4: Selenium 2.48.2 .NET Framework 4.5.2 Firefox 41 Windows 10  I've encountered an issue trying to run the Firefox driver locally when using Windows 10 and I think I've tracked it down to Platform.cs.  Take a look at this snippet of code.  ``` this.major = Environment.OSVersion.Version.Major;             this.minor = Environment.OSVersion.Version.Minor;              switch (Environment.OSVersion.Platform)             {                 case PlatformID.Win32NT:                     if (this.major == 5)                     {                         this.platformTypeValue = PlatformType.XP;                     }                     else if (this.major == 6)                     {                         this.platformTypeValue = PlatformType.Vista;                     }                      break;                  // Thanks to a bug in Mono Mac and Linux will be treated the same  https://bugzilla.novell.com/show_bug.cgi?id=515570 but adding this in case                 case PlatformID.MacOSX:                     this.platformTypeValue = PlatformType.Mac;                     break;                  case PlatformID.Unix:                     this.platformTypeValue = PlatformType.Unix;                     break;             }         } ```  As you can see, when the PlatformID is Win32NT, it checks for major versions 5 and 6.  Windows 10 has a major version of 10.  When I run locally, I'm instantiating the firefox driver like this.  ``` IWebDriver driver = new FirefoxDriver(); ```  When I attempt to run a test, selenium seemingly is unable to find the Firefox executable.   In an attempt to track down the issue, I downloaded the source for version 2.48.2 of selenium and build the dotnet bindings as is so I could get the debug symbols.  Here is the stack trace.  ``` System.ComponentModel.Win32Exception : The system cannot find the file specified TearDown : System.ApplicationException : Unable to retrieve the browser driver for the current thread.  at System.Diagnostics.Process.StartWithCreateProcess(ProcessStartInfo startInfo)    at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.Internal.Executable.LocateFirefoxBinaryFromPlatform() in    c:\Users\bjharo\Documents\selenium\selenium-selenium-2.48.2\dotnet\src\webdriver\Firefox\Internal\Executable.cs:line 197  at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.Internal.Executable..ctor(String userSpecifiedBinaryPath) in     c:\Users\bjharo\Documents\selenium\selenium-selenium-2.48.2\dotnet\src\webdriver\Firefox\Internal\Executable.cs:line 63     at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxBinary..ctor(String pathToFirefoxBinary)     in c:\Users\bjharo\Documents\selenium\selenium-selenium-2.48.2\dotnet\src\webdriver\Firefox\FirefoxBinary.cs:line 66     at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxDriver..ctor()     in c:\Users\bjharo\Documents\selenium\selenium-selenium-2.48.2\dotnet\src\webdriver\Firefox\FirefoxDriver.cs:line 119     at Automation.Ui.Interface.Browser.BrowserDriverFactory.GetSeleniumDriver()     in C:\dev\CRM\Automation\Automation.Ui.Interface\Browser\BrowserDriverFactory.cs:line 125     at Automation.Ui.Interface.Browser.BrowserDriverFactory.GetBrowser()     in C:\dev\CRM\Automation\Automation.Ui.Interface\Browser\BrowserDriverFactory.cs:line 67     at Automation.Ui.Tests.BaseUiTest.BaseUiTestSetup()     in C:\dev\CRM\Automation\Automation.Ui.Tests\BaseUiTest.cs:line 71 ```  Looking at where it is failing in Executable.cs at line 197, it appears to be executing a code block when current platform is not detected to be Windows so it's trying to find a file that does not exist.  I debugged through the code at at the point where the FirefoxDriver should be instantiated, Platform.CurrentPlatforms show the current type as Platform.Any.  That leads me to the conclusion that since Platform.cs does not take a major version of 10 in account, it is failing to detect Windows 10 as being Windows.  I tried to just specify the Firefox binary directly.  ``` var ffbinary = new FirefoxBinary(@"C:\Program Files (x86)\Mozilla Firefox\firefox.exe"); IWebDriver driver = new FirefoxDriver(ffbinary, new FirefoxProfile()); ```  This works but it has a bad side effect.  I cannot run more than one instance of Firefox at once.  I see the following errors when I try to run 2 or more test threads at one time.  ``` OpenQA.Selenium.WebDriverException : Unable to bind to locking port 7054 within 45000 milliseconds ```  My setup does work with other operating systems and Firefox.  I can run multiple instance of Firefox at once using Selenium 2.48.2 on both OS X 10.11 and Windows Server 2012.

column3: Unable to send value to input text in firefox 38, selenium 2.47.1
column4: Selenium 2.47.1, firefox 38 - When trying to fill in a form, elem.sendKeys("String") isn't working, the input remains empty 50% of the time. Works in debug, but when running it doesn't work. Also I've tried to put some sleeps and wait for elements but still it didn't work.  In the previous version of selenium it didn't work 90% of the time.  Is it a familiar issue?

column3: Frames are not identified when the browser user interface is not available (tests are run as services)
column4: Scenario : Integrating the selenium maven tests with Jenkins/Teamcity in order to schedule these tests once in a week. The tests are for automating a website which contains many frames and subframes. So in order to identify an element every time i need to switch among frames.  Code snippet :  String Username = s.getCell(0,row).getContents(); String Password = s.getCell(1,row).getContents(); Login(Username,Password); Thread.sleep(5000); driver.switchTo().frame(0);  Problem: When the tests are run through command line or eclipse, they pass. Problem occurs when the tests are run through Jenkins/Teamcity. The reason might be that these two tools (Jenkins/Teamcity) do not perform tests on real browsers. Instead the tests are run from backend. Hence, the frames are not identified and exception is thrown.   Note : Even after putting wait condition before switching to frame exception is thrown.  Expected output : Frames should be identified and switched successfully. column3: rb: Support Safari::Options#clean_session?
column4: Safari supports resetting itself using the `--resetSafari` command- line option (true as of 8.0.8 -- not sure how far back that is supported).  If the `clean_session:true` option/capability is provided to the Safari driver, append `--resetSafari` to the command-line arguments.

column3: problems with $ in a string
column4:
Runing firefox 42.0 and Next Generation Java Plug-in 10.80.2 for Mozilla browsers Webdriver version 2.47.1  When I send the driver a string with an embedded $ character it cause the webdriver to exit to the parent string.  I can see from the wireshark trace below the $ charcaters is being sent to the local loopback for the wed driver.  On the screen I just see”sparky1” and then it exits.  I have tried all of the normal escape sequences and nothing seems to work. How can I send the string "sparky$1' as just ascii text?  Wireshark trace   bytes: b'POST /hub/session/dd854199-8912-4eb1-b4c6-6060ab2a7fc8/element/{c58d697c-1c4f-43ba-97cd-3a561f059c3a}/value HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:59649
Accept-Encoding: identity
Content-Length: 152
Accept:   application/json
Content-type: application/json;charset="UTF-8"
User-Agent: Python http auth
POST:   /hub/session/dd854199-8912-4eb1-b4c6-6060ab2a7fc8/element/{c58d697c-1c4f-43ba-97cd-3a561f059c3a} /value
Connection: keep-alive

{"sessionId": "dd854199-8912-4eb1-b4c6-6060ab2a7fc8", "value": ["s", "p", "a",  "r", "k", "y", "$", "1"], "id": "{c58d697c-1c4f-43ba-97cd-3a561f059c3a}"}'  str.join Found at: http.client msg = b"
".join(self._buffer)  Webdriver code   ``` def _send_output(self, message_body=None):     """Send the currently buffered request and clear the buffer.     Appends an extra \r\n to the buffer.     A message_body may be specified, to be appended to the request.     """     self._buffer.extend((b"", b""))     msg = b"
".join(self._buffer)     del self._buffer[:]     # If msg and message_body are sent in a single send() call,     # it will avoid performance problems caused by the interaction     # between delayed ack and the Nagle algorithm. However,     # there is no performance gain if the message is larger     # than MSS (and there is a memory penalty for the message     # copy).     if isinstance(message_body, bytes) and len(message_body) < self.mss:         msg += message_body         message_body = None     self.send(msg)     if message_body is not None:         # message_body was not a string (i.e. it is a file), and         # we must run the risk of Nagle.         self.send(message_body)  def putrequest(self, method, url, skip_host=0, skip_accept_encoding=0):     """Send a request to the server.     `method' specifies an HTTP request method, e.g. 'GET'.     `url' specifies the object being requested, e.g. '/index.html'.     `skip_host' if True does not add automatically a 'Host:' header     `skip_accept_encoding' if True does not add automatically an        'Accept-Encoding:' header     """     # if a prior response has been completed, then forget about it.     if self.__response and self.__response.isclosed():         self.__response = None ```

column3: Parse message when error response is dictionary

column3: Clues about a Bug causing instability in DriverService in selenium-java
column4: Referring to this issue I created a while back, https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/676  , I think the source of the issue is that waitUntilAvailable() is too quick to check status code of the process, before it has even completed or had a chance to return a status code. When I used apache commons libs with a tool called jscover, I had this same issue and it got completely fixed when I added a 1s pause before the first attempt to check status.  Can something like this be done for this code too? It seems to be causing sporadic failures quite frequently for me, with just about any driver (since the bug is in the selenium-java layer code)  The code I am referring to is here:  https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/9c1b1e66c9326c8d7c38cc7fb8814877210a4388/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/remote/service/DriverService.java

column3: Unexpected UnreachableBrowserExceptions when using FirefoxDriver
column4: Recently, I ran into some unexpected UnreachableBrowserExceptions. More on this in a second. For context, here is my setup. Imagine a longer-running Java program that uses FirefoxDriver to test a web site. At the end of the test, the program    - collects some values from the browser, - takes a last screenshot, and - finally quits the driver, so the browser process gets removed.  If this program does not run to completion, but is terminated externally (via Ctrl-C or signal), it should nevertheless execute the above steps, so they are implemented as a JVM shutdown hook which is called in any case.  However, since moving the cleanup code to the shutdown hook, the driver receives an UnreachableBrowserException for any command in the shutdown hook, even though the browser is still alive. See the Java class below that demonstrates this behavior.  After some debugging I believe that this issue is caused by the fact that once program termination is initiated, the browser's profile directory gets cleaned immediately, ie. while the browser is still being actively used. This happens via the shutdown hook of class TemporaryFilesystem.  When profile cleaning is disabled temporarily by setting the system property "webdriver.reap_profile = false", no UnreachableBrowserExceptions will be thrown and the cleanup code works fine.  Cleaning up the profile directory should probably be done by quit() alone.  [Tested on Windows 7/Linux with Selenium 2.47.1. ChromeDriver is not affected.]  **Test Case**  ``` java import org.openqa.selenium.OutputType; import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver;  public class UnreachableBrowserExceptionTest {     public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException     {         // enable this to make the issue go away         // System.setProperty("webdriver.reap_profile", "false");          final FirefoxDriver driver = new FirefoxDriver();          // add a shutdown hook to ensure browser cleanup even in the event of termination         Runtime.getRuntime().addShutdownHook(new Thread()         {             public void run()             {                 try                 {                     // wait some time as the issue is slightly timing-dependent                     Thread.sleep(1000);                      driver.getScreenshotAs(OutputType.BYTES);                 }                 catch (Exception e)                 {                     e.printStackTrace();                 }                 finally                 {                     try                     {                         driver.quit();                     }                     catch (Exception e)                     {                         e.printStackTrace();                     }                 }             }         });          // here the test begins         driver.get("https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium");          // now let the shutdown hook do the cleanup     } } ```

column3: Webdriver javascript profile keys undocumented
column4: Recently while troubleshooting an issue with selenium not working on a fresh install of Ubuntu 14.04 I stumbled across a rather old bug that was causing the loopback address logic to timeout: https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=3280#c5  The one time hack is to reorder my host aliases. The better solution is to configure the firefox profile with host preference. I could not find they key to set this preference, but @jleyba pointed out the key is `webdriver_firefox_allowed_hosts`. https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/1403#issuecomment-169478200 https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/1403#issuecomment-169492291  This matches the Java documentation: https://selenium.googlecode.com/git/docs/api/java/constant-values.html  It does not seem to be documented for javascript or exposed as an object: https://selenium.googlecode.com/git/docs/api/javascript/module_selenium-webdriver_firefox_class_Profile.html#setPreference  Ideally the key constants can be exposed to the javascript API and documented.  Also I would like to dig into the underlying issue with the loopback address and see if that can be fixed.

column3: Test with SVG Elements on IE 11 are slow
column4: Python selenium version 2.49, IE11 Windows 10. webdriver IE 32 bit or 64 bit.  My test with SVG elements on IE 11 are running very slowly. The same test on Chrome and Firefox runs as expected. Completing in 60 seconds. On IE11 runs successfully but the execution time is 10 minutes!  Selenium launches the app fairly quickly and then proceeds to test. Elements are located quickly until it gets to the SVG component in the application; using the action chain methods it moves quickly to the first g element and then slows to a crawl to the others.  I have tried both 32 and 64bit versions of IE webdriver. Version 2.48 This is a locally run script.( Not remote. I have no results for that test.)  Expected: to execute as successfully in IE 11 as it does on chrome or firefox. Find and assert the SVG g elements.  Actual: Find and assert the SVG g elements but is painfully slow. May as well be done manually.  Any ideas?

column3: Program freezes when accessing Chrome driver after clicking __blank link which opens a xml
column4: Python 2.7.9, Ubuntu 14.04.3 x64, Selenium 2.48.0, Chrome 47.0.2526.106 (64-bit), ChromeDriver 2.20  When using Chrome driver, if you click a link with selenium with target="_blank", and the linked url points to a xml file, then when switching to the xml window and accessing driver properties such as current_url will freeze the script. If you Ctrl+C then you get this backtrace:  ``` pytb Traceback (most recent call last):   File "/tmp/bug.py", line 10, in      print driver.current_url   File "/tmp/.env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 454, in current_url     return self.execute(Command.GET_CURRENT_URL)['value']   File "/tmp/.env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 199, in execute     response = self.command_executor.execute(driver_command, params)   File "/tmp/.env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/remote_connection.py", line 395, in execute     return self._request(command_info[0], url, body=data)   File "/tmp/.env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/remote_connection.py", line 426, in _request     resp = self._conn.getresponse()   File "/opt/python/lib/python2.7/httplib.py", line 1073, in getresponse     response.begin()   File "/opt/python/lib/python2.7/httplib.py", line 415, in begin     version, status, reason = self._read_status()   File "/opt/python/lib/python2.7/httplib.py", line 371, in _read_status     line = self.fp.readline(_MAXLINE + 1)   File "/opt/python/lib/python2.7/socket.py", line 476, in readline     data = self._sock.recv(self._rbufsize) KeyboardInterrupt ```  The attached script and files reproduce the problem and are also listed below  bug.py  ``` py from selenium import webdriver  chrome_profile = webdriver.ChromeOptions() driver = webdriver.Chrome(chrome_options=chrome_profile)  driver.get('file:///tmp/index.html') a = driver.find_element_by_tag_name('a') a.click() driver.switch_to.window(driver.window_handles[1]) print driver.current_url ```  index.html  ``` html  doc ```  doc.xml  ``` xml   ```  [freeze_open_blank_xml.zip](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/81354/freeze_open_blank_xml.zip)

column3: Python (and thus Java Standalone Server) thinks it cannot go back and forward in Safari
column4: Python (and thus Java Standalone Server) thinks it cannot go back and forward in Safari. calling driver.back() or driver.forward() generates an exception with a the message: selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: Yikes! Safari history navigation does not work. We can go forward or back, but once we do, we can no longer communicate with the page... (WARNING: The server did not provide any stacktrace information)  This is absurd. The very JavaScript history.back() and history.forward() work just fine. They work so fine, that they work from driver.execute_script() with either  > > > sg.driver.execute_script('history.forward()') > > > sg.driver.execute_script('history.back()')   Should be reasonable to implement.

column3: Python remote client does not implement read timeouts
column4: Problem description:  When a WebDriver instance makes a remote command request, and the server accepts the connection and reads the request but does not write a response, then the client continues waiting indefinitely for a response.  Expected results:  The WebDriver client raises some kind of TimeOut exception after sending a request and not receiving a response within some predefined time period.  Actual results:  The WebDriver client blocks indefinitely (or until the connection is terminated, etc).  Steps to reproduce:  1) Listen on port 4444 with netcat: `nc -l 4444` 2) Use Python client to issue a webdriver command: `python -c 'from selenium.webdriver.remote.webdriver import WebDriver; WebDriver("http://127.0.0.1:4444/wd/hub", {})'` 3) Observe that the client blocks and never times out

column3: WebElement __eq__ compares against more types
column4: Prior to the definition of **ne**, many users were using != with items without 'id' attr. These users are broken by the new definition of **ne** as **eq** raises an AttributeError. Ensure **eq** returns false when no 'id' attr is defined.

column3: Compute the correct pageX/Y for touch events.
column4: Previously, pageX/Y were always the same as clientX/Y, which would be incorrect if the page had been scrolled.  Submitted on behalf of a Googler.

column3: HtmlUnitMouse: no need to .focus()
column4: Previously, HtmlUnit didn't correctly handle 'focus' event on .click()ing an element, but now it does.  This change fixes a test case  Also, the constructor with HtmlUnitDriver is not needed, so it is deprecated.

column3: {} vs [] for use with non-number indices
column4: Prepare for tightening of the Array definition which would make this warning an error.

column3: Fix format string.
column4: Preconditions.checkArgument only accepts "%s", and not "%d" or any of the other placeholders.

column3: IDE: alert() fails in a modified test case
column4: Open and modify an existing test case, or create a new test case, with one following Selenese command. (Do not open a saved test case with the following command. If you do, then modify the test case - e.g. by adding whitespace - before running it.)  getEval | alert('hi')  Run by 'Play current test case' button. As expected, the alert shows up (saying 'hi'). However, the test case fails.  The problem only happens when you have a new test case, or you modify a test case (regardless of whether you then save it or not), and if it calls getEval | alert(...). However, if you load such a test case and you run it without any modification, then the problem doesn't show up.  Runs: 1 Failures: 1  Log:  ``` [info] Playing test case Untitled [info] Executing: |getEval | alert('h') | | [info] script is: alert('h') [error] Threw an exception:  [info] Test case failed  ```  ---  Test with a blank Firefox profile, Selenium IDE 2.9.1 and following versions of Firefox:  Firefox 44.0 "E:\SW\Mozilla Firefox 45.0\firefox.exe" -no-remote -P alert "C:\Program Files\Mozilla Firefox 46.0b1\firefox.exe" -no-remote -P alert "E:\SW\Mozilla Firefox Nightly 2016-03-07\firefox.exe"  -no-remote -P alert (e10s Multiprocessing turned off)

column3: W3C endpoints for execute
column4: Only the JSON Wire Protocol endpoints to marionette through the remote server currently work: /session/{session id}/execute and /session/{session id}/execute_async  The W3C endpoints to marionette through the remote server do not currently work: /session/{session id}/execute/sync and /session/{session id}/execute/async  Marionette does support them, as they work when I run them locally, directly through Ruby bindings.

column3: Kill binary so profile folders can be deleted
column4: On Windows, Firefox locks its profile folders and files so they can't be deleted while Firefox is running, so shutil.rmtree will always fail if Firefox is still running.

column3: Fixes the Windows crash dialog box when Firefox quits
column4: On Windows and when a plugin is loaded in Firefox, a child process is created. But when the quit command is called, this child process remains and a crash dialog box is displayed.  **Changes** This fix uses the Windows taskkill command instead of the python kill method.  **Scope** Python language binding Windows platform  **To reproduce**  ``` import selenium, time from selenium import webdriver driver = webdriver.Firefox() driver.get('https://www.dhs.state.il.us/accessibility/tests/flash/video.html') time.sleep(2) driver.quit() ```  **Screenshot**  ![crash-dialog](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/918557/9069973/93799606-3ae4-11e5-9e5d-20a59f418d50.png)

column3: Adding El Capitan (OS X 10.11) to the Platform enum
column4: Now that OS X 10.11 has been released (September 30, 2015), we should add it to the Platform enum as we have for all other versions of OS X since 10.6.

column3: [Improvement] Add ability to listen for "refresh" WebDriver events
column4: Now org.openqa.selenium.support.events.WebDriverEventListener supports different navigation event types (before/after navigate to/back/forward). But there is no ability to listen for refresh events. Could you please add this functionality?

column3: Re-evaluate Node.js support policy
column4: Node.js >= 4.0.0 has a different release policy than earlier versions. Each 6 months a new major gets released, every even major gets promoted to LTS **once the next major is released**. This means that the moment Node.js 6.0.0 gets released the only Node.js LTS actively supported will be 4; when Node 8.0.0 gets released the only actively supported LTS will be 6 (v4 will still receive critical security fixes but this will be a "maintenance phase"; apps shouldn't be developed on such Nodes but only maintained so it seems fine to drop support there). See https://github.com/nodejs/LTS for more details (the graph at the bottom is pretty descriptive). Non-LTS Nodes lose support 2 months after the next Node gets released. Node.js 4 will still be supported after Node.js 5 loses support etc.  If you just support latest two Node.js releases, for half of the time there will be **no Node.js LTS release** that you'll be supporting; this sounds bad.  Could the support policy be changed to supporting the latest stable release & the latest supported LTS? This will still be two versions but an LTS will be supported which seems good. This is how it'd look like: 1. current state - support for Node.js 4 & 5 2. Node.js 6 gets released - support for Node.js 4 & 6 3. Node.js 7 gets released - support for Node.js 6 & 7 4. Node.js 8 gets released - support for Node.js 6 & 8 5. Node.js 9 gets released - support for Node.js 8 & 9 6. Node.js 10 gets released - support for Node.js 8 & 10 7. Node.js 11 gets released - support for Node.js 10 & 11 8. etc.  How does that sound? Ideally you'd support all stable versions supported by upstream (there is always only 1 or 2 of them) but that would complicate things a little as sometimes you'd test on 2 versions and sometimes on 3.

column3: Refactor TestCase.debugContext to have a class on its own
column4: No bug. Simple/trivial enhancement of Se IDE that - makes the code more structured readable - allows easier maintenance of 3rd part flow control plugins (like SelBlocks/SelBlocks Global/Control Flow) - backwards compatible  This is Se IDE-specific. Basically, currently TestCase class uses an anonymous object for its object field debugContext. The code of that anonymous debugContext object refers back to the TestCase via a closure variable 'testCase'.  I propose a new class TestCaseDebugContext. TestCase.debugContext will be an instance of that class. Its constructor and object field 'testCase' will link to the given TestCase instance (the owner of debugContext). That way references between them are clear and over the board.  That allows 3rd party to tail-extend prototype methods of TestCaseDebugContext, if needed. It is backwards compatible with Se IDE.  Attached is a git diff (against current master). Following is the suggested code - for ide/main/src/content/testCase.js  function TestCaseDebugContext( testCase ) {     this.testCase= testCase; }  TestCaseDebugContext.prototype.reset= function() {     this.failed = false;     this.started = false;     this.debugIndex = -1; };  TestCaseDebugContext.prototype.nextCommand= function() {     if (!this.started) {         this.started = true;         this.debugIndex = this.testCase.startPoint             ? this.testCase.commands.indexOf(this.testCase.startPoint)             : 0;     } else {         this.debugIndex++;     }     for (; this.debugIndex < this.testCase.commands.length; this.debugIndex++) {         var command = this.testCase.commands[this.debugIndex];         if (command.type == 'command') {             return command;         }     }     return null; };  TestCaseDebugContext.prototype.currentCommand= function() {     var command = this.testCase.commands[this.debugIndex];     if (!command) {         this.testCase.log.warn("currentCommand() not found: commands.length=" + this.testCase.commands.length + ", debugIndex=" + this.debugIndex);     }     return command; };  function TestCase(tempTitle) {     ....     this.debugContext= new TestCaseDebugContext( this ); }  See a .diff file attached to https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=5495.  Selenium version: 2.9.1 Browser: Firefox  Browser version: 44.0 (Originall reported as https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=5495)

column3: Python Selenium Firefox on Ubuntu: New Tabs Not Working
column4: New tabs in Firefox are not opening up for this configuration: - Ubuntu 14.04.2 - Python 2.7.6 - Selenium 2.47.1 - PyVirtualDisplay 0.1.3  Example:  ``` from selenium import webdriver from selenium.webdriver.common.keys import Keys from selenium.webdriver.common.action_chains import ActionChains from pyvirtualdisplay import Display  # launch our headless display  display = Display(visible=0, size=(800, 600)) display.start()  # launch our web driver and get a page browser = webdriver.Firefox() browser.get("http://www.google.com/")  # try to open a new tab ActionChains(browser).key_down(Keys.CONTROL).send_keys("t").key_up(Keys.CONTROL).perform()  # this should print 2, but it prints 1, because new tab not opened print len(browser.window_handles)  # clean up everything browser.quit() display.stop() ```  Also reported on StackOverflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/32040316/python-selenium-firefox-on-ubuntu-new-tabs-not-working

column3: "Access violation reading location" in IISExpress 10 (in webengine4.dll) with IEDriverServer 12.6
column4: My configuration as follows. XUnit runner (1.9.2) fires tests generated using SpecFlow. IISExpress 10 starts in singleton like this:  ``` _iisProcess = new Process {      StartInfo = {          FileName = Path.Combine(programFiles, @"IIS Express\iisexpress.exe")          }      };  var applicationPath = GetApplicationPath(); _iisProcess.StartInfo.Arguments = string.Format(     "/path:{0} /port:{1} /systray:false /trace:e",     applicationPath,     IisPort); // so far 9090 _iisProcess.Start(); ```  Selenium IEDriverServer.exe (2.46) configured as this:  ``` _driver = new InternetExplorerDriver(     new InternetExplorerOptions(){EnsureCleanSession = true});  ```  The machine configured as per [this guide](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/InternetExplorerDriver#required-configuration). IEDriverServer.exe listens 17923 port.  At some points in tests IISExpress fails with "Access violation" (c0000005) error. The actual fail system test varies but looks like it happens when there is some active UI interaction. There is SignalR, dynamic content and other. The Problem signature:  ```   Problem Event Name:   APPCRASH   Application Name: iisexpress.exe   Application Version:  10.0.10046.0   Application Timestamp:    55121079   Fault Module Name:    webengine4.dll   Fault Module Version: 4.6.57.0   Fault Module Timestamp:   551b8b21   Exception Code:   c0000005   Exception Offset: 00066ccf   OS Version:   6.3.9600.2.0.0.256.48   Locale ID:    1049   Additional Information 1: 5861   Additional Information 2: 5861822e1919d7c014bbb064c64908b2   Additional Information 3: a10f   Additional Information 4: a10ff7d2bb2516fdc753f9c34fc3b069 ```  Sometimes it fails at code like this with "OpenQA.Selenium.WebDriverTimeoutException : Timed out after 30 seconds" at `DefaultWait.Until`  ```         IWait wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, TimeSpan.FromSeconds(30.00));         try         {             wait.Until(driver1 => ((IJavaScriptExecutor)driver).ExecuteScript("return document.readyState").Equals("complete"));         }         catch (InvalidOperationException ex) // js error { /*...*/  } ```  IISExpress log also does not help. It writes some last requests only and terminates:  ``` Request started: "POST" http://localhost:9090/signalr/abort?transport=webSockets... Request ended: http://localhost:9090/signalr/connect?transport=webSockets...  with HTTP status 101.0 Request ended: http://localhost:9090/signalr/abort?transport=webSockets&clientProtocol=1.4.... with HTTP status 200.0 WriteCompletedInline Action = 00000002 Action = 00000000 Request ended: http://localhost:9090/signalr/connect?transport=webSockets....  with HTTP status 101.0 Request ended: http://localhost:9090/BotDetectCaptcha.ashx?get=image&c=SampleCaptcha&t=44c45e60afac46809bfce16e123b54a2 with HTTP status 200.0 ```  It does not help if the tests run under Administrator. The same when R# test runner fires the tests.   Any your thoughts, help would be much appreciated. Thanks!  (Duplication of http://stackoverflow.com/questions/31520718/access-violation-reading-location-in-iisexpress-10-in-webengine4-dll-with-se)

column3: How to adjust polling frequency of selenium using javascript selenium-webdriver?
column4: My apologies for using the issue tracker to ask a question, but maybe we could consider it a documentation issue or missing feature :)  I was just noticing that when instructing selenium to find an element using an implicit wait, it will poll until the element is found (or time out if not found). I found some instructions for how to change the polling frequency if using java with the WebDriverWait class, but can find no equivalent for javascript when using selenium-webdriver.  Is it possible to change the polling frequency when driving the tests with node.js?  Thanks,  Chris

column3: Support for Firefox WebExtensions
column4: Mozilla introduced new [WebExtensions API](https://blog.mozilla.org/addons/2015/08/21/the-future-of-developing-firefox-add-ons/), which works already in Firefox Nightly. The old CPOWs extensions will be deprecated.  Trying to load an extension to Firefox Nightly, Seenium tries to find `install.rdf`, which doesn't exist anymore.  ``` javascript     var firefox = require('selenium-webdriver/firefox');     var binary = new firefox.Binary('/Applications/FirefoxNightly.app/Contents/MacOS/firefox');     var profile = new firefox.Profile();     profile.addExtension('./build/firefox');     var options = new firefox.Options()       .setProfile(profile)       .setBinary(binary);     this.driver = new firefox.Driver(options); ```  Any plans to support the new extension format for firefox?

column3: Inconvenient text querying & manipulation
column4: Manipulating `contenteditable` elements with webdriver (e.g. testing an RTE's flow) is quite inconvenient right now, while it's possible to get all the text of an object, selecting text requires action chains and iffy offsets, and I've found no way to get the offset of some text within an element so things are really quite inconvenient and really not cross-platform. I also haven't found a way to query text selection e.g. know/copy currently selected text.  There's always the alternative of using text ranges from within JS/DOM, but it removes much of the user-similar interaction with page content webdriver provides.

column3: Actions.doubleClick() is not working correctly in Java Selenium WebDriwer 2.48.2
column4: Looks like something happened to Actions.doubleClick() in 2.48.2 version. I had this util method working with 2.46:  > protected void doubleClickByXPath(String xpath){ > waitUntilVisibleByXPath(xpath); > WebElement e = driver.findElement(By.xpath(xpath)); > Actions a = new Actions(driver); > a.doubleClick(e); > a.perform(); > }  So it stopped working after I've upgraded to 2.48.2. If I comment last 3 lines and instead add  > e.click(); > e.click();  then it works.

column3: Python 2.46.1 bindings break findElement compatibility with third-party dirvers
column4: Lines 706-716 in selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py in 2.46.1 breaks findElement and findElements compatibility with non web drivers as it replaces all strategies with css selector strategy. This breaks mobile drivers like Appium and Winium.  This was later fixed [here](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/61e866d43e6c149bba363d63d544c15d3ed0a72e#diff-6f9f8008b5e139c03e64fedabf4b3122R719).  Can we have a fixed package released to PyPi or 2.46.1 removed from PyPi?

column3: IDE should use MutationObserver instead of Mutation Events which is deprecated
column4: Launching Selenium IDE shows a warning on debugger as such:  ``` Use of Mutation Events is deprecated. Use MutationObserver instead. ```  [According to MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/Events/Mutation_events), Mutation Events will be removed in the future. Selenium IDE is now depending on three Mutation Events: `DOMAttrModified` `DOMNodeInserted` `DOMNodeRemoved` which are replasable with MutationObserver + `subtree` option.

But on clicking Trust, nothing happens - no extension is installed.

column3: Fix ChromeOptions passing
column4: Just passing "this" will serialize the ChromeOptions object as-is. Since the var names have underscore suffixes, those are serialized as well, and none of the options are actually accepted by ChromeDriver (silently ignored).   i.e. current code leads to serialization: "chromeOptions":{"options_":{ "detach" : true },"extensions_":[],"logPrefs_":{"performance":"ALL"},"proxy_":null}  while we actually want this behaviour: "chromeOptions":{ "detach" : true }  Since extensions, logPrefs and proxy are added to DesiredCapabilitites and not ChromeOptions separately.

column3: Allow to reuse sessions
column4: It's often necessary to reuse already running session. For instance, when you don't want to wait for browser to open. Example:  ``` @browser = Selenium::WebDriver.for :remote, url: 'http://dockerhost.dev:4444/wd/hub', session_id: '46fa1494-3b69-4dd0-bfdf-915aa28a8d71' ```

column3: Export browsers memory profilers via webdriver
column4: It would be valuable if selenium could export the memory profilers of the different browsers and possibly would try to uniform their API.  This would make possible for users to track memory allocations verifying memory leaks and other issues while doing automatic testing.  Probably what would be simple to be impleneted trting to get support in all the various browsers is to have simply an API like Node `process.memoryUsage()` that exports rss and heapUsage: https://nodejs.org/api/process.html#process_process_memoryusage  This would make possible to implement retesting on critical applications like we are trying to do in [GlobaLeaks](https://github.com/globaleaks/GlobaLeaks) and [OpenPGP.js](https://github.com/openpgpjs/openpgpjs): https://github.com/openpgpjs/openpgpjs/issues/403

Could this be documented in the wiki? https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki  This is valuable for developing tests as it would reduce startup overhead.

column3: Degradation of grid performance with release of v2.49.x and v2.50.x
column4: It appears that the Selenium Grid functionality is degrading with each release since v2.48.2.  I've been running a Selenium grid for 3+ years with no issue until release v2.49.x and up. My grid is comprised of a hub running on a Linux VM and 56 nodes running on Windows 2008 server VM's. All nodes are registered to support Firefox (v43.0.4), Chrome v48. Versions of IE8-11 are also registered but distributed evenly across the 56 nodes.  During peek utilization of the grid, I see 100% utilization of the registered nodes and upwards of 40-60+ requests in the hub queue waiting for a slot to be free.  As tests run I can see the hub queue increase/decrease and tests finish in a timely fashion.  This is what we consider normal behavior with the grid pre-v2.49.x.  Multiple teams use the grid from different geographical locations (hence the queue increase/decrease).  Since upgrading to v2.49.1 (with TIMEOUT fix, which now appears to have regressed in v2.50.0), the same grid configuration, same set of tests, etc, the grid (or test execution/webdriver?) degrades rapidly, such that tests that normally complete in 2-2.5 hours are still running after 6+ hours. We aborted the tests at this time since clearly something was amiss and our test efforts were being hindered and reverted back to v2.48.2.  I can visibly see activity on the nodes, albeit slow and sporadic  - i.e. browsers opened on nodes, sendKeys/clicks/get happening periodically, but with very lengthy delays.  It is as if there is a very lengthy pause/sleep happening between periods of webdriver requests, which normally are not present.  Please note, the tests have not changed, no sleeps were added to the tests.  When I reverted back to v2.48.2 the grid behavior goes back to what we consider normal behavior.  Same behavior with node utilization, hub queue requests, etc.  I've inspected the logs, monitored CPU/memory utilization to try and identify anything that might give me a hint as to what is causing this behavioral change in the grid (or webdriver?), but nothing seems to be out of the ordinary.  I create my hub/nodes via Java API's.  With v2.49.x there was some code refactoring with SelfRegisteringRemote (and other classes) that required me to explicitly call SelfRegisteringRemote.setRemoteServer(), as the creation of the SeleniumSever() was removed from SelfRegisteringRemote.startRemoteServer(). Without this change my nodes would not register to the hub.  Are there additional code changes that I need to make with respect to hub/node creation/registration that I'm missing?  I cannot find any documentation that might address it.  In addition, (I believe it has already been reported), the TIMEOUT issue introduced in v2.49.0 and fixed in v2.49.1 now appears to be back in v2.50.0:  org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: Session [981f8342-ae79-4424-8910-0b59f1ddb084] was terminated due to TIMEOUT  With v2.50.0 I'm now seeing sporadically this:  org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: The FirefoxDriver cannot be used after quit() was called.  Again, I have made absolutely no code changes in my Selenium grid configuration, creation of hub/nodes, except for adding a call to SelfRegisteringRemote.setRemoteServer(), or test sets being run between v2.48.2, 2.49.0, 2.49.1, and 2.50.0.  Again, if I revert back to v2.48.2 everything works just fine with the grid and test sets.  The only thing I can see that might be causing this is the refactoring work being done to decouple the RC server stuff.  I'm willing to work with whomever to try and isolate/understand this issue.

column3: verify* should show the diff
column4: It appears that if you do an assert\* it puts an error message in the log on failure, but there is nothing comparable for verify\* failures. I think there should be an 'info' level log that shows the diff.  To narrow down the issue a bit: verify\* puts a message in the log, but only if you run the whole test case (or the whole test suite). If you run a single Selenese verify\* command (by double-clicking at it) and it fails, then the command gets highlighted in pink/reddish, but it doesn't put anything in the log. However, that may not be so obvious and is confusing. So, please make it add the message to the log, so it is consistent.  That's per Selenium IDE 2.9.1, Firefox 44.0. (Originally reported at https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=1092 and starred by seven people)
