column3: InternetExplorerDriver fails to evaluate XPath predicate on attribute
column4: InternetExplorerDriver seems to ignore XPath predicates on attributes, instead matching every element with that attribute and returning the first result.  Tested using Selenium 2.47.0.0.  Steps to reproduce: Using this example HTML:  ``` html   foo bar   ```  Play back the following JUnit:  ``` java import static org.junit.Assert.*; import java.io.*; import org.junit.*; import org.openqa.selenium.*; import org.openqa.selenium.ie.*;  public class Example {     @Test     public void testPredicateOnAttribute() throws Throwable {         File file = new File("\\IEDriverServer.exe");         System.setProperty("webdriver.ie.driver", file.getAbsolutePath());         InternetExplorerDriver driver = new InternetExplorerDriver();         try {             driver.get("");             WebElement bar = driver.findElement(By.xpath("//span[contains(@class,'bar')]"));             assertEquals("bar", bar.getText());             WebElement bar2 = driver.findElement(By.xpath("//span[@class[contains(.,'bar')]]"));             assertEquals("bar", bar2.getText()); // fails because 'foo' element is returned             try {                 driver.findElement(By.xpath("//span[@class['a'='b']]"));                 fail("Should have thrown exception"); // fails because 'foo' element is returned             } catch (NoSuchElementException e) { }         } finally {             driver.quit();         }     } } ```  An equivalent test in Firefox passes as expected:  ``` java import static org.junit.Assert.*; import org.junit.*; import org.openqa.selenium.*; import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.*;  public class Example {     @Test     public void testPredicateOnAttribute() throws Throwable {         FirefoxDriver driver = new FirefoxDriver();         try {             driver.get("");             WebElement bar = driver.findElement(By.xpath("//span[contains(@class,'bar')]"));             assertEquals("bar", bar.getText());             WebElement bar2 = driver.findElement(By.xpath("//span[@class[contains(.,'bar')]]"));             assertEquals("bar", bar2.getText());             try {                 driver.findElement(By.xpath("//span[@class['a'='b']]"));                 fail("Should have thrown exception");             } catch (NoSuchElementException e) { }         } finally {             driver.quit();         }     } } ```

column3: C# implementation of RemoteWebDriver fails to install browser extensions
column4: Installing and configuring an extension works when using a local driver as described [here](https://support.saucelabs.com/customer/en/portal/articles/2200902-creating-custom-firefox-profiles-and-chrome-instances-for-your-automated-testing). Doing the same using the C# implementation of RemoteWebDriver does not. Tested this with both Firefox and Chrome.   In my test case, the remote execution was done against SauceLabs. Contacted their support and they verified that installing extensions via RemoteWebDriver works in the JAVA implementation, but fails using the C# implementation. #To quote from their support ticket:  > I was able to verify this by running a sample test to load the Modify Headers and Firebug extensions in a custom Firefox profile locally(with C#/Selenium) as well as through a C# and Java test. Both the local test which uses the Firefox Driver and the Java Sauce test using RemoteWebDriver passed and adds the extensions to the FF browse. But the C# Sauce test using RemoteWebDriver doesn’t load the profile despite using the same code as the local test.  **Setup** Tested with Selenium.WebDriver v2.48.2, v2.49.0, and v2.50.1, against Windows 7 and 10, using Firefox 43 and Chrome 47.  Here's the C# test setup for Firefox using this [extension](https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/downloads/latest/967/addon-967-latest.xpi)  ``` private static FirefoxProfile CreateFirefoxProfile() {     FirefoxProfile profile = new FirefoxProfile();     profile.AddExtension("Tools/modify_headers-0.7.1.1-fx.xpi");     profile.SetPreference("general.useragent.override", "UA-STRING");     profile.SetPreference("extensions.modify_headers.currentVersion", "0.7.1.1-signed");     profile.SetPreference("modifyheaders.headers.count", 1);     profile.SetPreference("modifyheaders.headers.action0", "Add");     profile.SetPreference("modifyheaders.headers.name0", "SampleHeader");     profile.SetPreference("modifyheaders.headers.value0", "test1234");     profile.SetPreference("modifyheaders.headers.enabled0", true);     profile.SetPreference("modifyheaders.config.active", true);     profile.SetPreference("modifyheaders.config.alwaysOn", true);     profile.SetPreference("modifyheaders.config.start", true);      return profile; }  private static IWebDriver GetRemoteDriver() {     var capabilities = new DesiredCapabilities();      var profile = CreateFirefoxProfile();      capabilities.SetCapability(FirefoxDriver.ProfileCapabilityName, profile);      capabilities.SetCapability("name", buildContext);     capabilities.SetCapability(CapabilityType.BrowserName,"firefox");     capabilities.SetCapability(CapabilityType.Version,"");     capabilities.SetCapability(CapabilityType.Platform, "Windows 10");     capabilities.SetCapability("screen-resolution", "1280x1024");     capabilities.SetCapability("username", "SaucelabsUserName");     capabilities.SetCapability("accessKey", "SaucelabsAccessKey");     capabilities.SetCapability("build", "BuildNumber");      return new RemoteWebDriver(new Uri("http://ondemand.saucelabs.com/wd/hub"), capabilities); } ```

column3: Proposal: JS driver.waitToFindElement(Condition): WebElementPromise
column4: In the interest of being able to write this line in a test:  ``` js const loadingElement = driver.wait(until.elementLocated(by.css(app.loading)), MOMENTS) ```  instead of this:  ``` js const loadingElement = new WebElementPromise(driver, driver.wait(until.elementLocated(by.css(app.loading)), MOMENTS)) ```  I wrote the following `until` monkey patch module:  ``` js import { wrap } from 'lodash'  const { until, WebDriver, WebElementPromise } = require('selenium-webdriver')  // automagically coerce element locator waits into WebElementPromise WebDriver.prototype.wait = wrap(WebDriver.prototype.wait,   function (wait, condition, ...args) {     let promise = wait.call(this, condition, ...args)     if (condition._promiseType) {       promise = new condition._promiseType(this, promise)     }     return promise   })  Object.defineProperty(until, 'elementLocated', {   value: wrap(until.elementLocated, function (locate, locator) {     return Object.assign(locate(locator), { _promiseType: WebElementPromise })   }) })  export { until } ```  Do you think it would make sense to implement this behavior natively? or is this too magic / in conflict with Closure Compiler? (I haven't used it so I'm not sure if this could be expressed properly)

column3: Authentication using RemoteWebDriver
column4: In the current WebDriver version, authentication cannot be configured using the RemoteWebDriver (see http://stackoverflow.com/questions/32365872/ntlm-authentication-in-selenium-remotewebdriver). The only way to configure it is by overriding the modifyWebClient method of the HtmlUnitDriver, which is not available when using the RemoteWebDriver.  As a result, .NET projects have no way to use Selenium if they require authentication.  I have created the following branch to solve this issue: https://github.com/RemiNV/selenium/tree/feature-webdrivercredentials  Basically, you can now configure authentication just like you configure proxies; example in .NET:  ``` var capabilities = DesiredCapabilities.HtmlUnitWithJavaScript(); var credentials = new WebDriverCredentials() {     Type = AuthType.NTLM,     Username = "username",     Password = "password",     NtlmDomain = "domain" };  capabilities.SetCapability("credentials", credentials); var driver = new RemoteWebDriver(capabilities); ```  This only works with HtmlUnit (I guess configuring the other browsers may not be that easy).  It works as I want it to, and I would like to open a pull request. However, before I spend time writing unit tests and updating the documentation, I would like to know if this is likely to be merged in the main branch, or if you see a problem with my approach/other things missing in my branch. Any thoughts ?

column3: Python: clean-up error in Chrome / IE "Service" in selenium 2.49
column4: In Selenium 2.49 the Service objects were refactored to use a common base class. This common base class now contains a "**del**" method (which is not a bad thing in itself). However if the driver was quit before this "**del**" fails.  Try to execute the following Python script:  ``` python import os from selenium import webdriver from time import sleep  def spam():     webDriver = webdriver.Chrome(chrome_options=None)     webDriver.get("http://www.google.com")     sleep(1)     webDriver.quit()  os.environ['no_proxy'] = '127.0.0.1,localhost' spam() sleep(1) ```  This results in Python 2.7:  ``` Exception urllib2.URLError: URLError(error(10061, 'No connection could be made because the target machine actively refused it'),) in  ignored ```  With selenium 2.49 this returns an URLError in the "send_remote_shutdown_command". With 2.48 this works fine.  What is happening (if I am not completely mistaken) is that webDriver.quit() already called the "stop" method in the Service class. After the "spam" method is finished garbage collection comes into effect and the "**del**" method is called which calls this method again. Of course the port is already closed and the request fails.

column3: System.InvalidOperationException in PageFactory.InitElements
column4: In my project I use C#, Selenium WebDriver with Support classes and NUnit 3.0 framework. I have many tests and these tests uses pages. I create instances of pages in SetUp section of my tests.   ```     [SetUp]     public void SetUpBaseProjectTest()     {         _projectsPage = new ProjectsPage(Driver);         _deleteDialog = new DeleteDialog(Driver);     }      [Test]     public void CreateProjectTest()     {          _projectsPage.CreateProject(); ```  Each page have a constructor where I placed initialization of page elements (PageFactory.InitElements).  ```     public class ProjectsPage     {         public WebDriver Driver { get; protected set; }          public ProjectsPage(WebDriver driver)         {             Driver = driver;             PageFactory.InitElements(Driver, this);         }  ```  When I run my tests in parallel using NUnit 3.0, I get an error:  > System.InvalidOperationException : Collection was modified; enumeration operation may not execute. >  at System.Collections.Generic.List`1.Enumerator.MoveNextRare() >  at OpenQA.Selenium.Support.PageObjects.DefaultPageObjectMemberDecorator.CreateTypeForASingleElement() >  at OpenQA.Selenium.Support.PageObjects.DefaultPageObjectMemberDecorator.get_InterfaceProxyType() >  at OpenQA.Selenium.Support.PageObjects.DefaultPageObjectMemberDecorator.CreateProxyObject(Type memberType, IElementLocator locator, IEnumerable`1 bys, Boolean cache) >  at OpenQA.Selenium.Support.PageObjects.DefaultPageObjectMemberDecorator.Decorate(MemberInfo member, IElementLocator locator) >  at OpenQA.Selenium.Support.PageObjects.PageFactory.InitElements(Object page, IElementLocator locator, IPageObjectMemberDecorator decorator)  I think the error occurs due to the parallel tests execution. It is a bug in a Selenium framework or in my test project? How to avoid this error?  Selenium Webdriver DotNet 2.47.0

column3: Make fully qualifying of href/src attributes configurable
column4: In HtmlUnitWebElement on line 371 the url always gets fully qualified. See the following code snippet.  ``` java     if ("href".equals(lowerName) || "src".equals(lowerName)) {       if (!element.hasAttribute(name)) {         return null;       }        String link = element.getAttribute(name).trim();       HtmlPage page = (HtmlPage) element.getPage();       try {         return page.getFullyQualifiedUrl(link).toString();       } catch (MalformedURLException e) {         return null;       }     } ```  I would prefer this to be configurable. Sometimes I want to explicitly test whether the attribute contains an absolute link or fully qualified url. As the link is always turned into a fully qualified url, this is not possible anymore.

column3: WebDriverWait should be able to be initialised with IWebElement
column4: In C# bindings `WebDriverWait` can be initialised only with IWebDriver, yet some of `ExpectedConditions` do not require `IWebDriver`, more over, there are cases when it is reasonable to use [`ElementExists`](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/dotnet/src/support/UI/ExpectedConditions.cs#L107) condition with searching not from `IWebDriver`, but from a particular search context.  This problem can be approached with two ways: 1. There should be a `WebDriverWait` that is initialised with `IWebElement` or even with `ISearchContext`. 2. `ElementExists` and some other relevant `ExpectedConditions` would accept `IWebElement` or `ISearchContext` as an optional parameter and would use it to search for an element, if set.  In other languages (e.g. python) one can use both webelement and webdriver for Wait (due to duck typing).  This would be especially useful when selenium bindings are used to drive non-web drivers (where css selectors are not supported).

column3: Add support for interacting with text nodes
column4: In addition to `WebElement` can a `WebText` be added? A `WebText` would be to [text](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Text) nodes what `WebElement` is to [element](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element) nodes.  Sometimes it is enough to use the element containing text but this can be problematic when an element containing text also contains elements. e.g. Without using `JavascriptExecutor` it is not possible, at least to my knowledge, to click the text `"First name: "` in `First name: ` (which, in this example, should cause the input element to get focus).  A `WebText` interface might be as follows:  ``` java public interface WebText extends TakesScreenshot {   void click();   void sendKeys(CharSequence... keysToSend);   void clear();   boolean isSelected();   String getText();   boolean isDisplayed();   Point getLocation();   Dimension getSize();   String getCssValue(String propertyName); } ```  Other potential `WebText` methods might include `select()` (to highlight/select the text) and `select(String)` (to highlight/select a substring of the text).  Additional methods to `SearchContext` such as `findTexts(By)` and `findText(By)` would also make sense.  I believe that `WebElement`'s `submit()`, `getTagName()`, `getAttribute(String)`, `isEnabled()`, `findElements(By)`, and `findElement(By)` methods would not make sense to include. A new `WebNode` interface might even be worthwhile for both `WebElement` and `WebText` to extend to declare the common methods between them.  Notes: 1. The `sendKeys(CharSequence...)` and `clear()` methods on a `WebText` would be especially useful when dealing with text nodes in [Content Editable](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/HTML/Content_Editable) elements. e.g. Double-click or otherwise select the text to highlight it and then send keys to overwrite it, etc. 2. `WebText.isSelected()` would return true if the user has highlighted/selected the text; otherwise false. 3. In addition to being able to "find" elements and text on the page and interact with them, the capability to send a text node over the JSON wire protocol in addition to element nodes would allow automation scripts using `JavascriptExecutor` to "list" or "query" for relevant text and element nodes on the page. e.g. Such a script might list all displayed nodes. On a simple login page it would return a list such as `[WebText[Email: ], WebElement[], WebText[Password: ], WebElement[], WebElement[]]`. This would allow the automation script to list text nodes, input elements, select elements, button elements, etc. and then interact with them inferring what they are based their tagName, attributes, and relative positioning in the list (e.g. the password input should be the element immediately following the text "Password: "). This would seem to get closer to automating how a user interacts with a page instead of searching within a page's DOM for elements by id, name, xpath, css selector, etc.

column3: Selenium Hover on multiple elements doesn't work in IE
column4: In  my company I have to test hover on elements in IE and FF. My code works perfectly in FF but it doesn't work in IE. Almost same site would amazon.com Step 1: Hover mouse to Element 1 (in Amazon site we can try to hover shop by department) step 2: Hover to element 2 (in amazon we can try "echo") - KEEP IN MIND in my internal site element 2 is disable till we hover to element 1.  step 3. Hover to element 3 (in amazon we can try "echo power")- KEEP IN MIND in my internal site element 3 is disable till we hover to element 2.  step 4. click on element 3  Below is my sample code for Amazon   import java.awt.Robot; import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;  import org.openqa.selenium.By; import org.openqa.selenium.WebElement; import org.openqa.selenium.ie.InternetExplorerDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.interactions.Actions; import org.openqa.selenium.remote.DesiredCapabilities;  public class Hover {     private static InternetExplorerDriver driver;  ``` public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {     System.setProperty("webdriver.ie.driver",             "C://Users//xx/IEDriverServer.exe");     DesiredCapabilities returnCapabilities = DesiredCapabilities             .internetExplorer();     returnCapabilities.setCapability(             InternetExplorerDriver.ENABLE_PERSISTENT_HOVERING, false);     driver = new InternetExplorerDriver(returnCapabilities);     Robot r = new Robot();     r.mouseMove(1, 1);     driver.get("http://www.amazon.com/");     driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(40, TimeUnit.SECONDS);     driver.manage().window().maximize();      Actions action = new Actions(driver);     WebElement dept = driver.findElement(By             .xpath(".//*[@id='nav-link-shopall']/span[2]"));     action.moveToElement(dept).perform();     WebElement mouseDevice = driver.findElement(By             .xpath(".//*[@id='nav-flyout-shopAll']/div[2]/span[8]/span"));     action.moveToElement(mouseDevice).perform();     WebElement echoall = driver             .findElement(By                     .linkText(".//*[@id='nav-flyout-shopAll']/div[3]/div[8]/div[1]/a[3]/span[1]"));     action.moveToElement(echoall).click().perform();  } ```  }

Documenting it here.

column3: Calling .click() on WebElement in Firefox causing page to not render properly
column4: If you run the code example below, Chrome and Safari will properly render the resulting page but in Firefox the page gets cut-off and not rendered properly - half the web elements are missing and the page doesn't fully load.  I have tested on the following and am able to reproduce it consistently: - Mac OS X Yosemite and Windows 7 - Firefox 40 and 41 - Selenium version 2.47.1 and 2.48.2  Notes about the test: - If run as is, the test will run on Chrome.  You will just need to comment out the ChromeDriver line and uncomment the FirefoxDriver line to switch browsers - The browser is intentionally left open at the end so you can see the issue - If you manually scroll the browser after the example code is executed, you will see the proper heading on the page and the page will be rendered properly in Chrome.  After running it in Firefox you will see the top part of the page is missing. - I intentionally resize the page to 1024x768 to show the issue since this is the resolution our Grid machines use.  We do see different behavior with different resolutions.  ``` java import org.openqa.selenium.By; import org.openqa.selenium.Dimension; import org.openqa.selenium.WebDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.WebElement; import org.openqa.selenium.chrome.ChromeDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.safari.SafariDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.support.ui.ExpectedConditions; import org.openqa.selenium.support.ui.WebDriverWait;  public class FirefoxIssue {      public static void main(String args[]) {         WebDriver webDriver = new ChromeDriver();         //WebDriver webDriver = new FirefoxDriver();         //WebDriver webDriver = new SafariDriver();          WebDriverWait webDriverWait = new WebDriverWait(webDriver, 30l);          webDriver.manage().window().setSize(new Dimension(1024, 768));          webDriver.get("https://caspa.liaisoncas.com");          webDriverWait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(By.id("cas-login-field-username")));          WebElement username = webDriver.findElement(By.id("cas-login-field-username"));         WebElement password = webDriver.findElement(By.id("cas-login-field-password"));         WebElement signin = webDriver.findElement(By.cssSelector(".cas-login-sign-in-button"));          username.sendKeys("firefoxissue");         password.sendKeys("p@ssw0rd");         signin.click();          webDriverWait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(By.cssSelector("div.cas-category-overview-container.cas-academicHistory")));          WebElement academicHistory = webDriver.findElement(By.cssSelector("div.cas-category-overview-container.cas-academicHistory"));          academicHistory.click();          webDriverWait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(By.linkText("Standardized Tests")));          WebElement standardizedTests = webDriver.findElement(By.linkText("Standardized Tests"));          standardizedTests.click();          webDriverWait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(By.cssSelector(".cas-standardizedtests li:nth-child(2) .cas-transcript-actions button")));          WebElement addMCATScore = webDriver.findElement(By.cssSelector(".cas-standardizedtests li:nth-child(2) .cas-transcript-actions button"));          addMCATScore.click();     } } ```

column3: Node client drops auth data from server url
column4: If you look at the javascript selenium-webdriver client for node, it contains an `HttpClient` that makes all of its requests to selenium. This client is configured by passing in a url that it parses, but it doesn't hold onto the auth data in the url.   https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/8b79cbdd3949c46d2bbe2322e0066965fe852b15/javascript/node/selenium-webdriver/http/index.js#L57  This means that if you want to sign into a selenium server, you have to use another method.

column3: safe_alert() fails at UI element startup in Selenium IDE
column4: If you have a UI-Element definition with test case(s) (as per https://selenium.googlecode.com/git/javascript/selenium-core/scripts/ui-doc.html > UI-Element Shorthand > testcase*), and the test case(s) fail, then Selenium IDE shows an ugly error, but not even a hint of the failed test case(s).  UI-Element calls safe_alert() twice from UIElement's test(), once from UIElement's init(), twice from UIMap's addPageset(), three times from UIMap's addElement(). The only other call is in getLocator(), which should work since that's when Selenium IDE window is already shown.  This may be caused by Firefox change in 2013 mentioned at https://forums.mozilla.org/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=14917, or related to https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=912655, or who knows....  What steps will reproduce the problem? 0. Download a file attached to https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=8428 1. Selenium IDE > Options > Options > Selenium Core extensions > select the downloaded  ui_element_with_brokent_testcase.js 2. Restart Selenium IDE 3. You get an error popup: "Cannot call openModalWindow on a hidden window".  There may be similar problems elsewhere in Selenium IDE, if it uses safe_alert() before its window is displayed.  Selenium version: 2.9.1 IDE OS: Fedora 20 Browser: Firefox 44 For streamlining, I suggest implementing together with https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/1536. (See the below original issue for call stack, but based on IDE 2.8.0) Migrated from https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=8428

column3: UI element test cases should be run even after Selenium IDE startup
column4: If you have a UI-Element definition with test case(s) (as per https://selenium.googlecode.com/git/javascript/selenium-core/scripts/ui-doc.html > UI-Element Shorthand > testcase*), and the test case(s) fail, and you re-load that Core extension, then Selenium IDE doesn't re-run the test cases().  What steps will reproduce the problem? 0. Download a file attached to https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=8429 (or Download a file attached to https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=8428) 1. Selenium IDE > Options > Options > Selenium Core extensions > select the attached ui_element_with_brokent_testcase.js 2. Restart Selenium IDE 3. The custom ui element definition is loaded, its test case is run and if it fails it's reported (side note: the error doesn't currently show up well, see https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/1535) 4. Selenium IDE > Options > Options > click at Reload button right of 'Selenium Core extensions' 5. The custom ui element definition is re-loaded, but its test case is not run (and any failures in it are not reported).  Please, modify UIMap's addElement() in chrome://selenium-ide/content/selenium-core/scripts/ui-element.js, around line 886, from  ```     // run the element's unit tests only for the IDE, and only when the     // IDE is starting. Make a rough guess as to the latter condition.     if (is_IDE() && !editor.selDebugger && !uiElement.test()) { ```  to  ```     // run the element's unit tests only for the IDE.     if (is_IDE() && !uiElement.test()) { ```  To streamline, I suggest you implement it together with https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/1535.  Selenium version: 2.9.1 OS: Fedora 20 Browser: Firefox 44  (Originally reported at https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=8429)

column3: Firefox does not list tabs in getAllWindowHandles
column4: If a test opens up a new tab (or a new tab is opened manually), it will not be listed in the return from `getAllWindowHandles` in FireFox. Chrome correctly lists all tabs.  Here's a repo showing a reproduction: https://github.com/prbaron/protractor-demo-tab  Note that FireFox will correctly return handles for new _windows_.   The spec says that window handles should be returned for each "top level browsing context." I'm not a spec expert, but I would think that a new tab would qualify.

column3: Implement IE Specific Desired Capabilities
column4: IE Bridge [fails to initialize when using an unknown parameter](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/rb/lib/selenium/webdriver/ie/bridge.rb#L49)  And most of the [IE specific capabilities](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/DesiredCapabilities#ie-specific) are not currently listed.  I'll eventually get to this, but if any lurking Windows Rubyists want something to work on before that... :)

column3: SafariDriver should implement requireWindowFocus capability similar to IE
column4: I've noticed, that Safari driver opens the browser window behind the other opened windows.   Launched this way, Safari does not have focus, which leads to certain problems in the test.   Notably, the CSS queries with ":focus" modifier does not return any element and because of that some of our tests fails.   This behaviour does not match the behaviour of other webdrivers on mac - Chrome and Firefox windows are brought by their drivers to the front. It should be an easy fix I assume, the workaround is described in this (prematurely closed) ticket: https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=4801

column3: semver compliance for node.js
column4: I've noticed that there are arguably "breaking" changes in minor and even patch releases. For example, between `2.46` and `2.48` support becomes deprecated/broken for `node@v0.12.x`: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/javascript/node/selenium-webdriver/CHANGES.md#v2480  This has probably been noted by others previously. But I'd like to know the rationale for it. Can you point me to a previously closed ticket, etc

column3: Schedule time is not working
column4: I've got problem with schedule the time when Selenium should start work. When I click on Play current test case everything works fine, but when I set up starting time at Scheduler nothing happen :/ Any idea why ?

column3: Selenium scrolls badly when trying to click on Firefox
column4: I've found that selenium scrolls badly when I try to click on a table's row and when to reach this row the browser must scroll down. When this happen, the browser scrolls one extra row past the expected one and it clicks in the wrong location.  I've found that this issue occurs after we upgraded to selenium version 2.4.80, using 2.47.3 this issue doesn't occurs, at least with firefox.  Greets, let me know if you need more info, tks

column3: Node WebDriver: Can't use Loopback option for DriverService via SeleniumServer
column4: I've been trying to run Protractor while on my company's VPN while working remotely.  Whenever the server starts, it gets my IP address of my home network (i.e. 192.168...), and attempts to use that as the address for the Selenium server.    > Selenium standalone server started at http://192.168.1.127:56359/wd/hub  As the VPN prevents local network traffic, the connection hangs and then gives a timeout error.    > Error: Timed out waiting for the WebDriver server at http://192.168.1.127:56359/wd/hub  After hours of tracking down the cause of this issue, I found the following in `/javascript/node/selenium-webdriver/remote/index.js`:  There is a `loopback` option documented (line 39): https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/javascript/node/selenium-webdriver/remote/index.js#L39  The `DriverService` seems to use this `loopback` option to determine whether or not to use a loopback address (i.e. `127.0.0.1`) (line 82): https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/javascript/node/selenium-webdriver/remote/index.js#L82  **I tested this out by changing the source to always set `loopback` to true, and my problem using Protractor with the VPN went away.**  So I went on a quest to figure out how I could get that option to be set through my Selenium / Protractor configuration.  Here's what I found:  Although `loopback` is documented, the typedef in the same comment does not include the `loopback` option (line 53): https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/javascript/node/selenium-webdriver/remote/index.js#L53  When `SeleniumServer` is initialized, it calls `DriverService`, but never passes along a `loopback` option.  Consequently, the code at line 82 setting `this.loopbackOnly_` will always resolve to `false`. (line 278, 193) https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/javascript/node/selenium-webdriver/remote/index.js#L278 https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/javascript/node/selenium-webdriver/remote/index.js#L193  I was able to capture a relevant stack trace from the `DriverService` constructor:  ```     at SeleniumServer.DriverService (~/project/node_modules/protractor/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/remote/index.js:76:32)     at new SeleniumServer (~/project/node_modules/protractor/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/remote/index.js:268:17)     at LocalDriverProvider.setupEnv (~/project/node_modules/protractor/lib/driverProviders/local.js:80:18)     at Runner.run (~/project/node_modules/protractor/lib/runner.js:254:31)     at TaskRunner.run (~/project/node_modules/protractor/lib/taskRunner.js:123:19)     at createNextTaskRunner (~/project/node_modules/protractor/lib/launcher.js:223:20)     at ~/project/node_modules/protractor/lib/launcher.js:246:7     at _fulfilled (~/project/node_modules/protractor/node_modules/q/q.js:797:54)     at self.promiseDispatch.done (~/project/node_modules/protractor/node_modules/q/q.js:826:30)     at Promise.promise.promiseDispatch (~/project/node_modules/protractor/node_modules/q/q.js:759:13) ```  Is there any way to trigger the `loopback` option in `DriverService`, or will some work be required to plumb the `loopback` option through from configuration or command-line arguments?  Environment: Mac OS X 10.10.5, Pulse Secure VPN

column3: Cannot schedule concurrent requests
column4: I'm using selenium-webdriver with a remote driver, with relatively high (seconds) latency.  One of the things our tests do is request a bunch of elements by CSS, then call getText() on each of them. Because element.getText() schedules a command in the flow, each of these commands runs in series. I think commands which do not mutate the page (findElement, getText etc) should run in parallel.

column3: DoubleClick doesn't work in SmartGWT framework
column4: I'm using Selenium WebDriver to write tests on application based on SmartGWT. It almost works, but there is a problem with doubleClick(). It works like single click (but it works on html-based applications). I'm using selenium-java 2.47.0. Sample code:  ```         WebDriver driver = new ChromeDriver();         driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(30, TimeUnit.SECONDS);         driver.get("http://www.smartclient.com/smartgwt/showcase/#grid_summaries_featured_category");         WebElement webElement = driver.findElement(By.xpath("//*[@class='cell']//*[text()='Office Application Suite']"));         Actions actions = new Actions(driver);         actions.doubleClick(webElement).perform(); ```  Expected result: a line in grid should transform to input fields (you can try to do this by hands, not Selenium). ![screenshot 002](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12131583/9222461/9a59ed9c-40fa-11e5-8858-52a1919bffdc.png)  Actual result: a line doesn't transform to input fields (it's like a single click). ![screenshot 003](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12131583/9222469/aa4e13f4-40fa-11e5-93e3-779013ea9b8d.png)

column3: Python bindings for Firefox should correct permissions for copied profile dir
column4: I'm using Selenium Python bindings with RobotFramework Selenium2Libary, which provides its own  Firefox profile directory skeleton. If I have Selenium2Library installed as a read only package, a read only profile directory from Selenium2Library gets copied and later a permission exception is raised when Selenium bindings try to add additional user.js into that directory:  ``` IOError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/var/folders/b1/mld_r9wj1jbfwf2jcfl_d61sc6kdnb/T/tmpBjsYCj/webdriver-py-profilecopy/user.js' ```  To fix the issue, I have needed to make the copy of profile dir writable after copy:  ``` --- a/py/selenium/webdriver/firefox/firefox_profile.py  2016-01-13 11:32:42.000000000 +0200 +++ b/py/selenium/webdriver/firefox/firefox_profile.py  2016-01-13 11:32:12.000000000 +0200 @@ -76,6 +76,7 @@              shutil.copytree(self.profile_dir, newprof,                              ignore=shutil.ignore_patterns("parent.lock", "lock", ".parentlock"))              self.profile_dir = newprof +            os.chmod(self.profile_dir, 0755)              self._read_existing_userjs(os.path.join(self.profile_dir, "user.js"))          self.extensionsDir = os.path.join(self.profile_dir, "extensions")          self.userPrefs = os.path.join(self.profile_dir, "user.js") ```

column3: py: phantomjs service needs to really kill the spawned process
column4: I'm using selenium on Python2 with the PhantomJS driver. I noticed phantomjs processes accumulating after running my selenium script, despite having a `driver.quit()` call. Googling led me to this fix https://code.google.com/p/selenium/source/detail?r=885b62bbb7ee in the old codebase where a SIGTERM was added to the selenium.webdriver.phantomjs.Service.stop method. However that fix is not in the GitHub codebase it seems. Was that missed in the migration to GitHub ?

column3: Connection problem and TIME_WAIT
column4: I'm using Selenium Java 2.47.1 and Firefox 39.0 on Windows.  While crawling my website, i do a lot of "findElement" and other commands with Selenium. It seems that Selenium isn't using persistent connections (perhaps it's not possible). webDriver.get("http://www.google.fr");      for (int i=0;i

column3: Can't enter fullscreen in Firefox
column4: I'm using Protractor, a framework on top of WebDriver designed to be used with Angular. In my application we use fullscreen and would like to test that you enter fullscreen when clicking a certain button. In Chrome it works, but when run in Firefox the click doesn't have any effect. If I pause before the click and manually click the button, fullscreen is entered.   Here is a minimalistic example of when it works in Chrome but not in Firefox:  ``` html                      angular.module("test", []).controller(function() {});                  Enter fullscreen              var enterFullscreen = function() {             var elem = document.querySelector("video");             if (elem.requestFullscreen) {                 elem.requestFullscreen();             } else if (elem.msRequestFullscreen) {                 elem.msRequestFullscreen();             } else if (elem.mozRequestFullScreen) {                 elem.mozRequestFullScreen();             } else if (elem.webkitRequestFullscreen) {                 elem.webkitRequestFullscreen();             }         };         ```  ``` javascript describe('fullscreen tests', function () {     it('should enter fullscreen when clicking button', function () {         browser.get(...);         element(by.buttonText('Enter fullscreen')).click();         browser.sleep(3000); // Expecting fullscreen to be entered         browser.driver.manage().window().setSize(800, 400); // Exit fullscreen     }); }); ```  In Chrome fullscreen is entered, but in Firefox the button is just active and pressed, but nothing else happens. And what causes this to only happen when WebDriver click the button but not when I do it.

column3: event or callback after returned driver from Builder.build() is opened and ready?
column4: I'm trying to time how long it takes to create the driver for several different browsers and I can't find an  event or way to pass a callback into the Builder.build() chain.  No promise is returned from build() either.  For example, from the API documentation you would think that the following would work however the third line will execute before a browser is ever opened:  ``` let start = Date.now(); let driver = new webdriver.Builder().forBrowser('chrome').build(); let elapsed_s = (Date.now() - start) / 1000.0; ```  Any suggestions?

column3: Memory leak in session creation
column4: I'm seeing an increase in memory consumption as I create and delete browser sessions. The increase is small - if I had to guess I'd say it's in the order of a few MBs per session - but large enough to mean I can't run my Selenium Grid Nodes for more than a few hours.   I took some heap dumps and one thing I noticed is that each Session instantiates a TemporaryFilesystem which registers an inner class as a shutdown hook - this means the JVM will hold on to the TemporaryFilesystem until it terminates (I think). I don't know if this is related to the memory increase I'm seeing, but it doesn't look right.  I've seen various articles about Selenium Grid clusters describing the need to periodically restart the nodes. Is this actually recommended, or is it intended that sessions are fully cleaned up on deletion?  (For the avoidance of doubt, I'm calling WebDriver.quit() each time.)

column3: Internet Explorer Driver not sending modifier keys as expected
column4: I'm running selenium 2.46.0 via [WebDriverIO](https://github.com/webdriverio/webdriverio/) on IE 11 (win7 x64), and I'm trying to test a copy/paste scenario.  I have JavaScript functions listening for the `keydown` and `keyup` events. In this case, it's for a particular element, but the issue seems to be present regardless of what element they're subscribed on.   The scenario involves sending the "Control", "c", and "v" characters, in that order, then checking to see if the operation was successful. _These are all sent in a single request, in the correct order._  The expectation is that the `KeyboardEvent` sent with "c" would have its `ctrlKey` property set to `true`, since, according to the [documentation](https://code.google.com/p/selenium/wiki/JsonWireProtocol#/session/:sessionId/keys), the modifier keys are sticky. (Moreover, a `keyup` event does not fire for the Control key until after the sequence completes.) In actuality, the `KeyboardEvent` sent with "c" (and "v") has all modifier key properties set to `false`. The `keydown` event _is_ firing in the expected order for all keys.

column3: Chromedriver stops recording logs after page load
column4:
I'm running into a weird issue where I can get logs from Chrome, but only while the page is loading. This is using the Node API. To reproduce:  ``` javascript var webdriver = require('selenium-webdriver') var chrome = require('selenium-webdriver/chrome') var webdriver_path = require('chromedriver').path  chrome.setDefaultService(new chrome.ServiceBuilder(webdriver_path).build()) var driver = new webdriver.Builder().withCapabilities(webdriver.Capabilities.chrome()).build()  require("fs").writeFileSync("index.html",   "                                  
" +   "                                           
" +   "                                           
" +   "  Timer test                      
" +   "                                          
" +   "                                           
" +   "                  
" +   "  console.error('setting up timers')             
" +   "  for (var i = 0; i < 20; i++) {                 
" +   "    (function(i){                                
" +   "      var at = Math.pow(2,i)                     
" +   "      setTimeout(function(){                     
" +   "        console.error('hello at ' + at + 'ms')   
" +   "      }, at)                                     
" +   "    })(i)                                        
" +   "  }                                              
" +   "                                        
" +   "                                          
" +   "                                          
")  driver.get("file://" + process.cwd() + "/index.html")  function get_logs (argument) {   driver.manage().logs().get("browser").then(function(logs) {     logs.forEach(function(line){       console.log(line.message)     })   }) }  setInterval(get_logs, 200) ```  To run:  ``` npm install selenium-webdriver chromedriver node test.js ```  Expected output - same as what's in the browser console, i.e.,  ``` setting up timers hello at 1ms hello at 2ms hello at 4ms hello at 8ms hello at 16ms hello at 32ms hello at 64ms hello at 128ms hello at 256ms hello at 512ms hello at 1024ms hello at 2048ms .. and so on... ```  Actual output:  ``` file:///selenium/index.html 8:11 setting up timers file:///selenium/index.html 13:17 hello at 1ms file:///selenium/index.html 13:17 hello at 2ms file:///selenium/index.html 13:17 hello at 4ms file:///selenium/index.html 13:17 hello at 8ms file:///selenium/index.html 13:17 hello at 16ms file:///selenium/index.html 13:17 hello at 32ms ```  It just stops getting logs. The `logs().get("browser")` calls succeed, but simply return an empty array.

column3: Using Mendix as PaaS -> Clicking on a action (=submit) button resets the input field.
column4: I'm not sure if this is a Mendix or Selenium bug, but this bug only occurs when executing the click command in Selenium. Manually pressing the submit button works just fine.  This only occurs with numerical input fields, Texts work just fine. The value goes back to default value right before submission. I can even see the numbers change on the form right before the popup page closes.  -- Example code --  NumberInput:  `  `  Actionbutton:  ` Opslaan `

column3: Maximise browser window on Linux has no effect
column4: I'm maximising the browser window during my tests: `myDriver.manage().window().maximize();`  This works fine on my local Windows machine, but doesn't work on our CI machine, which runs Linux.  I found an old bug report for this, which has been closed for no real reason: https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=6775  Could we please try to get this problem solved? Resizing the window to the screen's size isn't exactly the same as maximise and brings new problems.

column3: Lack of documentation for JavaScript
column4: I'm just diving into using Selenium for the first time and I'm attempting to write my tests in JavaScript and Mocha as the test runner. When searching for examples out in the wild I come across plenty of Python and Java examples but not a whole lot in JavaScript. I figured I'd go to the source and ended up on the official Selenium site but even there JavaScript seems not to be given equal treatment. Just look at the [code examples](http://docs.seleniumhq.org/docs/03_webdriver.jsp).  http://docs.seleniumhq.org/docs/03_webdriver.jsp#setting-up-a-selenium-webdriver-project  Currently I'm struggling to find the supported ways of dealing with _select_ and _option_ elements. Some Java examples show wrapping the element in a _Select_ object but I can't find any similar usage in JavaScript. Is there somewhere that I can find more complete documentation? If not, are there plans to improve the JavaScript documentation?

column3: [JAVA] Can't move in context menu through keyboard - Only in Chrome
column4: I'm facing an issue in Chrome 47, using Selenium (WebDriver) 2.48.2, ChromeDriver 2.20.353145, and last version of Java as programming language. I couldn't find any solutions online. I need to open the "right click menu of browser" (or context click menu) from an input and I could do this using this code:  new Actions(driverExample).contextClick(inputExample).build().perform();  So the next step: select an option from it. I searched online and it seemed simple, but it's not. I didn't try on others browsers, but I always saw online that many people did this in Firefox and Internet Explorer using something like:   new Actions(driverExample).contextClick(inputExample).sendKeys(Keys.ARROW_UP).sendKeys(Keys.ARROW_UP).sendKeys(Keys.RETURN).build().perform();   In this situation I put two "arrow up" and one "enter", because I have to select the second option from the bottom. Anyway, this seems to work for people in Firefox and Internet Explorer, but not on Chrome and I also saw few discussions about this problem without solution. Thanks in advance.

column3: Firefox driver can't click anything after redirect with window.location and opening popup in one click
column4: I'm creating tests for application which behaviour is reflected by attached HTML files. After clicking a button, two things happen with JS: 1. the main window is redirected to another location, 2. a popup window is opened. After 1. users can do other things in the main window.  The issue is that this is working "manually" in Firefox, but somehow Firefox driver can't click any more in the main window, because the button still seems to be pressed. Everything works fine with Chromium. The test fails with  org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: UnknownError: Cannot press more then one button or an already pressed button. I'm attaching HTML files and test cases so this can be replicated. [seleniumPopup.zip](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/97430/seleniumPopup.zip) I'm using Selenium 2.49.0, Firefox 41.0.2, Chromium 47.

column3: Support for Message Sequencing changes in Marionette protocol
column4: I was playing around with Marionette and subsequently raised a [bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1231119) which received this response:  ``` Bug 1211489 introduced message sequencing in the Marionette protocol and it appears this change is not reflected in the Selenium implementation.  Please file a bug with the Selenium project to update the Marionette protocol to support level 3.  See this thread to tools-marionette@ for further explanation: https://groups.google.com/d/msg/mozilla.tools.marionette/ZVWNINCjrTQ/hGtMg26oBgAJ ```  I have no idea what this level 3 support means, but if anyone can guide me somehow I might be able to help.

column3: Selenium 2.48.x WebDriver#switchTo().frame() does not set driver.currentUrl
column4: I upgraded to selenium 2.48.2 due to the fact that current firefox is not compatible with version 2.47.  Within my tests I have the following code:   browser.driver.switchTo().frame('gwt-debug-pdfpreview-panel') File pdf = new File(browser.getReportGroupDir(), "${filename}.pdf") pdf.bytes = downloadStream().bytes  This does not work anymore with version 2.48.x  Investigation a bit seems that the switchTo().frame() does not update the driver.currentUrl variable anymore.  Is there a workaround for this issue ?  Thanks, Detlef

column3: Please remove deprecation from Actions.pause()
column4: I understand the bad design mentioned in the deprecation note in `Actions.pause()`. It's from one perspective just as bad as using `Thread.sleep()`. So I agree that usage should be considered possibly harmful.  Nevertheless it was the only option for us to perform stable drag-and-drop in a Rich-Web-UI: - We needed to pause on the source after click-and-hold. - We needed to cycle a little on the target and then pause before actually releasing the mouse button.  Our helper code for drag-and-drop which has ripened for years now and has proven to be very stable is:  ``` java public void dragFromTo(final WebElement source, final WebElement target, final int offsetX, final int offsetY) {     bypassIEScrollIntoViewBugWorkaround(target);      final Actions actionProvider = createActions(source);     // Pausing - bad practice: Yes, pausing is bad practice but unless you know states to wait for     // there is no other chance then giving the UI some time to e. g. activate a drop-zone.     Actions startDrag = actionProvider.clickAndHold(source).pause(500);     Actions moveTo = startDrag.moveToElement(target).moveByOffset(offsetX, offsetY);     Actions waitSomeTime = moveTo.moveByOffset(1, 1).moveByOffset(-1, -1).pause(500);     Actions dropElement = waitSomeTime.release();     final Action completeAction = dropElement.build();     try {       completeAction.perform();     } catch (WebDriverException e) {       reportOnException(e, source, target);       throw e;     } } ```  The pause really was essential and fixed about 80% of our flaky drag and drop tests.  I am now about to add a SuppressWarnings to the code... but I think it would be better to just turn the warning into a normal JavaDoc.

column3: WebDriver commands differ between language bindings
column4: I tried `driver.execute('setBrowserOnline', {'state': False})` in the Python Selenium client but encountered a `KeyError`.  That command is missing in https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/55a252442ad57cd63731959b44b12a1e6977b64f/py/selenium/webdriver/remote/command.py but present in https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/55a252442ad57cd63731959b44b12a1e6977b64f/javascript/webdriver/command.js#L182 and https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/remote/DriverCommand.java#L108

column3: visibility_of_elemenet_located
column4: I think visibility_of_elemenet_located should work in a different way than now. Now it takes first found element and returns it if it is visible. I think a better idea is to return first visible element  class visibility_of_element_located(object):     def **init**(self, locator):         self.locator = locator  ``` def __call__(self, driver):     return self._first_visible_element(ec._find_elements(driver, self.locator))  def _first_visible_element(self, elements):     for e in elements:         if e.is_displayed():             return e     return False ```  And by the way:  class visibility_of_all_elements_located(object):     def **init**(self, locator):         self.locator = locator  ``` def __call__(self, driver):     return self._visible_elements(ec._find_elements(driver, self.locator))  def _visible_elements(self, elements):     return [e for e in elements if e.is_displayed()] ```

column3: Found a typo in PageFactory.java
column4: I think the word *_fniding *_below should be a typo, can you have a look and fix it?    /** - Similar to the other "initElements" methods, but takes an {@link ElementLocatorFactory} which - is used for providing the mechanism for *_fniding *_ elements. If the ElementLocatorFactory returns - null then the field won't be decorated.   * - @param factory The factory to use - @param page    The object to decorate the fields of   */   public static void initElements(ElementLocatorFactory factory, Object page) {     final ElementLocatorFactory factoryRef = factory;     initElements(new DefaultFieldDecorator(factoryRef), page);   }

column3: It's not possible to upload files with spaces in path
column4: I tested. It works in firefox. It's possible to upload a file writing the path character by character to an input type file. Including file paths containing spaces.  But in chrome It doesn't work. At least in Linux. It's not possible to upload a file which path name contains spaces.

column3: elementeScrollBehavior does not work with actions
column4: I successfully tested the elementScrollBehavior capability and it works, but only if you don't use Actions!  webElement.click(); >>> scrolls to bottom if it is set to 1 new Actions(driver).click(webElement).build().perform(); >>> scrolls always to the top  If you try this code you will see that it will always scroll to the top if you use actions:  ``` DesiredCapabilities desiredCapabilities = new DesiredCapabilities(); desiredCapabilities.setCapability(CapabilityType.ELEMENT_SCROLL_BEHAVIOR, 1); FirefoxDriver driver = new FirefoxDriver(desiredCapabilities); WebElement webElement = driver.findElement(By.cssSelector("div.selenium-sponsors a"));  // always scrolls to the top new Actions(driver).click(webElement).build().perform();  // scrolls to the bottom //webElement.click(); ```

column3: "Not clickable" error message is not JSON when ErrorHandler.check_response expects JSON
column4: I saw an error like this one:  ```   File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webelement.py", line 75, in click      self._execute(Command.CLICK_ELEMENT)    File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webelement.py", line 454, in _execute      return self._parent.execute(command, params)    File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 201, in execute      self.error_handler.check_response(response)    File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/errorhandler.py", line 102, in check_response      value = json.loads(value_json)    File "/opt/python/3.5.0/lib/python3.5/json/__init__.py", line 319, in loads      return _default_decoder.decode(s)    File "/opt/python/3.5.0/lib/python3.5/json/decoder.py", line 339, in decode      obj, end = self.raw_decode(s, idx=_w(s, 0).end())    File "/opt/python/3.5.0/lib/python3.5/json/decoder.py", line 357, in raw_decode      raise JSONDecodeError("Expecting value", s, err.value) from None  json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0) ```  I did some digging and it looks like [this line](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/30a541659e3e72c64f159f3da8cb06ff28e5a362/py/selenium/webdriver/remote/errorhandler.py#L102) is choking because the value of `value_json` was:  ``` 'Element is not clickable at point (156, 457.79998779296875). Other element would receive the click: ' ```

column3: Mono and x64 Firefox exception: 'Could not locate amd64'
column4: I ran into a problem on mono 3.12.1, centos 6.6 (x64) with firefox 38, but I suppose that the problem is global for Firefox x64:    OpenQA.Selenium.WebDriverException : Could not locate amd64: native events will not work.   at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxBinary.ExtractAndCheck (OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxProfile profile, System.String noFocusSoName, System.String libraryPath32Bit, System.String libraryPath64Bit) [0x00000] in :0   at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxBinary.ModifyLinkLibraryPath (OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxProfile profile) [0x00000] in :0   at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxBinary.StartProfile (OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxProfile profile, System.String[] commandLineArguments) [0x00000] in :0   at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxDriverServer.Start () [0x00000] in :0   at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxDriverCommandExecutor.Execute (OpenQA.Selenium.Remote.Command commandToExecute) [0x00000] in :0   at OpenQA.Selenium.Remote.RemoteWebDriver.Execute (System.String driverCommandToExecute, System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary`2 parameters) [0x00000] in :0   at OpenQA.Selenium.Remote.RemoteWebDriver.StartSession (ICapabilities desiredCapabilities) [0x00000] in :0   at OpenQA.Selenium.Remote.RemoteWebDriver..ctor (ICommandExecutor commandExecutor, ICapabilities desiredCapabilities) [0x00000] in :0   at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxDriver..ctor (OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxBinary binary, OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxProfile profile, ICapabilities capabilities, TimeSpan commandTimeout) [0x00000] in :0   at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxDriver..ctor (OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxBinary binary, OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxProfile profile, TimeSpan commandTimeout) [0x00000] in :0    After some investigations in source code of firefox driver I detected potential bug: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/dotnet/src/webdriver/Firefox/FirefoxBinary.cs#L346  ``` c# private void ModifyLinkLibraryPath(FirefoxProfile profile)         {             // Extract x_ignore_nofocus.so from x86, amd64 directories inside             // the jar into a real place in the filesystem and change LD_LIBRARY_PATH             // to reflect that.             string existingLdLibPath = Environment.GetEnvironmentVariable("LD_LIBRARY_PATH");              // The returned new ld lib path is terminated with ':'             string newLdLibPath = ExtractAndCheck(profile, NoFocusLibraryName, "x86", "amd64");             if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(existingLdLibPath))             {                 newLdLibPath += existingLdLibPath;             }              this.SetEnvironmentProperty("LD_LIBRARY_PATH", newLdLibPath);              // Set LD_PRELOAD to x_ignore_nofocus.so - this will be taken automagically             // from the LD_LIBRARY_PATH             this.SetEnvironmentProperty("LD_PRELOAD", NoFocusLibraryName);         } ```  Previous method is trying to extract '**x_ignore_nofocus.so**' file from **WebDriver.FirefoxNoFocus.x86.dll** and **WebDriver.FirefoxNoFocus.amd64.dll**.  But according [build.desc](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/dotnet/src/webdriver/build.desc#L17) there is no file**WebDriver.FirefoxNoFocus.amd64.dll**, but only **WebDriver.FirefoxNoFocus.x64.dll**. So '**x_ignore_nofocus.so**' file for x64 Firefox cannot be extracted and driver [throw exception](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/dotnet/src/webdriver/Firefox/FirefoxBinary.cs#L328)  I could not build the project from sources, so I just changed "amd64" to "x64"  at [this line](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/dotnet/src/webdriver/Firefox/FirefoxBinary.cs#L346)  ``` c# string newLdLibPath = ExtractAndCheck(profile, NoFocusLibraryName, "x86", "amd64"); ```  through ILSpy in WebDriver.dll, and after that my test worked fine on CentOS.

column3: Cannot disable a command from the Selenium IDE GUI

column3: Add Some Useful Helper Functions
column4: I often find that my elements aren't visible immediately due to JS latency. Therefore I I have written a click method like this:  ``` public void click(By locator) {   new WebDriverWait(driver, 15).until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(locator));   driver.findElement(locator).click(); } ```  I then found myself repeating a lot of XPaths to find buttons and click them so I wrote a helper for that too:  ``` public void clickButton(String buttonText) {   click(By.xpath("//button[contains(.,'" + buttonText + "')]")); } ```  Helper methods like this would be useful in the framework to remove a lot of boilerplate from the test code and make the tests a lot more readable.

Does Selenium offer an API to store in the browser this information?  Or is the only way to do it  manually (logging 2 times to let the first time store the pair ).

column3: getText on a select element should return the text of the first selected option
column4:
I need to retrieve the text from a select element, like as follows:  ```                                 item1             item2             item3                      ```  I'd expect getText on `#items` (as well as on `form`) to return what's _visible_ on the UI, aka the first selected option, aka "item1" in the example. Instead, I'm getting a string with all of the options  ``` WebElement selectElement = driver.findElement(By.id("items")); String firstSelectedOptionText = new Select(selectElement).getFirstSelectedOption().getText(); assertEquals(selectElement.getText(), firstSelectedOptionText); ```  is failing with   ```  java.lang.AssertionError: Expected : item1 Actual : item1
 item2
 item3
 ```  Is this expected?  Selenium v2.47.1 ChromeDriver 2.20.353145 Firefox 41.0.2  Thanks

column3: keyDown() does not work with Internet Explorer Driver
column4: I have tried to do it in different ways, but what works on Chrome (version 46.0.2490.86 m) and Firefox (version 42.0) won't work with IE 9. Neither  ``` javascript browser.actions()             .sendKeys(protractor.Key.chord(protractor.Key.CONTROL, '1'))             .perform() ```  nor  ``` javascript browser.actions()             .keyDown(protractor.Key.CONTROL)             .sendKeys('1')             .keyUp(protractor.Key.CONTROL)             .perform(); ```  work. I use protractor to send my tests to the selenium standalone server (which is on a VM which runs win7). Please tell me in case I overlooked something or if there is a workaround for this issue.  Full test:  ``` javascript describe('keyDown', function () {     browser.ignoreSynchronization = true;     browser.get('http://ci.seleniumhq.org:2310/common/keyboard_shortcut.html');      it('should work with IE9', function () {         browser.actions()             .sendKeys(protractor.Key.chord(protractor.Key.CONTROL, '1'))             .perform()          expect(element(by.tagName('body')).getAttribute('style')).toContain('background: red');     }); }); ```  Thank you in advance, Miro

column3: Selenium on Edge doesn't invoke onchange() when calling SelectElement.SelectByValue()
column4: I have the following HTML:  ```              Français             English          Chinese       ```  In my Selenium C# test case, I do:  ``` [FindsBy(How = How.XPath, Using = "//select[not(option[1][@value='-1'])]")] protected IWebElement ComboBoxLanguageInternal { get; set; } protected SelectElement ComboBoxLanguage => new SelectElement(ComboBoxLanguageInternal);  this.SelectLanguage("en");  public void SelectLanguage(string locale) {     ComboBoxLanguage.SelectByValue("?locale=" + locale); } ```  This works for all browsers and platforms. The language select element is switched from "Français" to "English" and the JavaScript function redirect() is executed. The only exception is MS Edge on Win10 Desktop: Here, the value is also switched to "English" but the JavaScript onchange event is not invoked.

column3: Selenium Python 2.47.0 fails to close Python on Windows
column4: I have Firefox 39.0 on Windows 7. Running the following script:  ``` from selenium.webdriver.firefox.webdriver import WebDriver as Firefox  if __name__ == '__main__':     ff = Firefox()     ff.quit() ```  results in the following error being printed on `stdout`:  ``` [Error 32] The process cannot access the file because it is being used by another process: 'c:\\users\\michael\\appdata\\local\\temp\\tmpqovo2w\\cert8.db' ```  The browser does close successfully. However, the temporary directory mentioned in the error message is not cleaned up.  Debugging into Firefox' WebDriver#quit:  ``` def quit(self):     """Quits the driver and close every associated window."""     try:         RemoteWebDriver.quit(self)     except (http_client.BadStatusLine, socket.error):         # Happens if Firefox shutsdown before we've read the response from         # the socket.         pass     if "marionette" in self.capabilities and self.capabilities['marionette'] is True:         self.service.stop()     else:         try:             shutil.rmtree(self.profile.path)             if self.profile.tempfolder is not None:                 shutil.rmtree(self.profile.tempfolder)         except Exception as e:             print(str(e)) ```  It appears that `RemoteWebDriver.quit(self)` doesn't "wait" long enough for the browser to close fully. Setting a breakpoint on that line and waiting for a couple of seconds before continuing on to the next line makes the problem disappear.

column3: [Question] What protocol do browsers use to accept automation requests?
column4: I have a question and potential doc issue.  If I understand correctly, specific implementations of the [WebDriver API](http://www.w3.org/TR/webdriver/), such as the standalone [ChromeDriver](https://code.google.com/p/selenium/wiki/ChromeDriver) or [InternetExplorer Driver](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/InternetExplorerDriver) executables or the [FireFoxDriver](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/FirefoxDriver) extension, take commands sent over the [JSON Wire Protocol](https://code.google.com/p/selenium/wiki/JsonWireProtocol).  My questions is two-fold: 1. What protocol do the WebDriver implementations use to talk to the browser? 2. Why don't browsers implement the JSON Wire Protocol directly? It seems that the WebDriver bit must implement both JSON Wire and whatever protocol it uses to     talk to that browser, and then the browser must implement that protocol as well. This seems like a considerable duplication of effort.  The argument that browser size should be minimized seems relatively weak, since browsers have to implement the latter protocol anyway.  The [JsonWireProtocol docs](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/JsonWireProtocol#server) claim that  > [the term "server"] may also refer to a **specific browser that implements the wire protocol directly**, such as the [FirefoxDriver](https://code.google.com/p/selenium/wiki/FirefoxDriver) or IPhoneDriver  That doesn't make sense - FirefoxDriver isn't a browser. As far as I can tell, it's an XPI extension for Firefox. This would be the potential documentation issue.

column3: Bug in 2.48.0 getting value of a data attribute when it contains a DateTime in ISO8601 format
column4: I found a bug that only happens when using version 2.48.0 of the Selenium Webdriver and Support nuget packages (for C#). I am using the latest chrome driver 2.19.  I have an element in my page that looks like so:  ```      2015/09/10 13:23  ```  I have a test that grabs the value of the data-utc attribute.  ``` [FindsBy(How = How.CssSelector, Using = "#comments time")] private IWebElement commentTimestamp;  public static string GetTimeValueUtc()  {     return commentTimestamp.GetAttribute("data-utc"); } ```  In version 2.47.0 this function returns the string "2015-09-10T19:23:37.3631878Z" as expected.  But in version 2.48.0 this function returns the string "9/10/2015 7:23:37 PM".  To make sure it wasn't my code, I reverted back to 2.47.0 and verified that was the only difference that causes this inconsistency.  Perhaps there's some kind of weird casting going in the lastest version? I know .NET looooooves casting anything resembling a DateTime without being asked.

column3: Cannot start clean session, nor delete cookies on Safari
column4: I am using the latest version of selenium driver 2.48 with ruby 2.2.3.  I have been trying to force Safari to run with `ensureCleanSession` but it ignores it. `delete_all_cookies` does not work as well. I also tried deleting  `Cookies.banarycookies` but Safari still loads with cookies present.

column3: Slow/incomplete page load in the browser launched by selenium
column4: I am using selenium WebDriver using RobotFramework. The major problem we are facing is, my tests are timing out even after setting timeout as high as 10 minutes. It happen with any browser I use. These thing works much faster If I run test manually (with all browser cache/data/cookie cleared). These are the other things I have observing for few months. - Some component are never loaded (I check the call trace using BrowserMob Proxy and we found nothing unusual) -  "Click Element" does not work in many cases. Clicking on element triggers some action but that action is not always trigerred in automation. Manually it works all the time.   Notes:  - This is happening on FF and Chrome. (IE is not working for me at all) - App server and automation suite is in LAN so latency is not an issue - No other heavy process is running at this time - This is not an application issue as we spent 2 month confirming that.  - Issue persist even if with firefox default profile  - I tried it with different selenium versions. (2.45 - 2.52) - I took latest driver for chrome. Broweser: FF 40+ and GC 48  Let me know if you need any other detail.

column3: Click command not working
column4: I am using selenium webdriver and testng for data driven testing along with java. One method is parameterized to be invoked mutliple times using dataprovider annotation. During the test execution on firefox and after 50 iterations, a selenium command (for example a click on a button) is called but didn't work correctly to fire the click event in the application, and no error is generated. Any idea on what can be the cause behind it.

column3: Webdriver with extended ASCII characters
column4: I am using Selenium stand-alone Build Info 2.48.2 on Linux. I am using Caius's webdriver for TCL to interface with selenium's API. I am trying to use the method "partial link text" with the selector "Français"   I used wireshark to capture the interaction between TCL and the Selenium. It looks like TCL is sending the correct data I can see "Français" being represented by hex 22 46 72 61 6e e7 61 69 73 22 in the POST packet But the returned HTTP 500 is showing incorrect data for "Français" , I see  hex 22 46 72 61 6e ef bf bd 61 69 73 5c 22"  So at some point it looks like Selenium is not working correctly, with extended ASCII as ç (e7) is represented by   ∩ ┐ ╜ (ef bf bd) in the return message

column3: Edge browser throws not implemented exception with special character in Selenium Grid
column4: I am using Selenium Gird, version 2.48.2. When I execute the test, I get a strange error message, like:  > org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: ၐݳ▘ӳtor not implemented (WARNING: The server did not provide any stacktrace information)  or  > org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: ၐ݈▘tor not implemented (WARNING: The server did not provide any stacktrace information)  The error is here: `WebElement loginBtn = webDriver.findElement(By.xpath("//button[contains(., 'Einloggen')]"));`  I don't know what's wrong with that.  I register the node like this:  `java -Dwebdriver.edge.driver=C:\Selenium\MicrosoftWebDriver.exe -jar selenium-server-standalone-2.48.2.jar -role node -browser browserName=MicrosoftEdge,platform=WINDOWS -hub http://10.0.50.34:4444/grid/register/ -trustAllSSLCertificates`  and in my java code:  `capabilities = DesiredCapabilities.edge();` `webDriver = new RemoteWebDriver(new URL("http://10.0.50.34:4444/wd/hub"), capabilities);`  Is there something wrong with EdgeDriver?

column3: Safari does not start a clean session in grid
column4: I am using safari options "setUseCleanSession(true)", but this is not starting clean session when i am using safari with remote webdriver.

column3: Cookies use 'None' for session cookies and for permanent cookies
column4: I am using python bindings for selenium webdriver.  The cookie dict uses None for the 'expiry' field for both session cookies and for permanent cookies.

column3: WebDriverWait not firing timeout exception
column4: I am using Python 3.4 on ubuntu 14.04.3 LTS and Python 3.5 on windows 10. In my script, I am using webdriver.Firefox(). WebDriverWait() function does not fire timeout. When there is a problem o a web page loading, it waits forever. In order to overcome that issue I am using socket timeout with the function RemoteConnection.set_timeout(180) My script is at   https://github.com/ahmetax/avare/blob/master/avare_50.py Ahmet Aksoy

column3: How to turn on responsive design view.
column4:
I am using java selenium driver and I want to turn on automatically the responsive design view with specific resolution at firefox start. Is it possible? I tried to set.  ``` String responsiveMode = "{"+""key":"800x600",
"+""name":"POS Terminal",
"+""width":800,
"+""height": 600"+"}"; FirefoxProfile profile = new FirefoxProfile(); profile.setPreference("devtools.responsiveUI.presets", responsiveMode); ```  But that did not work. Any recommendation?

column3: How to open new window (OpenWindow command) in iphone devices using selenium webdriver
column4: I am unable to open new window in devices using below code which is working as expected in FF, CH and IE browsers. I am using below javacsript code to open new window: ((JavascriptExecutor)driver).executeScript("window.open("http://www.gmail.com");"); ## Expected Behavior -  With the above code it has to open a new window with the given url. ## Actual Behavior -  New window is not opening with above code and it is not throwing any error. ## Steps to reproduce -  Step 1: Open a window using below code:    driver.get("http:www.google.com"); Step 2: Do some operations on opened window Step 3: Try to open another window using below code:   ((JavascriptExecutor)driver).executeScript("window.open("http://www.gmail.com");"); Step 4: switch focus to newly opened window  But i was unable to open new window in devices with below mentioned capabilities:  DesiredCapabilities caps = DesiredCapabilities.iphone();             caps.setCapability("platform", "OS X 10.10");             caps.setCapability("version", "9.0");             caps.setCapability("deviceName","iPhone Simulator");             caps.setCapability("deviceOrientation", "portrait"); I am using selenium version 2.48.2  Please provide any solution.

column3: Htmlunitdriver conflicting with Rest Assured API
column4: I am trying to use Htmlunitdriver but it looks like it is conflicting with Rest Assured API.  If i remove rest assured library from the pom.xml, the below code works fine HtmlUnitDriver driver = new HtmlUnitDriver();  If i add rest assured library to the pom.xml, an exception is thrown as below:  ``` Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/http/cookie/CookieSpecProvider at com.gargoylesoftware.htmlunit.WebClient.createWebConnection(WebClient.java:1907) at com.gargoylesoftware.htmlunit.WebClient.(WebClient.java:134) at org.openqa.selenium.htmlunit.HtmlUnitDriver.newWebClient(HtmlUnitDriver.java:303) at org.openqa.selenium.htmlunit.HtmlUnitDriver.createWebClient(HtmlUnitDriver.java:277) at org.openqa.selenium.htmlunit.HtmlUnitDriver.(HtmlUnitDriver.java:148) at dfbhdfbhdfbh.htmlunittest.main(htmlunittest.java:15) Caused by: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.apache.http.cookie.CookieSpecProvider at java.net.URLClassLoader$1.run(Unknown Source) at java.net.URLClassLoader$1.run(Unknown Source) at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(Native Method) at java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass(Unknown Source) at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(Unknown Source) at sun.misc.Launcher$AppClassLoader.loadClass(Unknown Source) at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(Unknown Source) ... 6 more ```  Below is the list of dependencies  ```               org.testng         testng         6.8.1                                   com.jayway.restassured         rest-assured         2.3.1                                   org.seleniumhq.selenium         selenium-server         2.45.0                                       commons-codec                 commons-codec                                 org.seleniumhq.selenium     selenium-java     2.45.0     ```  Not sure how to get around with this.  I tried to use different Selenium version (2.24.1) and it resolved the exception. But it is giving me problems with the webpage i am trying to access.

column3: CodeMirror: Element is not currently visible and so may not be interacted with
column4: I am trying to drive the CodeMirror widget but it proves impossibile to enter any text into it because of the error "Element is not currently visible and so may not be interacted with".  CodeMirror is a javascript library to edit code in a browser window.  It makes quite an odd use of a textarea to allow the text to be input. The textarea is always available for input but the fxDriver extension isShown method doesn't think so. I think that method implements a strategy to figure out if the element is editable, but that strategy fails in this case.  Try the following test with webdriver, it reproduces the error.  Thanks, Carlo.         code-mirror     code-mirror       open     https://codemirror.net/            type     css=div > textarea     something

column3: CodeMirror: Element is not currently visible and so may not be interacted with
column4: I am trying to drive the CodeMirror widget but it proves impossibile to enter any text into it because of the error "Element is not currently visible and so may not be interacted with".  CodeMirror is a javascript library to edit code in a browser window.  It makes quite an odd use of a textarea to allow the text to be input. The textarea is always available for input but the fxDriver extension isShown method doesn't think so. I think that method implements a strategy to figure out if the element is editable, but that strategy fails in this case.

column3: Selenium WebDirver Firefox document.readyState always return complete when pageLoadStrategy as none
column4: I am trying to automate a web application in Firefox to check the page rendering and network time of the application. I don't want to use any timeout function since it affect the purpose of my test so i decided to use document.readyState property for page navigation also for measuring the page rendering and network time (PR/Ntwk) i ll be waiting till the readyState gets complete. So i ll be measuring the PR/Ntwk time using stopwatch from the readyState loading to Complete.  When i am using default pageLoadStrategy for Firefox the readyState property is working as expected but when i am changed the pageLoadStrategy to none for some application which has signalR request (longpolling) the readyState property always returning the state as "complete" even when the page is still loading.  Can any one help me regarding this issue or any other solution would be helpful?  Firefox version : V43.0.2 Selenium Webdriver version : V2.48.2
