column3: HtmlUnitWebElement class getText method does not work
column4: getText returns empty string for HTML tags like title since 2.46.0 version of selenium-java  It is because of upgrade HTMLUnit now you should use: this.element.asXml() method if you want parse entire HTML or just use asText() method and do not handle HTML parsing on your side.

column3: [python] `tempdir` is not cleaned up after test run
column4: From [firefox_profile.py](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/py/selenium/webdriver/firefox/firefox_profile.py):  ``` class FirefoxProfile(object):     ANONYMOUS_PROFILE_NAME = "WEBDRIVER_ANONYMOUS_PROFILE"     DEFAULT_PREFERENCES = None      def __init__(self, profile_directory=None):         """         Initialises a new instance of a Firefox Profile         :args:          - profile_directory: Directory of profile that you want to use.            This defaults to None and will create a new            directory when object is created.         """         if not FirefoxProfile.DEFAULT_PREFERENCES:             with open(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__),                                    WEBDRIVER_PREFERENCES)) as default_prefs:                 FirefoxProfile.DEFAULT_PREFERENCES = json.load(default_prefs)          self.default_preferences = copy.deepcopy(             FirefoxProfile.DEFAULT_PREFERENCES['mutable'])         self.native_events_enabled = True         self.profile_dir = profile_directory         self.tempfolder = None         if self.profile_dir is None:             self.profile_dir = self._create_tempfolder()         else:             self.tempfolder = tempfile.mkdtemp()             newprof = os.path.join(self.tempfolder, "webdriver-py-profilecopy")             shutil.copytree(self.profile_dir, newprof,                             ignore=shutil.ignore_patterns("parent.lock", "lock", ".parentlock"))             self.profile_dir = newprof             self._read_existing_userjs(os.path.join(self.profile_dir, "user.js"))         self.extensionsDir = os.path.join(self.profile_dir, "extensions")         self.userPrefs = os.path.join(self.profile_dir, "user.js")  ```  `self.profile_dir` isn't cleaned up after usage. This causes several ~36MB files containing webdriver-py-profilecopy in `tempdir`. Eventually experienced low disk issue, since our tests run multiple times a day.

column3: Switching Between frame And iframe
column4: frame name="top"        frame name="middle"              frame name="middleframe"                frame name="listframe"     I am Unable to navigate from frame "middle" to iframe "middleframe" and the iframe "listframe" fetching all likns from here and navigating back to iframe "middleframe".

column3: Switching Windows using Edge and Remote
column4: For switching windows, [JSON Wire Protocol](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/JsonWireProtocol#sessionsessionidwindow) requires a 'name' parameter, but [w3c protocol](http://www.w3.org/TR/webdriver/#switch-to-window) requires a 'handle' parameter.   The Ruby bindings are using 'handle' for Microsoft Edge and it works when running locally, but the Remote WebDriver is only accepting 'name.'  I can add another conditional to the Ruby code, but I think the server should be accepting 'handle' here.

column3: Restarting Marionette session with Remote WebDriver
column4: For some reason the Remote WebDriver implementation for Marionette isn't letting me start a new session after ending a previous one.  I can verify the wires binary is started. It seems like I might be getting the error before the binary loads, but I can't tell for sure.  This code does work when I run directly through the Ruby code.  ``` -> DELETE session/01f3b40f-f5ba-4673-b45e-4ad847ef52b2  POST session    >>> http://127.0.0.1:4444/wd/hub/session | {"desiredCapabilities":{"browserName":"firefox","browserVersion":"any","platformName":"any","platformVersion":"any","acceptSslCerts":false,"takesScreenshot":false,"takesElementScreenshot":false,"pageLoadStrategy":"normal","marionette":true}}      > {"Accept"=>"application/json", "Content-Type"=>"application/json; charset=utf-8", "Content-Length"=>"241"}

column3: 2.48.x: WebDriver#getCurrentUrl doesn't change when switching to another frame
column4: For Selenium version 2.47.x (and before), switching to another frame (using webDriver.switchTo().frame(String)) has caused webDriver#getCurrentUrl() to be changed correctly the the frame's URL. Since 2.48.x this does not happen any longer. Instead the parent frame's URL is returned.   As a result it is no longer possible to determine the URL of a page that is currently displayed in an iframe.

column3: The API webdriver.getPageSource() doesn't return HTML tags for plain text file
column4: For Selenium v2.48.2 in conjunction with Firefox browser only, calling the API webdriver.getPageSource() doesn't return any HTML tags.  I've confirmed this is only happening with Firefox (v40.0.2, v41.0, v41.0.2, v42.0), and it is NOT happening when tested using Selenium v2.47.0.   There is also no issue with ChromeDriver v2.20 w/Chrome browser or IEDriverServer v2.48.0 w/IE browsers.  I believe this is a subtle/edge case because I'm only seeing this with plain text files, specifically a HOSTINFO.txt file. I do get HTML tags when I hit www.google.com (but do I get them all?).  Code snippet being run -  ```     webdriver.get("file:////HOSTINFO.txt");     String source = webdriver.getPageSource(); ```  where HOSTINFO.txt contains -  ```     "Installed on prod-c4-agrippa-3d927b8d at Mon Nov 02 17:26:36 UTC 2015     AppVersion: 20.9.0-1     DeployTag: agrippa-ops-1.954     Candidate: false" ```  when I inspect the page using Firefox->Tools->Inspector or Firebug I see basic html/body/pre tags -  Installed on prod-c4-agrippa-3d927b8d at Mon Nov 02 17:26:36 UTC 2015 AppVersion: 20.9.0-1 DeployTag: agrippa-ops-1.954 Candidate: false   In the console of Inspector, I get the following error (but not in the console of Firebug) -  "The character encoding of the plain text document was not declared. The document will render with garbled text in some browser configurations if the document contains characters from outside the US-ASCII range. The character encoding of the file needs to be declared in the transfer protocol or file needs to use a byte order mark as an encoding signature."  This leads me to suspect that there has been a very subtle change that is causing this to happen.

column3: Selenium 2.48.0 and 2.49.0 with FireFox failing
column4: For our testing we have been using RobotFramework-selenium2library we were on selenium 2.47.3 and FireFox 42.0 with all working normally FireFox released 43.0 so we upgraded our selenium to 2.48.0 to work with it and started noticing failures in our tests. Today I worked with different combinations and narrowed it down to anything newer than Selenium 2.47.3 and FireFox 42.0  Here is our testcases showing the problems:  Open Applications Window     [Documentation]    This test suite opens the Applications window.     [Tags]    GUI    smoke     Comment    Logging into the DE     DE GUI Login     Comment    Opening the Apps window.     DE GUI Open Apps Window     Page Should Contain Element    //div[text() = 'Apps']  Open CACE     [Documentation]    This test case opens CACE.     [Tags]    GUI    smoke     Comment    Variables to run my key words.     Set Suite Variable    ${Analysis}    CACE     Set Suite Variable    ${Category}    Comparative Methods     Comment    Open CACE.     DE GUI Select Analysis    ${Analysis}    ${Category}     Wait Until Page Contains Element    xpath=//div[text()='Analysis Name:CACE_analysis1']    ${GUIWaitShort}  The first testcase passes without issue, but on the newer FF and Selenium, the second testcase always fails right at the DE GUI Select Analysis keyword.  Here is the contents of that keyword: DE GUI Select Analysis     [Arguments]    ${Analysis}    ${Category}     [Documentation]    Combines steps for selecting an analysis by first clicking the Public Apps category, then selecting the subcategory specified in the test case, and then selecting the application specified in the test case.     ...     ...    Allows the user to select an analysis without having to go through all the little CSS annoyances.     Comment    Wait for the category to appear.     Wait Until Page Contains Element    xpath=//span[contains(text(), "${Category}")]    ${GUIWaitShort}     Click Element    xpath=//span[contains(text(), "${Category}")]     Wait Until Page Contains Element    xpath=//span[text()="${Analysis}"]    ${GUIWaitShort}     Comment    Select the App row.     Click Element    xpath=//span[text()="${Analysis}"]/../../../td[3]     Comment    Open the Apps window Apps dropdown (to expose the Use App button).     Click Element    //div[@id='gwt-debug-appsWindow.appsView.menuBar.apps']/div/table/tbody/tr[2]/td[2]/div/div/table/tbody/tr/td/div     Wait Until Page Contains Element    //div[@id='gwt-debug-appsWindow.appsView.menuBar.apps.useApp']/span    ${GUIWaitShort}     Comment    Click the Use App button.    This has proven more stable than clicking the link text to open the app.     Click Element    //div[@id='gwt-debug-appsWindow.appsView.menuBar.apps.useApp']/span     Wait Until Page Contains Element    xpath=//div[text()="Launch Analysis"]    ${GUIWaitShort}     Comment    Close the Apps window.     Click Element    css=div[id="gwt-debug-appsWindow.close"]     Page Should Not Contain Element    xpath=//div[@id='gwt-debug-desktop.deTaskBar']/div/div/div/table/tbody/tr/td/div/div/table/tbody/tr/td/div[text()="Apps"]  Unfortunately we do not use Selenium directly.

column3: selenium is not stable for firefox 38.1 on CentOS with headless
column4: For now, we just use selenium to run auto UI test on CentOS6 in ruby. And we just upgrade the firefox to 38.1. Then we run the UI test, it always failed because of different reasons, such as, 1.unable to obtain a stable firefox connection in 60 seconds. 2.Element is not currently visible and so may not be interacted with  By seeing the changelog of selenium ruby, it said selenium supports firefox 38 on 2.46.2. I have run UI test 20 times with 2.46.2 and only success once. But our test can successfully run on firefox 31 with selenium 2.41.0 and headless 0.3.1.  I just wonder how could I run test successfully on firefox 38.1 stably.

column3: When searching the Firefox binary on Linux, ignore directories
column4: For Linux, `findFirefox` (in firefox/binary.js) calls `io.findInPath('firefox')`. If you have a directory called _firefox_ in your path, this is going to return it.  You could add some options to `findInPath` to only search for files that have particular attributes. E.g. normal files (non-directories), executable, etc..

column3: [feature request] isEditable for elements
column4: For example DOM elements with the attribute contenteditable it would be nice to have a function to check whether or not the element is editable, that is: you can send keys to the element and they will be written out.

column3: changing default node id behavior to match ProxyStatusServlet
column4: Fixes an issue where if remoteHost has a trailing slash the node will constantly re-register itself because the status servlet strips slashes and registration does not. This caused much frustration trying to setup a docker based grid on multiple hosts.   --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/seleniumhq/selenium/1252)

column3: Added Firefox path variable for string placeholder
column4: Fixes #1424  Signed-off-by: Abhijeet Kasurde akasurde@redhat.com

column3: Update Contributing.MD Fixed Typo
column4: Fixed simple typo to make more sense.  I have signed the CLA!  Thanks for your time.

column3: Fix type warning
column4: Fix type warning revealed by improved array-like object type checking in the Closure Compiler.

column3: sendKeys() on input [type=file] works on Firefox but not on Chrome
column4: firefox: 43.0.4 chrome: 47.0 chromedriver: 2.20 selenium-server: 2.48.2  ``` javascript browser.executeScript('document.querySelector(\'input[type=file]\').style.display="inline";'); var inputElement = element(by.css('input[type="file"]')); inputElement.clear(); inputElement.sendKeys(absolutePath); ```  A lot of users have this issue and I could not find a definitive answer. Any help appreciated!

column3: RemoteWebDriver#getCookies() ignores httpOnly returned by driver
column4: Firefox, Chrome 2.19+ and IEDriverServer 2.47+ all return the "httpOnly" value, but it's ignored by Java bindings when constructing Cookie object.

column3: Improve firefox extension install.rdf parsing
column4: Firefox extension loading now supports em namespace (http://www.mozilla.org/2004/em-rdf#) as default namespace in install.rdf.  Some extensions set this namespace as default which breaks parsing in the current implementation as it results an  tag being present instead of em:id.

column3: Firefox ESR 31.4.0 is not working on windows 7 using selenium jar 2.41 or even with latest jar 2.45, 2.46
column4: Firefox ESR 31.4.0 is not working on windows 7 using selenium jar 2.41, however it's working fine on XP machine.   While executing test case browser is opening and immediately it is closing, hence getting exception as "WebDriver Exception : C is null"

column3: Firefox 43.0 Auto-disables Selenium IDE
column4: Firefox 43 [automatically disables unsigned add-ons](http://mzl.la/1J7Lcsp), including the Selenium IDE itself. The [wiki says](https://wiki.mozilla.org/Addons/Extension_Signing)  > Mozilla will begin requiring all extensions to be signed in order for them to be installable in Release and Beta versions of Firefox. Signing will be done through addons.mozilla.org (AMO) and will be mandatory for all extensions, regardless of where they are hosted.  That same wiki article describes the process for signing an add-on. Please sign the add on so that I can continue using it without workarounds.

column3: refactor concrete WebDriverException#getSupportUrl's

column3: Fix a NullPointerException in RemoteWebDriver.getCurrentUrl
column4: execute() is allowed to return null (see line 643), which will cause a NullPointerException to be thrown in getCurrentUrl. This doesn't fix the underlying problem, but it causes it to throw a WebDriverException instead of a NullPointerException so the user can handle it in a reasonable way.

column3: Issues with executeScript popping up javascript alerts
column4: Execute the following java code  ``` java     public static void main(String a[]) {         System.setProperty("webdriver.ie.driver", "\\IEDriverServer.exe");         WebDriver driver = null;         try {             driver = new InternetExplorerDriver();             driver.manage().timeouts().setScriptTimeout(30, TimeUnit.SECONDS);             driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(30, TimeUnit.SECONDS);             driver.manage().timeouts().pageLoadTimeout(30, TimeUnit.SECONDS);             driver.get("http://jqueryui.com/button/#splitbutton");              // Hangs here for InternetExplorerDriver             Object hello = ((JavascriptExecutor) driver)                     .executeScript("document.defaultView.frames[0].document.getElementById('rerun').click(); return 'hello';");             // Prints "Running the last action" instead of "hello" for FirefoxDriver             System.out.println("return from javascript : " + hello);              Thread.sleep(2000);             WebDriverWait wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, 10);             wait.until(ExpectedConditions.alertIsPresent());             Alert alert = driver.switchTo().alert();             alert.dismiss();             driver.switchTo().defaultContent();         } catch (Throwable e) {             e.printStackTrace();         } finally {             if (driver != null) {                 driver.close();                 driver.quit();             }         }     } ```  **Expected behavior** The program should navigate to the specified URL, click on the jquery button, Print "hello" in the console, accept the alert and exit.  **Actual behavior on InternetExplorer** The program hangs at the line where the javascript is being executed. The driver instance is blocked for some reason.  **Actual behavior on Firefox** `Running the last action` is printed on the console instead of `hello`  **Actual behavior on Chrome** The `executeScript` returns `null`  **Using** - selenium-java 2.47.1 - jdk 1.7/1.8 - Windows 7, Windows 2008,  - IE 10/11 - Firefox 38.0.1

column3: javascript: WebElement.isElementPresent() promise does not resolve with `false`
column4: Example code:  > ``` >    driver.findElement(By.css('.container')).then((webElement) => { >            webElement.isElementPresent(By.css('.foo')) >                .then((found) => { console.log(found); }); >        }); > ```  Assuming that an element with a class of 'container' exists, if an element with class 'foo' is present, then `found == true` and it's logged to the console. If an element with class 'foo' does not exist, then the Promise callback never executes.  I believe this had worked as expected in the past (maybe in Nov 2015 - unsure of what version I was running at the time), but was unsuccessful in identifying any code changes that would have impacted this behavior during my initial cursory search.

column3: In Firefox, execution of javascript to get 'tagName' will stuck.
getWindowHandles() returns wrong value when open link with ctrl/cmd + click
column4: Environment: selenium 2.49.0, firefox/ie11 osx/linux/windows 7  test case to reproduce  ``` (java) DesiredCapabilities capabilities = new DesiredCapabilities("firefox", null, ANY); capabilities.setCapability(CapabilityType.HAS_NATIVE_EVENTS, true); driver = new RemoteWebDriver(new URL("http://localhost:4444/wd/hub"), capabilities); driver.get("https://yandex.ru/search/?text=pain"); ((JavascriptExecutor) driver).executeScript("$('.serp-list').hide()"); new Actions(driver) //            .keyDown(Keys.CONTROL)             .keyDown(Keys.COMMAND)             .click(driver.findElements(By.cssSelector("div.related a")).get(0)) //            .keyUp(Keys.CONTROL)             .keyUp(Keys.COMMAND)             .build()             .perform(); Thread.sleep(5000); assertEquals(2, driver.getWindowHandles().size()); ```  Expected: `getWindowHandles` - return handles for both new tab and the old one Actual: `getWindowHandles` - return handle only for old tab

column3: driver.manage().getCookieNamed() return incorrect cookie in ie
column4: Environment: ie11 on windows7 iedriver.exe 2.45.0.5  Simple test:  ``` DesiredCapabilities caps = new DesiredCapabilities("internet explorer", "11", Platform.WINDOWS); driver = new RemoteWebDriver(url, caps); driver.get("https://www.yandex.com/search/?text=cats"); Cookie z = driver.manage().getCookieNamed("z"); Assert.assertEquals("/search/", z.getPath()); Assert.assertThat(z.getDomain(), CoreMatchers.notNullValue()); Assert.assertThat(z.getExpiry(), CoreMatchers.notNullValue()); ```  Expected: cookie contains correct path, domain and expiration date, the same you could get with help of developer tools in browser.

column3: [Python] WebDriverException message is not returned in Chrome after upgrade to 2.49.1
column4: Environment: chromedriver 2.20 // Python 2.7.11 // Windows 7  Since upgrading Selenium to 2.49.1, we're seeing an issue when WebDriverExceptions (or items which inherit it) are raised, the exception message is being returned as an empty string. I'm also seeing the issue in 2.49.2  The behavior we're seeing is the response is being passed to check_response in errorhandler.py as a dictionary in Chrome, but (for example) in Firefox, it's being passed as a a string (so it hits the json parsing block). Chrome does not return a message, Firefox does.  Example to Reproduce  ``` driver = webdriver.Firefox() driver.get("http://www.python.org") elem = driver.find_element_by_name("NameDoesNotExist") ```  Exception on Firefox  ``` elenium.common.exceptions.NoSuchElementException: Message: Unable to locate element: {"method":"name","selector":"NameDoesNotExist"} ```  Repeat code, but with Chrome: Exception on Chrome:  ``` selenium.common.exceptions.NoSuchElementException: Message:  ```

column3: Selenium 2.48.1 Firefox clicking wrong element as page loads
column4: Environment: C#, Nuget Package Selenium 2.48.1, Firefox  In firefox Selenium is clicking the wrong element in firefox in very specific situations,  For example... Load New page via URL Run Method that waits until an element is displayed (pulls every half second to see if it returns Displayed as true) and then clicks that element. Element needs to be scrolled down to for it to be clicked Browser does not scroll and another element that navigates me to another page is clicked in its place (xpath is not the problem i'm using a unique ID)  The other element being clicked does not cover the desired element, it's actually no where near it. If i debug the test and step through it (slow it down) it clicks the correct element and the test passes so it must be some sort of race condition.  My thought is that the problem occurs when i try to click the element right as it returns displayed as true when the page loads and it has to scroll down to get it. That seems to be the only place i'm running into this issue at.  Also worth nothing that this test passes fine in 2.47

column3: Fix WebDriver Promise tests for Microsoft Edge.
column4: Edge modifies the error's stack when the error is thrown, so we have to grab the "original" stack later, after the error is thrown.

column3: WebDriver interface WebElement now extends TakesScreenshot
column4: Due to changes from 2.46 public interface WebElement extends SearchContext { to 2.47 public interface WebElement extends SearchContext, TakesScreenshot {  it is now required to implement everywhere   X getScreenshotAs(OutputType var1) throws WebDriverException;  Is this change really required?

column3: java: fix log string for RemoteTargetLocator#defaultContent
column4: driver.switchTo().defaultContent() used to log the following:     Executing: [switch to frame: null]  It turns out that the handler SwitchToFrame expects the parameter id to be set to null for switching to the default content.

column3: Click button does not work after upgrade to selenium 2.48.0
column4: Doing test automation on a Ember.js web application: I have a button which is covered by a `` with a cooky notification. It looks something like this:  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5635462/10795869/fa412dfa-7d9b-11e5-9f84-2ecfc214e2e6.png)  With **Selenium 2.47.1** clicking on that button works as expected in Firefox. With **Selenium 2.48.0** clicking this button does not work in Firefox, although there is no exception or error. It's like selenium thinks that the click worked properly but actually the click had no effect. Here the Robot Framework log:  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5635462/10796560/fd4b41ea-7d9e-11e5-89c3-d5e8309424fc.png)  The structure of HTML is something like this:  ``` html ...         ::before            Last check        ::after             ::before     Close     ::after     ```  Just for comparison - executing the same click with **Selenium 2.47.1** in Chrome results in a WebDriverException:  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5635462/10797758/6650ed48-7da4-11e5-80a6-82b7ac58de40.png)  ``` stacktrace Traceback (most recent call last):   File "", line 2, in click_button   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\Selenium2Library\keywords\keywordgroup.py", line 15, in _run_on_failure_decorator     return method(*args, **kwargs)   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\Selenium2Library\keywords\_formelement.py", line 316, in click_button     element.click()   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webelement.py", line 69, in click     self._execute(Command.CLICK_ELEMENT)   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webelement.py", line 448, in _execute     return self._parent.execute(command, params)   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\Selenium2Library\webdrivermonkeypatches.py", line 11, in execute     result = self._base_execute(driver_command, params)   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webdriver.py", line 196, in execute     self.error_handler.check_response(response)   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\errorhandler.py", line 181, in check_response     raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace) ```  System configuration I: - Microsoft Windows 7 64 bit - Firefox 41.0.2 - **Selenium 2.47.1** - selenium2library 1.7.4 - Robot Framework 2.9.2   ==> click ``  works  System configuration II: - same as configuration I but - Google Ghrome Version 46.0.2490.80 m   ==> click `` does not work, WebDriverException  System configuration III: - same as configuration I but - **Selenium 2.48.0**   ==> click `` does not work, no error/exception

column3: Parallel Actions Implementation
column4: Does anyone know where one can determine where selenium-webdriver is at relative to the latest W3C specifications? Namely, parallel actions are nicely outlined within the the specs found here http://www.w3.org/TR/webdriver/#parallel-actions, but not anywhere to be found within the selenium-docs.  Is this something that is being considered by the Selenium Project?  Thanks for any help!

column3: SendKeys() drops random characters
column4: Description: When I use Selnium SendKeys() method, not verbatim text gets entered into text field, when text contains Polish special characters. It drops random characters, not necessarily Polish ones, e.g. :  text to be sent :    tz zF kźLqxdAźq    or                        qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm text actually sent: tz zF kźLqxdAq(dropped ź)    or       qwertyuioasdfghjklzxcvbnm (dropped p) It is hard to reproduce, as it doesn't happen every time, but at random. It happens more often, the longer the string is.  Using: Windows 8.1 Enterprise Chrome 44.0.2403.107 m C# on VS 2013 SeleniumWebDriver 2.46.0 ChromeDriver 2.16.0.0

column3: Page elements not recognized on different machine while intializing through PageFactort method
column4: Dear friends and colleagues  Here is a wierd scenario or may be someone already facing this issue not sure but see for yourself.  Consider there are 5 fields initialized using PageFactory method. 3 fields are on login page which is already loaded in DOM and remaining 2(Home page after login) fields are not yet loaded in DOM.  Now when I start the login test from my machine remotely on some other client using grid, it works fine.  But when I start the test from another machine remotely on same client using grid does not work.  My toolset Language binding => C#  WebDriver 2.47.0, TestRunner => Gallio/mBUnit, Browser => Any(Chrome/FF),  DotNet Grid Standalone Server 2.47.1   I have a Login function where all page elements are initialized through PageFactory method as given below  public LoginFunction(driver)         {             PageFactory.InitElements(driver, this);           }  Elements are declared as below  ```     [FindsBy(How = How.CssSelector, Using = @"#UserName")]     [CacheLookup]     public IWebElement UserNameTextField { get; set; }      [FindsBy(How = How.CssSelector, Using = @"#Password")]     [CacheLookup]     public IWebElement PasswordTextField { get; set; }      [FindsBy(How = How.CssSelector, Using = @".span2>input")] //input[@value='Sign in']")]     [CacheLookup]     public IWebElement LoginButton { get; set; }      [FindsBy(How = How.XPath, Using = @"//h2[contains(text(),'Welcome, admin')]")]     [CacheLookup]     public IWebElement WelcomeFormMessageText { get; set; }     [FindsBy(How = How.Id, Using = @"tabslist")]     [CacheLookup]     public IWebElement MainTabsList { get; set; } ```  Now when the PageFactory.InitElements(driver, this); statement executes, the test fails while initializing WelcomeFormMessageText IWebElement which is actually not present in DOM. These elements are present on Home page after login is successful.  Now the question is the same test runs fine when I run it from my machine and fails when I run it from another machine :-(  Both the machine configs are same having identical OS, browser versions, bit systems etc.  I have tried to run the test on third machine and it fails there too. It only seems to run from my m/c.  Has anyone seen this issue? or have any clue?  Thanks in advance.

column3: ReflectionBackendDriverSupplier: merge capabilities
column4: Currently, ReflectionBackendDriverSupplier doesn't handle requiredCapabilities for WebDriver other than Firefox, and it hinted that all WebDriver should have two Capabilities argument constructor, one for 'desired' capabilitities and the other for the 'required' ones.  I hope that just merging the two capabilities into one and pass this to the WebDriver should be fine.  However, I am not sure if this is correct or not.

column3: Easier way to restart Firefox
column4: Currently, if you want to restart Firefox, you need to create a new `Firefox.Binary` instance. Moreover, I can't find a simple way to keep the same profile.

column3: elementScrollBehavior is ignored when clicking in Firefox
column4: Currently, `elementScrollBehavior` is only invoked when `getLocationOnceScrolledIntoView` is called. The commit adding this capability has also added it for `clickElement` (see [changes](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/0ff44ccc9aa327082bd00d5d0235d9078c607d03#diff-55143335a0f3eeba31262bf2a13b139aR88)), but later when native events were removed from Firefox, this code has just been removed from `clickElement` (see [changes](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/73cffa2241b255be30c77a587305e7aa83ef58ae#diff-55143335a0f3eeba31262bf2a13b139aL92)). This makes this capability useless.  I believe this is a bug and would like to fix it, but not sure where exactly `Utils.scrollIntoView` might be called. So far I came up with this patch:  ``` diff diff --git a/javascript/firefox-driver/js/wrappedElement.js b/javascript/firefox-driver/js/wrappedElement.js index 18b4e62..b327417 100644 --- a/javascript/firefox-driver/js/wrappedElement.js +++ b/javascript/firefox-driver/js/wrappedElement.js @@ -68,6 +68,11 @@ WebElement.clickElement = function(respond, parameters) {     var offset = Utils.getClickablePoint(unwrapped);  +  var inViewAfterScroll = Utils.scrollIntoView( +      unwrapped, +      (respond.session.elementScrollBehavior == 0), +      new goog.math.Coordinate(offset.x, offset.y)); +    Utils.installWindowCloseListener(respond);    Utils.installClickListener(respond, WebLoadingListener); ```  At the same time, I feel like this should be used [`bot.action.click`](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/javascript/atoms/action.js#L684-L692).  @barancev Can you please take a look at this bug?

column3: py: phantomjs: make sure the spawned phantomjs process is killed
column4: Currently with many  > wd = webdriver.PhantomJS() > wd.quit()  calls, there will be many spawned phantomjs process remained, and they'll use up the RAM.  This issue has been described at https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=5921  and has been fixed at https://code.google.com/p/selenium/source/detail?r=885b62bbb7ee  However dbac7447d803a6efd33a031df841fa5f51e70ce5 and 1bc9c24d67b30ae1ebb7be7debdbfd7c8fd93f3e removed the fix.  This commit brings the fix back

column3: Selenium problems with detecting tabs/windows on Firefox 41.0.1
column4: Currently no matter if you have several tabs opened in latest Firefox, Selenium sees them as only one.  Before when I use driver.close it close the current window but not the browser if there are more tabs like it's described -> https://i.gyazo.com/70d4984d0ba63e15b534b650903f9fb7.png but right now it close the whole Firefox instance.  Also if I try to switch to another Window (tab) it's not happening since it detect that I have only one tab (which is wrong).

column3: Disable user name and password logging on Selenium Server side
column4: Currently I am using selenium-server-standalone-2.48.2.jar, it works perfect. However, when a user name and password is passed in by client, it also logs the user name and password: " java -jar /opt/selenium/selenium-server-standalone-2.48.2.jar -log /var/log/selenium.log -forcedBrowserModeRestOfLine *firefox -maxSession 40 -browserTimeout 90 " We want to run the server in the same way, just we just do not want user name and password go to selenium.log.   Is there a method to do this or it will show up in the future release?

column3: firefox: Throw error when element cannot be clicked
column4: Current behavior is that when element is overlapped by another one, trying to click it will silent fail because click is happening on overlapping element. This commit changes the behavior so instead error is thrown telling that overlapping element would receive click. It makes the behavior mostly similar to ChromeDriver.  I've implemented this after it was [mentioned on IRC](https://botbot.me/freenode/selenium/2015-10-23/?msg=52586420&page=3) that this behavior might make sense and after a bunch of issues were reported (#1202, #1204, #1166).  That is my first time I deal with FirefoxDriver, so the code may not be the best. Also, there is now some duplication with `webdriver.chrome.isElementClickable` function so maybe it makes sense to DRY it up. Also, since I don't have much experience with Java/JavaScript testing of Selenium, it was easier for me to add regression test in Ruby.  @barancev @lukeis Please, take a look.

column3: Handle IPv6 addresses in RemoteConnection.
column4: Convert the use of gethostbyname to getaddrinfo so that IPv6 addresses can be handled.

column3: ChromeDriver: `switchTo().frame(WebElement)` should throw StaleElementReferenceException in case the element is stale
column4: Consider the following code:  ``` WebDriver driver = new ChromeDriver(); driver.get("http://the-internet.herokuapp.com/iframe");  WebElement iframe = driver.findElement(By.tagName("iframe")); driver.switchTo().frame(iframe); // works  driver.navigate().refresh();  try {     driver.switchTo().frame(iframe); // **     Assert.fail(); } catch (WebDriverException e) {     e.printStackTrace(); } finally {     driver.quit(); } ```  With ChromeDriver, the command switchFrame at the line marked with "**" returns error code 13 aka UNHANDLED_ERROR, thus throws the exception below:  ``` org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: unknown error: Runtime.evaluate threw exception: Error: element is not attached to the page document     at Object.Cache.retrieveItem (:77:17)     at unwrap (:181:20)     at unwrap (:185:19)     at callFunction (:225:29)     at apply.ELEMENT (:239:23)     at :240:3     at Object.InjectedScript._evaluateOn (:875:140)     at Object.InjectedScript._evaluateAndWrap (:808:34)     at Object.InjectedScript.evaluate (:664:21)   (Session info: chrome=46.0.2490.71)   (Driver info: chromedriver=2.20.353145 (343b531d31eeb933ec778dbcf7081628a1396067),platform=Windows NT 6.2 x86_64) (WARNING: The server did not provide any stacktrace information) Command duration or timeout: 42 milliseconds Build info: version: '2.47.1', revision: 'unknown', time: '2015-07-30 11:02:44' System info: host: '', ip: '', os.name: 'Windows 8', os.arch: 'amd64', os.version: '6.2', java.version: '1.8.0_60' Driver info: org.openqa.selenium.chrome.ChromeDriver Capabilities [{applicationCacheEnabled=false, rotatable=false, mobileEmulationEnabled=false, chrome={userDataDir=C:\Users\ascotto\AppData\Local\Temp\scoped_dir8212_30311}, takesHeapSnapshot=true, databaseEnabled=false, handlesAlerts=true, hasTouchScreen=false, version=46.0.2490.71, platform=WIN8, browserConnectionEnabled=false, nativeEvents=true, acceptSslCerts=true, locationContextEnabled=true, webStorageEnabled=true, browserName=chrome, takesScreenshot=true, javascriptEnabled=true, cssSelectorsEnabled=true}] Session ID: fcc85d2699bc9507f004e76d4b7bfc76     at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)     at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:62)     at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)     at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:422)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.ErrorHandler.createThrowable(ErrorHandler.java:206)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.ErrorHandler.throwIfResponseFailed(ErrorHandler.java:158)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.RemoteWebDriver.execute(RemoteWebDriver.java:595)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.RemoteWebDriver$RemoteTargetLocator.frame(RemoteWebDriver.java:885)     at Main.test(Main.java:45) ```  As you can see, the exception message says `unknown error: Runtime.evaluate threw exception: Error: element is not attached to the page document`. It's not too bad as it says "element is not attached to the page document", from which we can understand it's a stale element issue. But the user should be able to catch explicitly StaleElementReferenceException and recover:  ``` WebElement iframe = ... try {     driver.switchTo().frame(iframe); } catch (StaleElementReferenceException e) {     iframe = driver.findElement( .. );     driver.switchTo().frame(iframe); } ```  For comparison, please consider what happens with FirefoxDriver, which is we get a StaleElementReferenceException as expected:  ``` org.openqa.selenium.StaleElementReferenceException: Element not found in the cache - perhaps the page has changed since it was looked up Command duration or timeout: 498 milliseconds For documentation on this error, please visit: http://seleniumhq.org/exceptions/stale_element_reference.html Build info: version: '2.47.1', revision: 'unknown', time: '2015-07-30 11:02:44' System info: host: '', ip: '', os.name: 'Windows 8', os.arch: 'amd64', os.version: '6.2', java.version: '1.8.0_60' Driver info: org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver Capabilities [{applicationCacheEnabled=true, rotatable=false, handlesAlerts=true, databaseEnabled=true, version=41.0.2, platform=WINDOWS, nativeEvents=false, acceptSslCerts=true, webStorageEnabled=true, locationContextEnabled=true, browserName=firefox, takesScreenshot=true, javascriptEnabled=true, cssSelectorsEnabled=true}] Session ID: e46c5e7a-5f20-4e0c-9105-75d8a4df6cc1     at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)     at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:62)     at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)     at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:422)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.ErrorHandler.createThrowable(ErrorHandler.java:206)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.ErrorHandler.throwIfResponseFailed(ErrorHandler.java:158)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.RemoteWebDriver.execute(RemoteWebDriver.java:595)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.RemoteWebDriver$RemoteTargetLocator.frame(RemoteWebDriver.java:885)     at Main.test(Main.java:45) Caused by: org.openqa.selenium.StaleElementReferenceException: Element not found in the cache - perhaps the page has changed since it was looked up For documentation on this error, please visit: http://seleniumhq.org/exceptions/stale_element_reference.html Build info: version: '2.47.1', revision: 'unknown', time: '2015-07-30 11:02:44' System info: host: '', ip: '', os.name: 'Windows 8', os.arch: 'amd64', os.version: '6.2', java.version: '1.8.0_60' Driver info: driver.version: unknown     at .fxdriver.cache.getElementAt(resource://fxdriver/modules/web-element-cache.js:9348)     at .Utils.getElementAt(file:///C:/Users/ascotto/AppData/Local/Temp/anonymous2819227405591454245webdriver-profile/extensions/fxdriver@googlecode.com/components/driver-component.js:8942)     at .FirefoxDriver.prototype.switchToFrame(file:///C:/Users/ascotto/AppData/Local/Temp/anonymous2819227405591454245webdriver-profile/extensions/fxdriver@googlecode.com/components/driver-component.js:10724)     at .DelayedCommand.prototype.executeInternal_/h(file:///C:/Users/ascotto/AppData/Local/Temp/anonymous2819227405591454245webdriver-profile/extensions/fxdriver@googlecode.com/components/command-processor.js:12643)     at .DelayedCommand.prototype.executeInternal_(file:///C:/Users/ascotto/AppData/Local/Temp/anonymous2819227405591454245webdriver-profile/extensions/fxdriver@googlecode.com/components/command-processor.js:12648)     at .DelayedCommand.prototype.execute/

column3: Display seconds in config page for timeouts
column4: Configuration page displays timeouts in milliseconds without indicating units. Since -timeout and -browserTimeout are given in seconds, it makes sense to display these values in seconds in configuration page.  This pull requests includes code that displays timeout and browserTimeout paramaters as seconds in the configuration page in the following format:  timeout : 10s browserTimeout : 10s  Fixes #1064 partially ("The hub settings" part).

column3: Restore a isNativeEventsEnabled check.
column4: Commit 9d132ee80f545a164665325d402b37537877a96b intended to delete all native-events checks for Firefox, but it inadvertently also deleted one for Internet Explorer.

column3: Clean the anonymous profiles timely
column4: Clean the anonymous profiles in Temp timely  Anonymous profiles generated by the method `FirefoxProfile.toJson()` are not cleaned after the conversion. This causes the temporary files keep growing overtime and consume disk space.  They also consume the system memory because the file names are kept in the variable `temporaryFiles` of `TemporaryFilesystem` object, which can only be cleaned by JVM application shutdown hooks when the JVM terminated.  The fix proposed cleans the anonymous profile at each `toJson` conversion. Thus, it can clean the anonymous profiles timely. - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Make Actions.resetCompositeAction() overridable
column4: Class org.openqa.selenium.interactions.CompositeAction.java can be extended. Even the class variables of org.openqa.selenium.interactions.Actions.java are protected and therefore made for Inheritance. But there is no way to make Actions.java replace its internal CompositeAction object with an object of a class that extends CompositeAction, because Actions.resetCompositeAction() is private. Would it be possible to raise its visibilty level to protected?  Use case: I want every Actions chain to execute some code (waiting for Ajax) after its perform() method. So I extended CompositeAction to override perform(). But I also have to extend Actions to make it use my class.

column3: Unable to check disabled status of object having class=af_goLink p_AFDisabled by isEnabled() method
column4: case "enabled": Func_FindObj(ORvalname, ORvalue);                 boolval = elem.isEnabled();                 System.out.println(boolval);                 actval = boolval.toString();                 System.out.println(actval);                 break; verification object having class=af_goLink p_AFDisabled  I am doing keyword driven automation testing using selenium open to test frame work. I write the web page elements and their path in one file and the actions to be performed on them in the other. I am supposed to check if the link is enabled for a particular kind of user or not. I am using this method to check that. But 'boolval' always returns 'true' for any given link no matter it is enabled or disabled. Is there any other way to check if the link is enabled. If not in-built can we write our own method to check? The only difference between the enabled and disabled element is the presence of 'href' in the anchor tag and the name of the class.

column3: Enabled:True/False is not working (selenium)
column4: case "enabled": Func_FindObj(ORvalname, ORvalue);                 boolval = elem.isEnabled();                 System.out.println(boolval);                 actval = boolval.toString();                 System.out.println(actval);                 break; I am doing keyword driven automation testing using selenium open to test frame work. I write the web page elements and their path in one file and the actions to be performed on them in the other. I am supposed to check if the link is enabled for a particular kind of user or not. I am using this method to check that. But 'boolval' always returns 'true' for any given link no matter it is enabled or disabled. Is there any other way to check if the link is enabled. If not in-built can we write our own method to check? The only difference between the enabled and disabled element is the presence of 'href' in the anchor tag and the name of the class.

column3: Trying to fill a form more then once with array in selenium python
column4: can you fill a form more then once with the same routine in selenium?  here is what im trying to do, first i call an array with some data i want to fill the form  ``` array3=[['title','description', 'name', 'misc'],['title2','description2', 'name2', 'misc2']] ```  then i call a routine:  ``` for i in range(len(array3)):     x=0     print "Start posting"     print array3[i][x]     cattext=str(array3[i][x])     print array3[i][x]     print i     categoria=".//*[@id='posting-categories-view']/ul/li[3]/a[text()='"+cattext+"']"     catelement = wait.until(lambda driver: driver.find_element_by_xpath(categoria))     catelement.click()     x=x+1      subcatext=str(array3[i][x])     subCategoria=".//*[@id='posting-categories-view']/ul/li[3]/ul/li[4]/a[text()='"+subcatext+"']"     subcatelement = wait.until(lambda driver: driver.find_element_by_xpath(subCategoria))     subcatelement.click()     X=x+1 ··· fill rest of the form ···submit form ```  first step of the array submits with no problem, but the second time it get stuck in catelement, i know its commencing the second step, but it wont throw exceptions nor start posting the second data, any ideas of what im doing wrong?.

column3: Communication with IEDriverServer is 3x slower on Windows Server 2008 than Windows 7
column4: Both systems are 64bit, both has the same version of Selenium (2.48.0), both has the same of IE (IE11). I'm using 32 bit IEDriverServer. I run a test which checks a lot of dynamic elements. On Windows Server I cannot check all elements because they are no longer valid (because communication is so slow). There is no such problem with IE, Firefox, Chrome on Windows 7 or on Linux.  I'm using Selenium with Python and I've check communication time with CProfile.

column3: Webdriver Issues With Firefox V2.50.0
column4: Below is the HTML for one of the month dropdown in application under test.  ```               month              month             January             February             March             April             May             June             July             August             September             October             November             December ```  I used the following script to select January option from the dropdown.  driver.findElement(By.xpath(//*[@id="month2_arrow"])).click(); driver.findElement(By.xpath(//div[@id='month2_child']/ul/li[2]/span)).click();  This code will have two clicks to select January option from the month dropdown.This was working fine till Selenium Webdriver 2.47. When I upgraded the selenium to 2.50, both the steps are executed successfully but the option is not selected.

column3: Chrome starting with version 44 fails to accept keystrokes via WebDriver after sendKeys("") to several elements on the page
column4: Basically, what I am doing is getting by xPath a list of potential focus elements, using sendKeys("") to go to each element, getting the current element, then checking to see if the correct element has focus (to generate a list of focusable elements). Then I go to the first focusable element on the page and tab through the page using sendKeys(keys.TAB). Up until Chrome Version 44 that worked great, but now when I go to sendKeys(keys.TAB) through the page after the initial scan the focus does not move. Is this a problem with Chrome, or did something in the Chrome API change requiring a change in the Chrome driver?

column3: Firefoxdriver does not open Firefox with system default locale
column4: Basically, if I don't use any overrides and use new FirefoxDriver(), I see that Firefox still opens up as English Firefox on a Japanese machine. Chromedriver+chrome however appears to open up as Japanese. This actually affects some tests we have where tests make assumptions that the browser locale is already the default system locale (that only used to run with chrome, and now trying Firefox)  I checked about:config, and noticed a difference between the Selenium+Firefox (case1) and the default install of Firefox on the system (case2)  case1: intl.accept_languages=en case2: intl.accept_languages=ja,en-us,en  So there it is. I could try to add these accept_languages setting to Firefoxprofile but I would have to track down the system locale myself and find the correct locale string to use. It seems like an onerous thing to do.  Also, the same firefox I am using with Selenium, if I launch directly  as firefox.exe, it does open up with the default system locale (japanese in this case)  Why does Firefox not open up with the default system locale when launched with FirefoxDriver?

column3: JavaScript: Array of keys must be converted to string before using sendKeys
column4: Based on the documentation of the sendKeys function, it should be possible to use an array or a string but (for example) the following array leads to wrong results when expanding the '4.5' string in an edit control:  ``` element.sendKeys([webdriver.Key.CONTROL, 'a', webdriver.Key.CONTROL, webdriver.Key.BACK_SPACE, '4.5', webdriver.Key.BACK_SPACE]); ```  where converting the array to a single straing leads to the expected results:  ``` element.sendKeys([webdriver.Key.CONTROL, 'a', webdriver.Key.CONTROL, webdriver.Key.BACK_SPACE, '4.5', webdriver.Key.BACK_SPACE].join('')); ```  Do I use the API wrongly or is there something wrong with the implementation?

column3: SeleniumServer: -browserTimeout does not take effect.
column4: Base on the source code of org.openqa.selenium.server. From the usage below, It does provide a way to set the timeout in seconds a browser is allowed to hang. https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/server/src/org/openqa/selenium/server/SeleniumServer.java#L876-L877    public static void usage(String msg) {     if (msg != null) {       System.out.println(msg);     }     String INDENT = "  ";     String INDENT2X = INDENT + INDENT;     printWrappedLine("", "Usage: java -jar selenium-server.jar [-interactive] [options]\n");     printWrappedLine(INDENT,                      "-port : the port number the selenium server should use (default 4444)");     printWrappedLine(INDENT,                      "-timeout : an integer number of seconds we should allow a client to be idle");     _printWrappedLine(INDENT,                      "-browserTimeout : an integer number of seconds a browser is allowed to hang");_     printWrappedLine(INDENT,                      "-interactive: puts you into interactive mode.  See the tutorial for more details");     printWrappedLine(       INDENT,     ...  But in the method parseLauncherOptions, it doesn't has a logic to parse -browserTiemout. https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/server/src/org/openqa/selenium/server/SeleniumServer.java#L948-L1120  So when the -browserTimeout argument is parsed?

column3: Add list of supported web browsers or drivers in python
column4: As Selenium keeps on increasing the number of browsers it supports continuously (which is quite cool), it would be a really good idea to start maintaining a list of browsers that are being supported or the webdrivers that Selenium has. This would allow apps using Selenium to always remain up-to-date with all the browsers and could save hard coding them in their own apps. For example, if they want to test an application on all browsers supported by Selenium or they want to take the browser name as a parameter from the user, it would be really helpful for them to know which browsers they can test on. Right now, they have to get this list by trying hacks like getting all modules and removing 'common', 'remote' and 'support' from it.  Something like `SUPPORTED_BROWSERS = ['firefox', 'chrome', 'ie', 'safari']` in the __init__ file should do the trick. Or even better, return a list of all the browser webdriver classes like `selenium.webdriver.Firefox, selenium.webdriver.Chrome` bcoz that's what they will finally be using at the end. ;)

column3: Ability to take full page screenshot
column4: As a follow up from #646, it would be nice if Selenium offered support to take full page screenshots.  Currently, the only way to do this in a consistent manner is to screenshot/pagedown in a loop until page end is reached, then stitch images together. This is a lot of user work, and would be great if Selenium exposed a method which handles this for the user, in all browsers. Although this could be provided as a separate library, it seems to me like the perfect candidate for core inclusion.  Could a maintainer/contributor give their thoughts?

column4: Are there any plans to support Selenium for DNX/dotnet-core in the near future?  Thanks!

column3: ruby: Cannot start multiple Safari drivers concurrently
column4: An attempt to start multiple Safari drivers concurrently maybe result in process hanging infinitely. That is because the server created to communicate with Safari extension is bind to the same port. Related to #736  ``` ruby require 'selenium-webdriver' require 'timeout'  Timeout.timeout(10) do   threads, drivers = [], []   5.times do     threads

column3: ruby: Cannot start multiple PhantomJS drivers concurrently
column4: An attempt to start multiple PhantomJS drivers concurrently maybe result in PhantomJS processes binding to the same port. Related to #736   ``` ruby require 'selenium-webdriver'  threads, drivers = [], [] 2.times do   threads

column4: An attempt to start multiple IE drivers concurrently maybe result in IE drivers binding to the same port. Related to #736  ``` ruby require 'selenium-webdriver'  threads, drivers = [], [] 2.times do   threads

column3: rb: Extract service into shared superclass
column4: An attempt to share service implementation between Chrome/Edge/IE/Marionette/PhantomJS to simplify code and make it easier to maintain. Basically do the same thing that is done in Python bindings. - [x] Refactor Chrome service to use superclass - [x] Refactor Edge service to use superclass - [x] Refactor Marionette service to use superclass - [x] Refactor PhantomJS service to use superclass - [x] Refactor IE server to use superclass (if possible) - [x] Run Chrome tests to see if everything is fine - [x] Run Edge tests to see if everything is fine - [x] Run Marionette tests to see if everything is fine - [x] Run PhantomJS tests to see if everything is fine - [x] Run IE tests to see if everything is fine (ran IE9 on Windows 7) - [x] Document all the API changes (and deprecate) - [x] Document all the behaviour changes - [x] Fix unit tests  @titusfortner There is still a lot to be done here, but it would be great to hear what you think about it (and should I proceed with it at all).

column3: Add Travis CI badge to README.md
column4: Also remove trailing whitespaces.

column3: Set chromedriver to be a new process group leader
column4: Allows for easier killing of the entire chromedriver process tree.  I have signed the CLA as "Benjamin Sedat".

column3: Allow use of JUnit filters.
column4: Allow use of JUnit filters.  This change allows the JUnit Filter API to work correctly, and will fall back to it being broken if some version of JUnit4's Suite/ParentRunner hierarchy is incompatible with it. I've verified this should work with at least JUnit 4.10, 4.11, and 4.12.

column3: Allow GeckoDriverService to be extended.
column4: Allow GeckoDriverService to be extended.  Note that this is the case for other driver services.

column3: EventFiringWebDriver's interaction with Navigating/Nagivated when clicking
column4: Afternoon,  I'm using the [EventFiringWebDriver](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/75b9300def2854cb1ab01bab6a15206b665da5ad/dotnet/src/support/Events/EventFiringWebDriver.cs#L32) to listen for navigation events via the use of Navigating and Navigated event handlers.  When I `.click()` on a `WebElement` that causes navigation, then none of the `Navigating` or `Navigated` events are triggering.  Am I going about this the wrong way, or are the `Navigated` and `Navigating` events just not available if it was a `.click()` that caused the navigation?

column3: Unable to connect to host 127.0.0.1 on port 7055 after 45000 ms when using an existing profile via Grid
column4: After upgrading from 2.47.1 to 2.52.0 Firefox 44 cannot be started with an existing profile via Grid. With 2.47.1 this worked fine. ## Expected Behavior -  Firefox should start on the remote machine using the existing profile. ## Actual Behavior -  Firefox starts but nothing happens after that. After some time a WebDriverException is thrown. I attached the complete log output as a file because it's quite lengthy.  [log.txt](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/153093/log.txt) ## Steps to reproduce -  ``` import java.io.File; import java.net.MalformedURLException; import java.net.URL;  import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxProfile; import org.openqa.selenium.remote.DesiredCapabilities; import org.openqa.selenium.remote.RemoteWebDriver;  public class Test {     @org.junit.Test     public void test() throws MalformedURLException {         FirefoxProfile profile = new FirefoxProfile(new File("path/to/profile"));         DesiredCapabilities capabilities = DesiredCapabilities.firefox();         capabilities.setCapability(FirefoxDriver.PROFILE, profile);         RemoteWebDriver driver = new RemoteWebDriver(new URL("http://grid.url:4444/wd/hub"), capabilities);         driver.quit();     } } ```

column3: [WebDriver - Java] selenium-java-2.48.2.jar can't support forech
column4: After update the jar file from selenium-java-2.47.1.jar to 2.48.2, can't run my code below: #####   ... static final String[] APPS = new String[] {"A", "B", "C"...}; ... for (String app : APPS) {...} ... #####   the program stop after run the first app "A".

column3: press and hold Key via Actions.keyDown(Keys.SHIFT);
column4: After update from Selenium (with Maven) 2.47.1 to 2.48.2 (latest) the action which shall provide pressing a key and holding it down seems to fail. here my Code:         WebDriver webDriver = getDriver();         WebElement row1 = webDriver.findElement(MyBy.byTextIgnoreCSS("perthes_1855_0001.jpg")).findElement(             By.xpath("ancestor::td"));         Actions selectRows = new Actions(webDriver);          WebElement row15 = webDriver.findElement(MyBy.byTextIgnoreCSS("perthes_1855_0015.jpg")).findElement(              By.xpath("ancestor::td"));         selectRows.keyDown(Keys.SHIFT);         selectRows.click(row1);         selectRows.click(row1);         selectRows.click(row15);         selectRows.keyUp(Keys.SHIFT);         selectRows.perform(); with that 15 rwos are selectet by using version 2.47.1 but with version 2.48.2 only row 15 is selectet.

column3: Selenium webdriver not working with latest versions of Chrome(43 and 44)
column4: After the latest Chrome upgrade to Version 43, the selenium webdriver scripts stopped working. Once the base URL is loaded , the next set of steps wont work and the browser just hangs for long time and then the test fails with Timeout Exception. Same issue is there for Chrome version 44 too . I tried downgrading the Chrome version to 42 and the tests work fine.  selenium version - 2.45 Chrome Driver - 2.16 Chrome Version - 43 and 44 have issues OS - Windows 7

column3: sendKeys() fails to fill  element (WebDriver 2.48.2, Java, Firefox 40.0.3 )
column4: After switch to webdriver 2.48.2 **sendKeys()** method does not work for WebElement:  ```  ```  ``` @FindBy (css = ".editor__area")  public WebElement bodyEditor;   public Message setBodyText(String string){         bodyEditor.sendKeys(string);                 return this; }  ```  Method _setBodyText(" some string")_  fails to send any symbol to editor field. While exactly the same code works just fine in case of webdriver 2.47.1  All-in-one details on snapshot: ![page-firebug code](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13039345/10540267/31ef6870-740f-11e5-9e9a-f0bacdd82242.jpg)

column3: Wrong version on GRID Console
column4: After starting the hub using the selenium-server-standalone-2.48.2.jar, "GRID Console 2.48.0" is displayed. The nodes however, show up as 2.48.2.

column3: Failed to connect to binary FirefoxBinary
column4: After including Selenium v2.47.1 in our automated tests and setting up the Agents (test runners) with FireFox 40.0.3 the following error springs up quite often:  ```   Failed to connect to binary FirefoxBinary(C:\Apps\Mozilla Firefox\40.0\FireFox.exe) on port 7055 ```  Note: This is the same as the following issue:  ```   https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=7954 ```  The last time this occurred I had deleted my FireFox profiles (via firefox.exe -p) and then recreated them by starting up the latest version of FireFox that I had installed. This reduced the occurrences of this error by about 95%.  I have tried that this morning and will let you know, later this week, if this is a viable fix once again.

column3: Selenium Remote Webdriver ignoring timeout and browserTimeout arguments
column4: After 30mins browser is closed no matter what command line parameters are used: I have tried various combinations of:  ``` java -jar "selenium\build\java\server\src\org\openqa\grid\selenium\selenium-standalone.jar" -timeout=999999 -browserTimeout=999999 -Dwebdriver.server.s ession.timeout=999999 -Dwebdriver.server.browser.timeout=999999 ```  ``` java -jar "selenium\build\java\server\src\org\openqa\grid\selenium\selenium-standalone.jar" -timeout=-1 -browserTimeout=-1 -Dwebdriver.server.session.timeout=-1 -Dwebdriver.server.browser.timeout=-1 ```  ``` java -jar "selenium-server-standalone-2.47.1.jar" -timeout=999999999 -browserTimeout=999999 -Dwebdriver.server.session.timeout=0 ```  ``` java -jar "C:\nodejs\node_modules\selenium-server-standalone-jar\jar\selenium-server-standalone-2.47.1.jar" -timeout=999999999 -browserTimeout=9999999 -Dwebdriver.server.session.timeout=9999999 ```  It logs a message like:  ``` 09:41:01.915 INFO - Session 3c366b28-a7a4-4f97-805f-2e5fe7b97b21 deleted due to client timeout ```  Related discussion and issues: https://groups.google.com/forum/?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer#!msg/selenium-users/XFYh36Ua2Mg/TBCioWkLm7oJ  https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=3224  This is reporting the failure of the hub to update nodes: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/374  Platform: 64-bit Windows 8.1  if you need any more debug info just ask.

column3: Added a builder for creating DesiredCapabilities.
column4: Adding this builder will allow more concise ways of creating capabilities.

column3: Add builder api for setting http agent for each request
column4: Adding extra two methods to the node selenium-webdriver's builder API, to set the http agent to be used for each request. One method sets the http agent and the other method returns the http agent. CLA signed.

column3: PhantomJS driver in Python does not properly accept proxy
column4: Adding a proxy via the service argument: --proxy=ip:port does not result in the proxy being used. The same is true for adding the proxy via desired capabilities.  The specific proxy was testing with PhantomJS directly via command line, and does work as expected. It only does not work when used with Selenium.  Note: this specific proxy is accessed via localhost "--proxy=localhost:8081". I do not have an external proxy to test.

column3: Added Ie launcher tests
column4: Added launcher tests similar to `Chrome` and `Firefox`

column3: changes for PR1698
column4: added alert authentication logic and tests for rb code pairing with @abaird  Fixes #1698 - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Added newWindowAvailable until Condition
column4: Added a condition that waits for a new window to be available. When successful, this returns the handle of the new window so it is easily available to switch too.  CLA has been signed!   --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/seleniumhq/selenium/1030)

column3: Adding close connection support to HttpClient to combat CLOSE_WAIT
column4: Added a .close() method to org.openqa.selenium.remote.http.HttpClient interface.  Added a call to the client's .close() method from the HttpCommandExecutor class when a org.openqa.selenium.remote.DriverCommand.QUIT is sent.  Implemented the .close() method in org.openqa.selenium.remote.internal.ApacheHttpClient which taps the connectionManager and closes idle connections.  Fixes #1080

column3: Update README.md
column4: Added "Books" section under documentation and a link to the "Selenium WebDriver in Practice" by Yujun Liang and Alex Collins (Manning Publications)

column3: [Java] Add toString() to DefaultElementLocator
column4: Add toString() method to DefaultElementLocator and child classes in order to display descriptive message instead of object's class name and hash code when TimeoutException is thrown while using PageFactory.  **Current version:** `org.openqa.selenium.TimeoutException: Timed out after XX seconds waiting for visibility of Proxy element for: org.openqa.selenium.support.pagefactory.DefaultElementLocator@64ecef7e`  **Proposed improvement:** `org.openqa.selenium.TimeoutException: Timed out after XX seconds waiting for visibility of Proxy element for: DefaultElementLocator 'By.className: myClass'`  CLA is signed.

column3: IEDriver: ability to take screenshot without window resizing
column4: Add new capability `ie.resizeOnScreenshot`. If set to `false` then Viewport screenshot will be taken, if `true` (default), than as usual - all that stuff with resizing and so on.

column3: Add FluentWait.withMessage with string supplier
column4: Add a withMethod(Supplier messgaeSupplier) to be able to evaluate the message when the wait is over, thus enabling developers to show more info on the context of failure through closures. Internally, the FluentWait class is using a supplier. withMessage(String message) method kept for backward compatibility creates a supplier that return the given string.

column3: Add FluentWait.withMessage with string supplier
column4: Add a withMethod(Supplier messgaeSupplier) to be able to evaluate the message when the wait is over, thus enabling developers to show more info on the context of failure through closures. Internally, the FluentWait class is using a supplier. withMessage(String message) method kept for backward compatibility creates a supplier that return the given string.

column3: Seleniun Standalone Server using Apache Commons Collection 3.2.1
column4: A review of recent versions of the selenium server and/or the selenium standalone server suggest it is using and delivers the Apache Commons Collection Library version 3.2.1.  This version of the Apache Commons Collection Library has a known issue.  https://threatpost.com/critical-java-bug-extends-to-oracle-ibm-middleware/115319/ http://www.infoq.com/news/2015/11/commons-exploit  It's possible for ALMOST ANYTHING that can connect to [an affected machine] to bypass authentication, authorization and auditing and remote execute code to take over a remote Java Process JVM (App Server or Standalone).  It is unknown (by me) if Selenium Server itself provides an endpoint or access point allowing an untrusted user to exploit this vulnerability.  However, the presence of  the Apache Commons Collections Library 3.2.1 in the active classpath for the running JVM exposes this vulnerability for others that may be extending the functionality of the Seleniun Server.  Specifically, users augmenting the JVM to be a Java RMI Server in tandem with the Selenium Server.  The Apache Commons Collection Library Version 3.2.2 provides a fix removing this vulnerability from the Library.  I believe it is in the best interest of the Selenium Server community to move to this new library as soon as possible.

column3: Proxy cannot be passed in from capabilities in protractor.conf.js for selenium-webdriver js/node
column4: A proxy should be read in from capabilities, however it is not.   from selenium-webdriver/builder.js   ```  /** @private {?string} */   this.proxy_ = null;    /** @private {!webdriver.Capabilities} */   this.capabilities_ = new Capabilities(); ```  ``` if (url) {     var executor = executors.createExecutor(url, this.proxy_);     return WebDriver.createSession(executor, capabilities, this.flow_);   } ```  We should have something like this instead:  `this.proxy_ = this.capabities.proxy;`

column3: Do not require extensions to be signed
column4: A pref to require installs be signed by a Mozilla-issued add-on signing certificate is set to true by default in Firefox 41, causing the WebDriver Firefox extension to fail to install. Setting it to false allows WebDriver to continue working on Firefox 41 in lieu of being signed.

column3: In Chrome, new web page opens with child browsing context active
column4: A minimal website which reproduces this behavior can be viewed at http://flash-critic.codio.io:3000/  In a nutshell, when I click on a link, I expect the new page which opens to be in the top-level browsing context rather that a child context (iframe in this example).  Firefox and phantomjs do this, but Chrome does not.  I am using Chrome 44.0.2403.89 m and Chromedriver 2.16.  The python code which follows demonstrates the problem.  ``` python # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- from selenium import webdriver from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By from selenium.webdriver.common.keys import Keys from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import Select from selenium.common.exceptions import NoSuchElementException from selenium.common.exceptions import NoAlertPresentException from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC import unittest  # Using selenium webdriver to automate browser and scrape  class SELENIUMTEST(unittest.TestCase):     def setUp(self):         #  Pick driver to use here by commenting out others         self.driver = webdriver.Chrome() #service_args=["--verbose", "--log-path=C:\\qc1.log"])         #self.driver = webdriver.Firefox()         #self.driver = webdriver.PhantomJS(executable_path='C:\Users\\redacted\Downloads\phantomjs.exe')         self.driver.implicitly_wait(20)         self.verificationErrors = []         self.accept_next_alert = True      def test_s_e_l_e_n_i_u_m(self):         driver = self.driver         driver.get("http://flash-critic.codio.io:3000")         #  Now on index page         driver.switch_to.frame("main")         element = driver.find_element_by_partial_link_text("Manage")         element.click()         #  Now on new page - but initial context is the first iframe!         driver.switch_to.default_content() # ? bug - shouldn't need to do this         driver.switch_to.frame("Search")         pass         # All done       def is_element_present(self, how, what):         try: self.driver.find_element(by=how, value=what)         except NoSuchElementException, e: return False         return True      def is_alert_present(self):         try: self.driver.switch_to_alert()         except NoAlertPresentException, e: return False         return True      def close_alert_and_get_its_text(self):         try:             alert = self.driver.switch_to_alert()             alert_text = alert.text             if self.accept_next_alert:                 alert.accept()             else:                 alert.dismiss()             return alert_text         finally: self.accept_next_alert = True      def tearDown(self):         self.driver.quit()         self.assertEqual([], self.verificationErrors)  if __name__ == "__main__":     unittest.main() ```

column3: CSP cannot be enabled in FirefoxDriver
column4: A few years ago, @barancev made a change (https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/1b3c4fcf96d37f53130612f37021005e7eb865dc) to fix a javascript error encountered when evaluate.js was included on a page.    https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=6358  However, the effect of this change is that it is impossible to launch a Firefox instance that respects CSP headers and directives.  CSP is becoming increasingly relevant and many sites are implementing it.  I think it's fine to leave CSP disabled by default, however, we should not prevent users from setting this attribute to true by including it in the "frozen" (immutable) section of the Firefox driver configuration.  Instead, it should be moved to the "mutable" section so that users can change the value of this setting and execute tests in a context that respects CSP headers and directives.

column3: Python binding does not handle potentially animated attributes correctly
column4: `selenium.webdriver.remote.WebElement.get_attribute` sometimes fails because the returned value from a lower level call is a dictionary. Here's the method:  ```     def get_attribute(self, name):         """Gets the given attribute or property of the element."""         resp = self._execute(Command.GET_ELEMENT_ATTRIBUTE, {'name': name})         attributeValue = ''         if resp['value'] is None:             attributeValue = None         else:             attributeValue = resp['value']             if name != 'value' and attributeValue.lower() in ('true', 'false'):                 attributeValue = attributeValue.lower()         return attributeValue ```  When called with the `name` "href" on an `` element, `resp['value']` is sometimes not a string but a dictionary, something like `{"baseVal": "foo", "animVal": "foo"}` (this is using Chrome). Calling `attributeValue.lower()` when `attributeValue` is a dictionary naturally raises `AttributeError`. ## Expected Behavior -  No `AttributeError` should be raised, and the `animVal` value should be returned as a string. Just returning the `resp['value']` would be preferable behaviour, leaving the caller to decide how to deal with unexpected return types. ## Actual Behavior -  Crashes with an `AttributeError`. ## Steps to reproduce -  Bring up any page which causes the Chrome remote driver to return a dictionary rather than a string for the `href` attribute of an `` element.

column3: Use of "takesElementScreenshot" to check if W3C Compliant browser might break compatibility with third-party drivers
column4: `"takesElementScreenshot"` is used to check if driver is w3c complaint and css selectors should be used for findElement and findElements commands. This might break comparability with third-party drivers, e.g. mobile drivers. `"takesElementScreenshot"` is not related to ability of a driver to find anything by css selector in general. Maybe [this](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/06fd3f334462af579674e1015136232f23fdb615/py/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py#L141-L142) check can be replaced with a more specific one?  ``` py # Quick check to see if we have a W3C Compliant browser self.w3c = "takesElementScreenshot" in self.capabilities ```  There is a  `cssSelector` capability in [WebDriver spec](https://w3c.github.io/webdriver/webdriver-spec.html#element-location-strategies) which seems to be more suitable:  > If the browser can support locating elements by CSS Selector, it must set the "cssSelector" capability to boolean true when responding to the newSession().

column3: ExecuteJavaScript always throws when JavaScript returns null
column4: _This is an issue in the WebDriver.Support library for .NET._  When using the `OpenQA.Selenium.Support.Extensions.WebDriverExtensions.ExecuteJavaScript` extension method and the script invoked returns `null`, then the method `IsInstaceOfType` (WebDriverExtensions.cs, line 91) will return `false` (`null` isn't an instance of any type). This causes the method to throw a `WebDriverException`, rather than returning `null` to the caller.

column3: ExecuteJavaScript does not handle Nullable very well
column4: _This is an issue in the WebDriver.Support library for .NET._  Almost immediately after my pull request last time (#1258), I realized that the `Nullable` type is a struct, and thus also a value type. One of the checks I added via the pull request will throw when any value type is used. This check should be modified to exclude the `Nullable` type, since it does support null values.

column3: Mouse drag yields undefined behaviour?
column4: [The protocol spec has this to say on the `buttonDown` action](https://github.com/seleniumhq/selenium/wiki/JsonWireProtocol#sessionsessionidbuttondown) (emphasis mine):  > Click and hold the left mouse button (at the coordinates set by the last `moveto` command). Note that the next mouse-related command that should follow is `buttonup`. **Any other mouse command (such as click or another call to `buttondown`) will yield undefined behaviour.**  It seems reasonable that `buttonDown` then `click` should result in undefined behaviour, but the common use case for `buttonDown` is to follow it with a `moveto` to simulate a drag. I'd count `moveto` as a mouse command which isn't `buttonUp` and therefore this also results in undefined behaviour.  Is this just poor wording or is `buttonDown` then `moveto` not a legal sequence?
