Reproduced with v2.45 and v2.48.0, on both Firefox and Chrome.

column3: WebElement.getAttribute("class") does not comply with javadoc on Chrome/FF/IE + Java
column4: [`WebElement#getAttribute()`](https://selenium.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/docs/api/java/org/openqa/selenium/WebElement.html#getAttribute%28java.lang.String%29), when using `ChromeDriver`, `FirefoxDriver` or `InternetExplorerDriver`, does not comply with its javadoc specification (bold is mine):  > Get the value of a the given attribute of the element. Will return the current value, even if this has been modified after the page has been loaded. More exactly, this method will return the value of the given attribute, unless that attribute is not present, in which case the value of the property with the same name is returned. **If neither value is set, null is returned**. The "style" attribute is (...). Finally, the following commonly mis-capitalized attribute/property names are evaluated as expected: > - "class" > -  "readonly" >  > Parameters: > name - The name of the attribute. >  > Returns: > The attribute's current value or null if the value is not set.  The element `an element without class attribute` returns `""` for `.getAttribute("class")`, when `null` is expected.  Note: The `HtmlUnitDriver` works fine.  Other attributes, with random names (such as `"other"`), return `null`.  ---  **Reproducing:**  ``` html                an element without class attribute       ```  ``` java WebDriver driver = new ChromeDriver();               driver.get("..."); WebElement p = driver.findElement(By.id("no-class")); String classAttr = p.getAttribute("class"); // classAttr is "", when it should be null String otherAttr = p.getAttribute("other"); // otherAttr is null, as expected ```  Chrome executable is 2.20, IEDriverServer is 2.48.0. Selenium-java is 2.48.2. JDK is 7.

column3: Ruby Marionette/Wires/W3C Support
column4: @p0deje - The goal of this PR is for user tests to work seamlessly with current versions of Firefox and Wires-only versions of Firefox. If their version of Firefox is incompatible with the current extension-based implementation, then this will raise an error for a user to download wires and put it in their PATH.  To test this out, you need to download wires: https://github.com/jgraham/wires/releases & Firefox Nightly. If you are on Linux and have multiple copies of firefox (Nightly & Release), you need to specify the path to the nightly firefox-bin file in ENV['FIREFOX_NIGHTLY_PATH'].  I've run the Ruby specs for this PR on all supported browsers in Windows, Linux & Mac. All tests pass with this code, or are guarded against with specific notes as to what is preventing it passing. This is definitely not the best abstracted or most elegant solution, but it works and is completely backward compatible.  Feedback is appreciated, otherwise I'll merge it in and continue to clean it up as more of the W3C protocol is implemented.

column3: Base URL Should Allow Path
column4: 1. Open the IDE. 2. Enter https://code.google.com/p/selenium/ (where /p/selenium is the path) as the base URL. 3. Insert a new "open" command with a target of /w/list. This is a path relative to https://code.google.com/p/selenium/. (That is, https://code.google.com/p/selenium/w/list is a valid page.) 4. Right click the open command and execute it.  What is the expected output? What do you see instead?  Expectation: Selenium should send a command to the browser that it should open https://code.google.com/p/selenium/w/list.  Actual Result: Selenium commands the browser to open https://code.google.com/w/list, which is invalid and results in a 404 page.  Selenium IDE 2.9.1, Firefox 44.0 (Originally reported as https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=3116.)

column3: Core extensions are loaded 2x - document this, or prevent it
column4: 1. Have Selenium IDE 2.4.0 in Firefox 25 2. Have a Core extension in a ,js file, specify it at IDE > Options > Options > core extensions (and restart Selenium) 3. The file will be loaded/processed (at least) twice 4. first, at IDE startup 5. second, the first time I run any Selenese command    See stacktraces below.  This may not affect simple usage. But it is badly confusing if your Core extension creates objects via XPCOM or JS component, SQLite connection, a file etc. - objects that need to be tracked or released, or that are book kept somehow.  Action needed: Either - preferred: change the behaviour, so that Core extension(s) are loaded only once - or: document this at http://www.seleniumhq.org/docs/02_selenium_ide.jsp#user-extensions  Example of stack trace in Selenium IDE 2.9.1:  At srtart of Selenium IDE: @chrome://selenium-ide/content/tools.js -> file:///tmp/core-extension.js?1453953484869:3:6 ExtensionsLoader.loadSubScript/ file:///tmp/core-extension.js?1453953493781:3:6 ExtensionsLoader.loadSubScript/

column3: Fix test case report text corruption if encoding differen from ISO_8859_1
column4: - [X] I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla) # Summary  If test case contains non ISO_8859_1 characters html report could not display them correctly. # How to reproduce: ## scenario:  `open http://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selenium` `assertText id=content *инструмент*` ## target page:  ![target-page](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17738390/13729737/45677ca4-e94d-11e5-9f5a-88b53b31c16e.png) ## Expected html report result:  ![report-good](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17738390/13958671/0bff7162-f062-11e5-9411-6327caf4ba91.png) ## Actual html report result:  ![encoding-wrong](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17738390/13729715/d49a343a-e94c-11e5-8794-e714a6c895a7.png) ## Description  Problem: If test case contains non ISO_8859_1 characters html report could not display them correctly.  How problem was solved: 1. By specifying file encoding for output and adding `` to html output header. 2. Current version of `selenium-testrunner.js` uses standard html POST method by `form.submit()`. It uses `application/x-www-form-urlencoded` content type. Unfortunately, `form.submit()` do not attach charset to content type. On server side jetty waits for charset and if it could not find it – uses default ISO_8859_1.  `form.submit()` was replaced by ajax post with fixed content type header. XMLHttpRequest allows to modify content type header. `Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded`  was changed to `Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded;charset=UTF-8`  We can change default UTF-8 report encoding by setting `org.openqa.selenium.server.htmlrunner.result.encoding` system property   --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/seleniumhq/selenium/1794)

column3: fix incorrect file access modes on some Python files
column4: - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  This PR is to fix incorrect file access modes on some Python files.  Git does not store full *nix file permissions, but it does mark whether or not a file's mode is executable (using octal 100755 or 100644).  From the selenium repo's base directory, I run this to recursively list all executable files under the py/selenium and py/docs directories:  ``` $ git ls-files ./py/selenium ./py/docs/ --stage | grep 100755 | awk '{print $1" "$4}' ```  output:  ``` 100755 py/docs/source/webdriver/selenium.webdriver.common.html5.application_cache.rst 100755 py/docs/source/webdriver/selenium.webdriver.common.proxy.rst 100755 py/selenium/webdriver/chrome/options.py 100755 py/selenium/webdriver/common/action_chains.py 100755 py/selenium/webdriver/common/by.py 100755 py/selenium/webdriver/common/desired_capabilities.py 100755 py/selenium/webdriver/common/proxy.py 100755 py/selenium/webdriver/common/touch_actions.py 100755 py/selenium/webdriver/phantomjs/service.py 100755 py/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py 100755 py/selenium/webdriver/remote/webelement.py ```  The files listed should not be executable (octal 100755), and should have the same file access mode as other source files (octal 100644).  to fix the situation, I ran:  ``` $ find ./py/selenium ./py/docs/ -type f -executable | xargs chmod -x ```  This removed the execution bit from those files... changing access mode from 100755 to 100644.

column3: Added an overload of ExecuteJavaScript extension method that returns void
column4: - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  Sometimes I want to execute JavaScript through Selenium, but the script doesn't return a value. Before this change I either had to use the ((IJavaScriptExecutor)IWebDriver).ExecuteScript(myScript, args) or somehow change my script to return something and use the ExecuteJavaScript extension, with the generic argument.  This change allows to execute JavaScript through the Selenium Extensions without casting and without having to return any value.

column3: Python: Page Object Implementation
column4: - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  Page object implementation in Python. This allows you to follow the Page Object Model design pattern for test development and borrows its ideas from the C#/Java implementation of PageObjects.  Each page object inherits from `PageObject` and defines a number of `FindBy` or `FindAllBy` within.  An example the implementation in action:  ```         from selenium.webdriver import Firefox         from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By         from selenium.webdriver.support.page_objects import PageObject, FindBy, FindAllBy          class SeleniumHome(PageObject):             search_box = FindBy(By.ID, 'q')             submit_button = FindBy(By.ID, 'submit')              def __init__(self, driver):                 super().__init__(driver) #  Python 3 __super__              def search_for(self, text):                 self.search_box.send_keys(text)                 self.submit_button.click()                  return SearchPage(self.driver)           class SearchPage(PageObject):             search_results = FindAllBy(By.CLASS_NAME, 'gs-title')          wd = Firefox()         wd.get('http://www.seleniumhq.org/')         page = SeleniumHome(wd)         results = page.search_for('Hello')         results.search_results[2].click() ```  The implementation is very simple, and only defines the `PageObject`, `FindBy` and `FindAllBy` objects.  The magic happens in the `FindBy`/`FindAllBy`, upon getting it, we return an instance (or list of instances) of the `WebElement` defined by the parameters in the `FindBy`/`FindAllBy` constructor  Tests are included. Let me know your thoughts on this. I'm completely open to anything.  Thanks.

column3: Remove unneccessary 'throws' annotations
column4: - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  If you use the addExtension methods you have to handle an IOException although it cannot be thrown. The constructors of FileExtension/ClasspathExtension do not throw IOExceptions. So the 'throws' annotation of the method addExtension is not neccessary.

column3: Standalone version problem with Opera
column4: **Version: 2.46.0** **Tested Browser: Opera 12.16 and Opera 26** (I tried both of them since I'm not sure whether the standalone version supports OperaDriver or the latter one) **Tested OS: Kali Linux 3.14 in my local environment and Ubuntu 14.04 with Xvfb framebuffer in EC2**  Currently, I'm trying to run [Codeception](http://codeception.com/) tests with the standalone version of Selenium 2.46. I've tried to run several same tests with Chrome and Firefox, but I cannot execute my tests in Opera.  Selenium's log is as the following:  ``` freedomofkeima@freedomofkeima:~/Desktop$ java -jar selenium-server-standalone-46.0.jar 19:34:30.248 INFO - Launching a standalone Selenium Server 19:34:30.359 INFO - Java: Sun Microsystems Inc. 23.25-b01 19:34:30.360 INFO - OS: Linux 3.14-kali1-amd64 amd64 19:34:30.429 INFO - v2.46.0, with Core v2.46.0. Built from revision 87c69e2 19:34:30.606 INFO - Driver provider org.openqa.selenium.ie.InternetExplorerDriver registration is skipped: registration capabilities Capabilities [{platform=WINDOWS, ensureCleanSession=true, browserName=internet explorer, version=}] does not match the current platform LINUX 19:34:30.607 INFO - Driver class not found: com.opera.core.systems.OperaDriver 19:34:30.607 INFO - Driver provider com.opera.core.systems.OperaDriver is not registered 19:34:30.612 INFO - Driver class is built for higher Java version: org.openqa.selenium.htmlunit.HtmlUnitDriver 19:34:30.620 INFO - Driver provider org.openqa.selenium.htmlunit.HtmlUnitDriver is not registered 19:34:30.916 INFO - RemoteWebDriver instances should connect to: http://127.0.0.1:4444/wd/hub 19:34:30.916 INFO - Selenium Server is up and running 19:34:33.781 INFO - Executing: [new session: Capabilities [{browserName=opera}]]) 19:34:33.918 INFO - Creating a new session for Capabilities [{browserName=opera}] Starting ChromeDriver 2.16.333243 (0bfa1d3575fc1044244f21ddb82bf870944ef961) on port 3635 ```  **Result from Kali Linux** Instead of opening a new Opera instance, Selenium started my Chrome browser instead of an Opera browser (see the last line from the log above).  **Result from Ubuntu 14.04** Instead of starting a new Opera browser, Codeception suggested that I have a misconfiguration problem with Phantom JS. However, I don't use Phantom JS in my testing. For your information, the test runs smoothly with Chrome and Firefox.   ``` Codeception PHP Testing Framework v2.0.15 Powered by PHPUnit 4.7.7 by Sebastian Bergmann and contributors. [UnknownServerException] The path to the driver executable must be set by the phantomjs.binary.path capability/system property/PATH variable; for more information, see https://github.com/ariya/phantomjs/wiki. The latest version can be downloaded from http://phantomjs.org/download.html ```  ---  After that, I tried to run it with the standalone version of **Selenium 2.39** and **Opera 12.16**. Surprisingly, it can access my Opera browser (even though there are several problems compared to Chrome and Firefox).   I think this issue is related to the following line: `19:34:30.607 INFO - Driver class not found: com.opera.core.systems.OperaDriver`. In the previous version, there is no such of error message. Is there any important changes that I missed in the configuration?  Thank you.

column3: [java] new ExpectedCondition windowsToBe N
column4: **Use case** - save number of current windows open (m) - click link which opens a new window - wait until windowsToBe m+1 - switch to the new window  About the name, another option is `numberOfWindowsToBe`, more verbose but also more precise. What do you think?  Also, I see that `RemoteWebDriver#getWindowHandles` may throw WebDriverException in case of ClassCastException. Shall we catch it in windowsToBe? I'm asking that because the javadoc of `WebDriver#getWindowHandles` does not mention any `@throws`.  And how about adding an integration test (maybe in FirefoxDriverTest?) to have the use case above in the test suite (tests as documentation)?  Thanks

column3: Running Protractor tests on Webdriver 2.47.1 gets - Error: Server terminated early with status 1
column4: **Steps:** 1. Install Protractor 2.5.1 via npm 2. Update webdriver/chrome: `webriver-manager update` (installs WebdriverJS 2.47.1) 3. Run any Protractor test  **Results:** Two of four people on my team get the error below, and cannot ever run the tests until they downgrade webdriver. It works fine for the other two machines.   **Impact:** - Downgrading Webdriver to 2.45.0 fixes the problem.  - This occurs for 1/2 my team, and I found the [same issue on StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33196337/gulp-protractor-selenium-webdriver-exited-status-1/33269135#33269135)  **Error:**  ``` Starting selenium standalone server... [launcher] Running 1 instances of WebDriver [launcher] Process exited with error code 1 /usr/local/lib/node_modules/protractor/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/lib/goog/async/nexttick.js:41  goog.global.setTimeout(function() { throw exception; }, 0);                                            ^ Error: Server terminated early with status 1    at Error (native)    at /usr/local/lib/node_modules/protractor/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/remote/index.js:204:25    at promise.ControlFlow.runInFrame_ (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/protractor/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/lib/goog/../webdriver/promise.js:1857:20)    at goog.defineClass.notify (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/protractor/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/lib/goog/../webdriver/promise.js:2448:25)    at promise.Promise.notify_ (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/protractor/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/lib/goog/../webdriver/promise.js:564:12)    at Array.forEach (native)    at promise.Promise.notifyAll_ (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/protractor/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/lib/goog/../webdriver/promise.js:553:15)    at goog.async.run.processWorkQueue (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/protractor/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/lib/goog/async/run.js:130:15)    at runMicrotasksCallback (node.js:337:7)    at process._tickCallback (node.js:355:11) ```

column3: "Exception: Unable to find a free port" - SeGrid/Python/Chromedriver/Ubuntu+OSX
column4: **Short Description:** on attempting to execute parallel tests on a host using selenium grid, the server-standalone hub accepts the first session and rejects all subsequent requests to create a session until the first terminates.  **Longer Description:** I am not a java developer, so I can only dig so deeply, but it does look like something is not being correctly executed in the PortProber.java class.  However, it may be something to do with the python requests to create a new session.  I spent some time digging into the python code and wasn't able to find a way to force a particular port be requested for the new session.  We're trying to run multiple scripts on a headless virtual.  This pattern has worked previously, but we needed to make updates to our chrome version, so we went ahead and updated the selenium-standalone version (I've tried 2.49-2.52), chromedriver (2.20-2.21), and Chrome (48.0.2564.82).  In fact, in developing the python test script, I was able to run 4 sessions simultaneously on my OSX laptop.  That is no longer the case (server standalone 2.50/2.52 tried - 2.50 previously worked)  I did try the selenium-server-standalone + a quick webdriver.io (nodeJS) script and it appears to work on my laptop.  **Script to recreate:** (start one instance, then start another on the same system)  ``` python #test.py from selenium import webdriver import time  baseURL='http://www.yahoo.com' url2='http://www.bing.com'  options=webdriver.ChromeOptions() options.add_argument('--disable-logging') driver=webdriver.Remote(desired_capabilities=options.to_capabilities())  driver.get(baseURL) time.sleep(2.5) print(driver.title)  driver.get(url2) time.sleep(2.5) print(driver.title)  driver.get(baseURL) time.sleep(2.5) print(driver.title)  driver.get(url2) time.sleep(2.5) print(driver.title)  driver.close() driver.quit() ```  **Python Script Error:**  ``` >>>python test.py Traceback (most recent call last):   File "test.py", line 11, in      driver=webdriver.Remote(desired_capabilities=options.to_capabilities())   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/selenium-2.51.1-py2.7.egg/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 87, in column3: FindElement(By.ClassName("X Y Z")  Doesn't work...
column4: **Problem** Elements with multiple classes are not found using By.ClassName as shown in title.  **Solution** Add iterator to that function that will allow multiple classnames separated by spaces to be used.

column3: PageFactory: Support instantiation of pages that depend on concrete WebDriver implementations
column4: **Motivation:** I'd like to instantiate pages by passing my own concrete WebDriver implementation, e.g.   ``` java public class MyWebDriverWrapper implements WebDriver {  /* ... */ }  public class MyPage {     public MyPage(MyWebDriverWrapper driver) { /* ... */ } } ```  **Problem:** Due to the way the `PageFactory.instantiatePage()` method is implemented, I'm forced to use casting:  ``` java public class MyPage {     public MyPage(WebDriver driver) {          this.driver = (MyWebDriverWrapper) driver;     } } ```  **Suggestion:** Change the `PageFactory.instantiatePage()` method to support pages that expect WebDriver subtypes:  ``` java private static  T instantiatePage(WebDriver driver, Class pageClassToProxy) {     try {       Constructor constructor = null;       try {         // Try to find a constructor with a concrete WebDriver subtype         constructor = pageClassToProxy.getConstructor(driver.getClass());       } catch (NoSuchMethodException e) {          // Continue as usual         try {             constructor = pageClassToProxy.getConstructor(WebDriver.class);         } catch (NoSuchMethodException e) {             return pageClassToProxy.newInstance();         }       }       return constructor.newInstance(driver);     } catch (InstantiationException e) {       throw new RuntimeException(e);     } catch (IllegalAccessException e) {       throw new RuntimeException(e);     } catch (InvocationTargetException e) {       throw new RuntimeException(e);     } } ```  Probably there's a good reason that the current implementation is what it is. Nevertheless I'd appreciate if you share your thoughts on this.

column3: java: User-friendly description for By* classes (in error case)
column4: **Description** 1) It would be great to have opportunity for adding of user-friendly description for By locators: // Some page object class // Section with web-elements locators (as example) private By someLocator = By.id("id123").description("Element Foo on page Bar"); // or private By someLocator2 = By.id("id123", "Element Foo on page Bar");  2) For FindBy annotation need to add new attribute "description"  3) Need to change toString() method in ById and others By\* classes (add "description" output)  **Benefits** More readable errors (element not found and etc). _Both_ locator and _user-friendly description_ (for problem element) will be present in test report (in stack-trace if error occured)

column3: ((Locatable) element).getCoordinates().inViewPort()  doesn't scroll to element in selenium-java
column4: ((Locatable) element).getCoordinates().inViewPort()  doesn't scroll to element.   Steps to reproduce: 1. Deploy the SmartGwtTester-1.0.war to e.g. Tomcat (pls see comment about attachment below) 2. Execute the following test:  ``` public class ScrollingIssue {      private static Logger LOG = LoggerFactory.getLogger(ScrollingIssue.class);     private static Logger BROWSER_LOG = LoggerFactory.getLogger("Browser");      WebDriver driver = new FirefoxDriver();     WebDriverWait wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, 5);      @Test     public void simpleTest() {         //open  URL         driver.get("http://localhost:8888/SmartGwtTester-1.0/");         driver.manage().window().maximize();         List results = driver.findElements(By.xpath("//td[@class='treeCell']//tbody/tr"));         int items = results.size();         System.out.println("total number of items is " + items);         int i = 0;         for (WebElement result : results) {             ((Locatable) result).getCoordinates().inViewPort();             WebElement itemLabel = result.findElement(By.xpath("./td[3][@class='treeCell'][contains(@style, 'white-space:nowrap')]"));             String itemLabelText = itemLabel.getText();             System.out.println("Click on #" + (i + 1) + " " + itemLabelText);             WebElement checkbox = result.findElement(By.xpath("./td[2][@class='treeCell']/span[2]"));             checkbox.click();             i++;         }     } } ```  Actual Result: The inViewPort() is not scrolling to 15th element in to view so the test is failing starting this point. All elements before #15 were already in View by default.  The issue is reproducible starting from Selenium 2.35 till Selenium 2.49.1 inclusive. The last working version is 2.34.  I have the war file to reproduce this issue unfortunately the file size is more than 10MB allowed. Please let me know where I can upload it.  Update: The file can be downloaded from here: http://turbobit.net/ih19hhutyehx.html

column3: Safari can wait indefinitely page load (driver.get command)
column4: > Safari: 8.0.8 (10600.8.9) > MacBook Air: OS X Yosemite 10.10.5 > Java: JDK 1.7.0_79-b15 > WebDriver: 2.47.1 > SafariDriver: 2.45.0  One page of our SUT is loading very long time (>1 hour) and SafariDriver doesn't throw an exception. To be honest it is loaded, but safari says that loading still is in progress.  ``` java SafariOptions safariOptions = new SafariOptions(); safariOptions.setUseCleanSession(true);  DesiredCapabilities capabilities = DesiredCapabilities.safari(); capabilities.setCapability(SafariOptions.CAPABILITY, safariOptions);  WebDriver webdriver = new SafariDriver(capabilities); webdriver.get("http://sut"); ```  I've tried add:  ``` java webdriver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(10, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS); ```  and  ``` java webdriver.manage().timeouts().setScriptTimeout(10, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS); ```  but It didn't help.

column3: Incorrect handling of "port 0" in Selenium Grid setup
column4: ###### Background: - Under Linux and Windows, bind()-ing to network port 0 assigns the application a free port from the dynamic port range. - I opened a similar ticket (#1292) but it was rejected because I only referred to deprecated RC tests, but the described behaviour also affects WebDriver tests. ###### Test setup: - Selenium server standalone version 2.48.2 - CentOS 7 - Java 1.7.0_91 ###### Issue description: - In a Selenium Grid setup, nodes launched using option `-port 0` will correctly listen to a random free port assigned by the OS but will wrongly register on the hub using **port 0** instead of the effective port they are listening on. ###### Example:  While having a hub listening on port 4444, launch a node with a `nodeconfig.json` similar to:  ``` {   "capabilities":       [         {           "browserName": "firefox" ,           "maxInstances": 2,           "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"         }       ],   "configuration":   {     "proxy": "org.openqa.grid.selenium.proxy.DefaultRemoteProxy",     "maxSession": 2,     "port": 0,     "host": 127.0.0.1,     "register": true,     "registerCycle": 5000,     "hubPort": 4444,     "hubHost": 127.0.0.1   } } ```  `lsof` will show that the node process listens on a random port offered by the OS, but the Grid console will show the node as being registered with **port 0** instead of the effective listening port:  ``` nodeConfig:nodeconfig3.json port:0 hubConfig:/opt/selenium/hubconfig.json servlets:[] host:127.0.0.1 cleanUpCycle:5000 browserTimeout:0 hubHost:127.0.0.1 registerCycle:5000 capabilityMatcher:org.openqa.grid.internal.utils.DefaultCapabilityMatcher newSessionWaitTimeout:-1 url:http://127.0.0.1:0 remoteHost:http://127.0.0.1:0 prioritizer:null register:true throwOnCapabilityNotPresent:true nodePolling:5000 proxy:org.openqa.grid.selenium.proxy.DefaultRemoteProxy maxSession:2 role:node jettyMaxThreads:-1 hubPort:4444 timeout:300000  ``` - No submitted Webdriver, RC, etc. tests will be able to run on this wrongly registered node.  Also this incorrect behaviour seems to affect all the possible use cases of Selenium (see also the closed ticket #1292 )  Kind regards,  Volker

column3: Add support for "port 0" dynamic port allocation
column4: ###### Background: - Under Linux and Windows, bind()-ing to network port 0 assigns the application a free port from the dynamic port range. ###### Test setup: - Selenium server standalone version 2.48.2 - CentOS 7 - Java 1.7.0_91 - Firefox 38.3.0 ###### Issue description: - When launching multiple Selenium instances on "HtmlSuites" it can be very useful for a user to be able to set the option `-port 0`. This would allow the Selenium application to receive a free port from the OS, removing the burden of finding one from the user's shoulders. - The tested Selenium server accepts `-port 0` option and will correctly listen on the random free port offered by the OS, as can be seen via `lsof`. -  The automatically generated configuration files for the browser (here: Firefox) do **not** reflect this assigned port but reference the port set via command-line: **0**. ###### Example:  Selenium command used, i.e. with your own favourite HtmlSuite:  ``` java -jar selenium-server-standalone.jar -port 0 -htmlSuite "*firefox" "http://some.url.ch/" "test_suite.html" "results.html" ```  Launching `lsof -p ` on the process ID will show the listening port:  ``` [...] java    9500 jenkins   11u  IPv6             190573       0t0      TCP *:51276 (LISTEN) [...] ```  When looking at the `prefs.js` file generated for the Firefox instance, we can see that the URL wrongly references **localhost:0** instead of **localhost:51276** (URL %XX notation removed for readability):  ``` [...] user_pref("browser.startup.homepage", "chrome://src/content/TestRunner.html?auto=true&multiWindow=true&defaultLogLevel=info&baseUrl=http://some.url.ch/&resultsUrl=../postResults&test=http://localhost:0/selenium-server/tests/test_suite.html"); [...] ``` ###### Possible resolution: - I'm not a programmer but the Java socket documentation has a [getLocalPort](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/net/Socket.html#getLocalPort--) function which could be used to identify the effective port number on which Selenium is listening. This value should then override the command-line value.  This would really help in our current setup of Selenium test cases :-)  Kind regards, Volker

column3: Synthetic events: unable to send a series of DELETE keys to a text input
column4: ### Versions  Selenium version: 2.48.0 all the way down to at least 2.45.0 Browser: Firefox 31 and 38, and probably other versions too... OS: Linux  (Note: I see 2.48.2 as the latest release on github, but 2.48.0 is the latest Python package of Selenium available through pypi.) ### What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. This code reproduces the problem 100% of the time here:        ```    import selenium    from selenium import webdriver    from selenium.webdriver.firefox.webdriver import FirefoxBinary    from selenium.webdriver.common.action_chains import ActionChains    from selenium.webdriver.common.keys import Keys        def perform(driver):    driver.get("http://example.com")    text = driver.execute_script("""    var body = document.body;    body.innerHTML += "";    var text = document.getElementById("text");    text.value = "abcd";    return text;    """)        print "selenium:", selenium.__version__    print "browser:", driver.desired_capabilities["platform"], driver.name, \        driver.desired_capabilities["version"]    print "native events:", driver.desired_capabilities["nativeEvents"]    print "initial value:", text.get_attribute("value")    keys = [Keys.HOME] + [Keys.DELETE] * 4        ActionChains(driver)\        .click(text) \        .send_keys(keys) \        .perform()        print "final value:", text.get_attribute("value")    print        driver.quit()        driver = webdriver.Firefox(    firefox_binary=FirefoxBinary("/home/ldd/src/firefox-31/firefox"),    capabilities={"nativeEvents": True})    perform(driver)        driver = webdriver.Firefox(    firefox_binary=FirefoxBinary("/home/ldd/src/firefox-31/firefox"),    capabilities={"nativeEvents": False})    perform(driver)        driver = webdriver.Firefox(    firefox_binary=FirefoxBinary("/home/ldd/src/firefox-38/firefox"))    perform(driver)        driver = webdriver.Chrome()    perform(driver)    ```        Save it as `issue.py`. Edit the `FirefoxBinary` paths to point to your instances. 2. Run:        python ./issue.py ### What is the expected output?  What the code does is click into a text input field and send HOME followed by 4 DELETE keystrokes. It should empty the text "abcd" that was pre-entered into the field.  In every single case of selenium version and browser version, the `final value:` line should show empty text because the field is empty. ### What do you see instead?  Only Chrome 47 (or any Chrome really) with any Selenium version, or Firefox 31.8 with Selenium 2.45.0 give the expected results.  In all other cases, we get `final value: bcd`, indicating that only one deletion happened.  Here is the output I get when running the test with Selenium 2.45.0:  ``` selenium: 2.45.0 browser: Linux firefox 31.8.0 native events: True initial value: abcd final value:  selenium: 2.45.0 browser: Linux firefox 31.8.0 native events: False initial value: abcd final value: bcd  selenium: 2.45.0 browser: Linux firefox 38.0 native events: False initial value: abcd final value: bcd  selenium: 2.45.0 browser: Linux chrome 47.0.2526.106 native events: True initial value: abcd final value: ```  With Selenium 2.48.0:  ``` selenium: 2.48.0 browser: Linux firefox 31.8.0 native events: False initial value: abcd final value: bcd  selenium: 2.48.0 browser: Linux firefox 31.8.0 native events: False initial value: abcd final value: bcd  selenium: 2.48.0 browser: Linux firefox 38.0 native events: False initial value: abcd final value: bcd  selenium: 2.48.0 browser: Linux chrome 47.0.2526.106 native events: True initial value: abcd final value: ``` ### Observations 1. The cases that produce incorrect results all correlate with the use of synthetic events in Firefox. 2. The `CHANGELOG` states that 2.48.0 "Supports native events for Firefox version 31 (immediately previous ESR)." but the test shows that even when native events are required with FF 31.8.0, Selenium 2.48.0 does not honor the request.

column3: synthetic events do not take into account overlapping elements
column4: ### Versions  Selenium version: 2.46.0 Browser: FF 34 OS: I reproduce this on Linux but it should happen the same irrespective of OS. ### What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. This code reproduces the problem 100% of the time here:        ```    from selenium import webdriver    from selenium.webdriver.firefox.webdriver import FirefoxBinary    from selenium.webdriver.common.action_chains import ActionChains        # We have to use a Firefox binary for which native events are supported.    binary = FirefoxBinary("/home/ldd/src/firefox-34.0.5/firefox")        def perform(native):        caps = {            "nativeEvents": native        }            driver = webdriver.Firefox(capabilities=caps, firefox_binary=binary)            print "NATIVE:", driver.desired_capabilities["nativeEvents"]            driver.get("http://output.jsbin.com/xufota/1")            contents = driver.find_element_by_id("contents")        ActionChains(driver) \            .click(contents) \            .perform()            print driver.execute_script("""        return document.getElementById("log").textContent;        """)            driver.quit()            for native in (False, True):        perform(native)    ```        Save it as `issue.py`. 2. Edit the script so that the path given for the Firefox binary for which native events can be produce is set to a path that works on your system, and run:        python ./issue.py ### What is the expected output?  ``` NATIVE: False      Log:   click in over NATIVE: True      Log:   click in over ``` ### What do you see instead?  ``` NATIVE: False      Log:   click in contents NATIVE: True      Log:   click in over ```  The click with native events turned off should register in `over` rather than in `contents`. ### Observations  What the script tries to simulate is a user clicking on the text `Hello`. When a real user performs this action, the browser will dispatch the event to the element with the id `over`. When Selenium runs with native events, it is able to dispatch the event in the same way a real browser does. However, Selenium when running with synthesized events is incapable of simulating what happens when a real user clicks in the browser window.  Setting an explicit `z-index` on `over` makes no difference.  Using `contents.click()` rather than an action chain makes no difference.  I'm reporting bug as requested [here](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/selenium-developers/DKnG2lA-KxM/_2xZsazCgs4J). In my opinion, the goal of trying to get synthetic events to stand in for native events is unsustainable. The scenario I have here is just the tip of the iceberg.

column3: synthetic events do not generate `focus` and `blur` unless FF is the topmost window
column4: ### Versions  Selenium version: 2.45.0, 2.46.1 Browser: FF 34 OS: Debian Testing up to date as of 2015-07-23 ### What steps will reproduce the problem?  To get the whole script to run you should run it on 2.45.0. See notes below regarding 2.46.0. 1. This code reproduces the problem 100% of the time here:        ```    from selenium import webdriver    from selenium.webdriver.common.action_chains import ActionChains    from selenium.webdriver.firefox.webdriver import FirefoxBinary    from selenium.common.exceptions import ElementNotVisibleException    from selenium.common.exceptions import InvalidElementStateException        import time    import subprocess        def pause():    time.sleep(1)        def makedriver(native):    desired_capabilities = {        "nativeEvents": native    }    driver = webdriver.Firefox(        firefox_binary=FirefoxBinary(            "/home/ldd/src/firefox-34.0.5/firefox"),        capabilities=desired_capabilities)        print driver.desired_capabilities["platform"]    print driver.name    print driver.desired_capabilities["version"]    return driver        def perform(native):    driver = makedriver(native)        # Make this False to easily turn off the creation of the new window.    if True:        #        # This will open a new window which will mess up the synthetic        # event generation.        #        with open("/dev/null") as null:            ff = subprocess.Popen(["xterm", "-e", "/usr/bin/top"],                                  stdout=null, stderr=null)    else:        ff = None        print "NATIVE:", driver.desired_capabilities["nativeEvents"]        driver.get("http://jsbin.com/picuxo")        field = driver.find_element_by_id("input")        ActionChains(driver) \        .move_to_element(field) \        .click() \        .send_keys("foo") \        .perform()        #    # The pauses should satisfy observers that the unexpected results    # we are getting with native events turned off are not due to some    # asynchronous browser-side process not having had time to run.    #    # I'm using the brute approach of using `time.sleep` so as to not    # get bogged down in polling logic.    #    pause()        print "START:", driver.execute_script("return arguments[0].value", field)        fill = driver.find_element_by_id("fill")    try:        ActionChains(driver) \            .click(fill) \            .perform()    except ElementNotVisibleException:        # We should not see this.        print "*** FILL ELEMENT NOT VISIBLE!"        pause()        # The field should contain `foofilled` because the `Fill` button    # added text to it.    print "FILLED:", driver.execute_script("return arguments[0].value", field)        button = driver.find_element_by_id("submit")    ActionChains(driver) \        .click(button) \        .perform()        pause()        modal2 = driver.find_element_by_id("modal2")    # It should not be visible because modal1 is covering the button.    print "MODAL2 VISIBLE?", modal2.is_displayed()        ActionChains(driver) \        .move_to_element(field) \        .click() \        .send_keys("bar") \        .perform()        dismiss = driver.find_element_by_css_selector("#modal1 button")    try:        ActionChains(driver) \            .click(dismiss) \            .perform()    except ElementNotVisibleException:        # We should not see this.        print "*** MODAL1 DISMISS ELEMENT NOT VISIBLE!"        ActionChains(driver) \        .click(button) \        .perform()        pause()        ActionChains(driver) \        .move_to_element(field) \        .click() \        .send_keys("baz") \        .perform()        pause()        # The final value should be `foofilled` because the `send_keys`    # that were called after the `Fill` button was clicked should have    # had no effect.    print "FINAL:", driver.execute_script("return arguments[0].value", field)    print        driver.quit()        if ff:        ff.terminate()        for native in (False, True):    try:        perform(native)    except InvalidElementStateException:        # This will happen when running with >= 2.46.0        print "*** Aborted due to the unavailability of native events!"        ``` 2. Save the script as `issue.py`. Edit the script so that the path given for the Firefox binary for which native events can be produced is set to a path that works on your system, and run:        $ xvfb-run python ./issue.py  `xvfb-run` is used to isolate the run from other applications running. If you just run it on your usual desktop, you may not get the results above due to window manager interference or some other factor. ### What is the expected output?  ``` Linux firefox 34.0.5 NATIVE: False START: foo FILLED: foofilled MODAL2 VISIBLE? False FINAL: foofilled  Linux firefox 34.0.5 NATIVE: True START: foo FILLED: foofilled MODAL2 VISIBLE? False FINAL: foofilled ```  Synthetic events should produce the same browser behavior as native events. ### What do you see instead?  ``` Linux firefox 34.0.5 NATIVE: False START: foo *** FILL ELEMENT NOT VISIBLE! FILLED: foo MODAL2 VISIBLE? True *** MODAL1 DISMISS ELEMENT NOT VISIBLE! FINAL: foobarbaz  Linux firefox 34.0.5 NATIVE: True START: foo FILLED: foofilled MODAL2 VISIBLE? False FINAL: foofilled ```  The main problem here is that `focus` and `blur` events are not generated, so elements that should become visible on the screen do not become visible. ### Observations  It is not possible to run the whole script with Selenium 2.46.0. The script is designed to show how the behavior of native events and synthetic events differ, with native events providing exactly what a developer would expect. Because 2.46.0 does not support native events on FF 34, the attempt at running with native events fails. However, it is possible to run the script in 2.46.0 and see the incorrect behavior provided by synthetic events, which is the same as in 2.45.0.  Running the script with `xvfb-run` and launching an `xterm` instance so that Firefox is not the topmost window is a means to get 100% reproducibility. On my own desktop here (Gnome) I can readily reproduce the problem if I just run `python ./issue.py`, and even if Firefox _looks_ like it is the topmost window. However, I found that if I start playing with the mouse while the test runs, reproducibility is not guaranteed.  Running the script with Chrome 44 (and chromedriver 2.16) produces the expected output, except for the fact that we get `NATIVE: True` in both runs given that it is not possible to turn off native events in Chrome. I'm not equipped to try to mimic what I'm doing in X11 in a Windows or Mac OS environment but I'd expect native events there too to work perfectly like they do in Chrome 44.  I'm reporting the bug as requested [here](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/selenium-developers/DKnG2lA-KxM/_2xZsazCgs4J).

column3: synthetic events do not accurately simulate the events normally generated when a user clicks in an element that is removed from the DOM
column4: ### Versions  Selenium version: 2.45.0, 2.46.0, 2.46.1 Browser: FF, IE OS: Debian Testing up to date as of 2015-07-31 ### What steps will reproduce the problem?  To get the whole script to run you should run it on 2.45.0. See notes below regarding 2.46.x. 1. This code reproduces the problem 100% of the time here. Please read the comments at the start to learn how it can be run.        ```    import sys    import collections        from selenium import webdriver    from selenium.webdriver.firefox.webdriver import FirefoxBinary    from selenium.webdriver.common.action_chains import ActionChains        # We have to use a Firefox binary for which native events are supported.    binary = FirefoxBinary("/home/ldd/src/firefox-31/firefox")        # Ways to run this script:    #    # - To launch a local browser:    #    # ./issue.py local [ firefox | ff | chrome | ch ]    #    # - To launch a remote browser on Sauce labs:    #    # ./issue.py remote user:key 'os,browser,version'    #    # where:    #    # * `user` is your user id on Sauce Labs    #    # * `key` is the key for Sauce Labs    #    # * `os` is the OS you want Sauce Labs to run the browser on    #    # * `browser` is the browser you want. This has to equal to one of the    #   fields of webdriver.DesiredCapabilities. (`INTERNETEXPLORER` and    #   `internetexplorer` are fine but `ie` won't work.)    #    # * `version` is the version number you want.    #    # e.g. python ./issue.py remote foo:bar 'Windows 8.1,firefox,31'    #    # would launch Firefox 31 on Windows 8.1 with user id `foo` and API key `bar`.    #        def makedriver(caps):        if sys.argv[1] == "remote":            Config = collections.namedtuple(                'Config', ('platform', 'browser', 'version'))                cmd_line_config = sys.argv[3]            split_config = cmd_line_config.split(",")            split_config[1] = split_config[1].upper()            config = Config(*split_config)                # config = Config("Windows 8.1", "INTERNETEXPLORER", "11")            # config = Config("Windows 8.1", "CHROME", "41")                desired_capabilities = dict(getattr(webdriver.DesiredCapabilities,                                                config.browser))            desired_capabilities.update(caps)                desired_capabilities["platform"] = config.platform            desired_capabilities["version"] = config.version            desired_capabilities["selenium-version"] = "2.46.0"            desired_capabilities["chromedriver-version"] = "2.16"            desired_capabilities["avoid-proxy"] = "true"            desired_capabilities["name"] = "ad-hoc test"                driver = webdriver.Remote(                desired_capabilities=desired_capabilities,                command_executor="http://" + sys.argv[2] +                "@ondemand.saucelabs.com:80/wd/hub")        elif sys.argv[1] == "local":            browser = sys.argv[2].lower()            if browser in ("firefox", "ff"):                driver = webdriver.Firefox(                    capabilities=caps, firefox_binary=binary)            elif browser in ("chrome", "ch"):                driver = webdriver.Chrome(desired_capabilities=caps)            else:                raise ValueError("cannot process argument: " + sys.argv[2])        else:            raise ValueError("cannot process argument: " + sys.argv[1])            print "browser: ", driver.desired_capabilities["platform"], driver.name, \            driver.desired_capabilities["version"]        print "native events:", driver.desired_capabilities["nativeEvents"]        return driver            def perform(native):        caps = {            "nativeEvents": native        }            driver = makedriver(caps)            driver.get("http://output.jsbin.com/reruke")            over = driver.find_element_by_id("over")        ActionChains(driver) \            .click(over) \            .perform()            print driver.execute_script("""        return document.getElementById("log").textContent;        """)            driver.quit()            for native in (False, True):        perform(native)    ``` 2. Save the script as `issue.py`. Edit the script so that the path given for the Firefox binary for which native events can be produced is set to a path that works on your system, and run:        $ python ./issue.py local firefox ### What is the expected output?  ``` browser:  Linux firefox 31.3.0 native events: False      Log:   mousedown in over (handled by over) mousedown in over (handled by body) mouseup in under (handled by under) mouseup in under (handled by body)  browser:  Linux firefox 31.3.0 native events: True      Log:   mousedown in over (handled by over) mousedown in over (handled by body) mouseup in under (handled by under) mouseup in under (handled by body) ```  Synthetic events should produce the same browser behavior as native events. ### What do you see instead?  ``` browser:  Linux firefox 31.3.0 native events: False      Log:   mousedown in over (handled by over) mousedown in over (handled by body)  browser:  Linux firefox 31.3.0 native events: True      Log:   mousedown in over (handled by over) mousedown in over (handled by body) mouseup in under (handled by under) mouseup in under (handled by body) ``` ### Observations  It is not possible to use 2.46.1 when running the test remotely as Sauce Labs does not have it installed yet. The latest version they have is 2.46.0.  It is not possible to run the whole script with Firefox with Selenium 2.46.0. The script is designed to show how the behavior of native events and synthetic events differ, with native events providing exactly what a developer would expect. Because 2.46.0 does not support native events on FF 31.3.0 (or 31.8.0, for that matter, or any other FF I tried), the attempt at running with native events fails. However, it is possible to run the script in 2.46.1 and see the incorrect behavior provided by synthetic events, which is the same as in 2.45.0.  The same problem occurs in IE 10 and IE 11: synthetic events fail to accurately simulate actual user interaction with the browser. The one difference is that in IE 10 or 11 and additional "click in body" event is produced. However, this extra event is also produced when I perform the operations manually on the jsbin page. Therefore, I conclude that this is not an inconsistency in Selenium but a discrepancy between how the browsers handle mouse events. **And this, by the way, is exactly why native events are so useful: they highlight such discrepancies among browsers.** To run it with IE, I do:  ``` $ python ./issue.py remote user:key 'Windows 8,internetexplorer,10' ```  The expected results are exactly those that are produced if I open the jsbin in Firefox and do manually the operations performed by the script. Native events reproduce accurately what happens when I manually operate the browser, synthetic events do not.  Running the script with Chrome 44 (and chromedriver 2.16) produces the expected behavior, except for the fact that we get `native events: True` in both runs given that it is not possible to turn off native events in Chrome. There's one difference when I perform the run in Chrome: an additional "click in body" event is produced. However, my conclusions about this additional event are the same as for IE (see above).  I'm reporting the bug as requested [here](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/selenium-developers/DKnG2lA-KxM/_2xZsazCgs4J).

column3: ChromeDriver throws UnsupportedCommandException
column4: ### Steps to reproduce  Run   ``` java js.executeAsyncScript(readFile("script.js"), readFile("0.js"), readFile("1.js"), readFile("2.js")); ```  where files are in the [archive](https://www.dropbox.com/s/bueqwjy3wit8gmd/selenium-error.zip?dl=0), and `readFile` is declared as following:  ``` java     static String readFile(File file) throws IOException {         try (InputStream input = new FileInputStream(file)) {             return IOUtils.toString(input, "UTF-8");         }     } ```  Get the following exception:  ``` org.openqa.selenium.UnsupportedCommandException: missing command parameters Command duration or timeout: 12 milliseconds Build info: version: '2.47.2', revision: '4d972c01cab1304452627f837654326a11eb92fe', time: '2015-09-24 09:17:17' System info: host: 'chesire-cat', ip: '192.168.1.34', os.name: 'Linux', os.arch: 'amd64', os.version: '4.1.8-100.fc21.x86_64', java.version: '1.8.0_40' Driver info: org.openqa.selenium.chrome.ChromeDriver Capabilities [{applicationCacheEnabled=false, rotatable=false, mobileEmulationEnabled=false, chrome={userDataDir=/tmp/.com.google.Chrome.Xddz8C}, takesHeapSnapshot=true, databaseEnabled=false, handlesAlerts=true, hasTouchScreen=false, version=45.0.2454.101, platform=LINUX, browserConnectionEnabled=false, nativeEvents=true, acceptSslCerts=true, locationContextEnabled=true, webStorageEnabled=true, browserName=chrome, takesScreenshot=true, javascriptEnabled=true, cssSelectorsEnabled=true}] Session ID: c7dc3caed25f70200920327db83f90c9     at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)     at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:62)     at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)     at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:422)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.ErrorHandler.createThrowable(ErrorHandler.java:206)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.ErrorHandler.throwIfResponseFailed(ErrorHandler.java:158)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.RemoteWebDriver.execute(RemoteWebDriver.java:595)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.RemoteWebDriver.executeAsyncScript(RemoteWebDriver.java:522) ``` ### Expected result  Script completes normally ### Additional comments  I run WebDriver on 1.5K scripts and all of them complete normally, except this one (`1.js` varies between executions, others remain the same). I can't find anything special about this particular script. I can't debug any further than `HttpCommandExecutor.execute`, since it just sends commands and receives this error, and I don't have idead how to debug `chromedriver`.

column3: How to use Chrome profile other than default?
column4:
### Documentation:  https://sites.google.com/a/chromium.org/chromedriver/capabilities  >  you can use the user-data-dir Chrome command-line switch to tell Chrome which profile to use:  ``` ChromeOptions options = new ChromeOptions(); options.addArguments("user-data-dir=/path/to/your/custom/profile"); ```  ---  I'm using - https://code.google.com/p/selenium/wiki/WebDriverJs 2.46.1 - and the following code:  ``` var webdriver = require('selenium-webdriver'); var chrome = require('selenium-webdriver/chrome'); var o = new chrome.Options(); o.addArguments("user-data-dir=c:/Users/a-miste/AppData/Local/Google/Chrome/User Data/"); var driver = new webdriver.Builder().withCapabilities(webdriver.Capabilities.chrome()).setChromeOptions(o).build();   driver.get('http://www.facebook.com');  driver.wait(function() {  return driver.getTitle().then(function(title) {    console.log("title: " + title);    return true;  }); }, 5000); ```  It was partially created thanks to this StackOverflow question: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25779027/load-default-chrome-profile-with-webdriverjs-selenium  As I navigate to `chrome://version/` the profile path is correct:  > C:\Users\a-miste\AppData\Local\Google\Chrome\User Data\Default  However the whole thing crashes and I do not navigate to Facebook (I stay on the homepage)  ``` C:\Michal\Code\Selenium

To circumvent that I copied **Profile 1** to the following directory structure:  ![directory structure](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/249703/8988373/b693c252-36dd-11e5-9075-27b33ed79a0c.PNG)  And now it works just fine...  ---  So the questions are: - how to use Default profile without crashing? - how to use other profiles without necessity of copying them?

column3: Java. Event firing: improvements and new features
column4: ## Problems - Current design doesn't allow end user to log events optionally. E.g.   if they want to log only searchings or searchings and navigation then   they are forced to leave unimplemented methods in their code - Current design doesn't allow to make any extension without backward   compatibility problems because each new method should be implemented or   left empty - There are some issues with the logging of thrown exceptions # What has been done - WebDriverEvent listener was separated to few interfaces. It is still   here and aggretes them (in order to support backward compatibility) - New listeners were added - EventFiringWebdraver was redesigned. The ability to use listeners   optionally is provided now  Warning!!! There is an issue of backward compatility. Users will face it if they directly use such classes as EventFiringKeyboard, EventFiringMouse, EventFiringTouch. But I hope there not many cases and it is not the critical issue.   --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/seleniumhq/selenium/1034)

column3: Python WebDriver: driver.execute_script() executes scripts in previous pages context sometimes after calling driver.get()
column4: ## Issue  Sometime when you first open page with `driver.get` and navigate to another page using `driver.get` again and then call `driver.execute_script` the script is executes in previous pages context. I would assume `driver.get` to block until the page has actually changed and only then return control to test script.  For example if you set some javascript variable on first page and then check that using `driver.execute_script` after calling `driver.get` it may still return the value even it should not. ## Expected behaviour  I expect `driver.get` to block test script from executing until page has changed. If `driver.execute_script` is called right after page load it should fail if javascript is not executed yet. It should not never use previous pages context. ## Test case that I'm able to reproduce the issue.  ``` python def test_script_is_called_in_correct_context(self):     # First open some test page and call scripts     self.driver.get("/first_page.html")     self._wait_for_engine_started(self.driver)     self.driver.execute_script("window.ourNameSpace.engine.refreshAll();")     WebDriverWait(self.driver, 10).until(         lambda driver: driver.execute_script('return window.SELENIUM_TEST_PASSES;')     )      # Now change to another page     self.driver.get("/second_page.html")      #     # NOTE: If line below are uncommented then the test seems to always pass.     #     #WebDriverWait(self.driver, 1).until(     #    lambda driver: driver.execute_script('return window.location.href.indexOf("second_page") > -1;')     #)      # If I uncomment below line it also sometimes prints previous page url.     # print self.driver.execute_script('return window.location.href;')      # Command below always execute successfully which indicates that they get called before      # browser has actually changed page.     self._wait_for_engine_started(self.driver)     self.driver.execute_script("window.ourNameSpace.engine.refreshAll();")      #      # NOTE: This line sometimes randomly cause error: "WebDriverException: Message: window.ourNameSpace is undefined".     # This happens even the previous line accesses window.ourNameSpace just fine!     # This makes me believe that the context is flushed randomly between these lines and the      # new pages javascript is not executed yet.     #     self.driver.execute_script('console.log(window.ourNameSpace.engine);')      #      # NOTE: Or if the line above passes then below line may cause same error.     #     WebDriverWait(self.driver, 10).until(         lambda driver: driver.execute_script('return window.ourNameSpace.engine._getStates();')[0]['state'] == 'passive'     )      def _wait_for_engine_started(self, driver):         WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(             lambda driver: driver.execute_script(                 'return window.ourNameSpace && window.ourNameSpace.engine && window.ourNameSpace.engine.isStarted;'             )         )   ```

column3: Firefox not loading profile correctly
column4: ## Expected Behavior -Firefox Webdriver should use the sourceprofiledir as the main profile dir ## Actual Behavior - Firefox Webdriver will use null as profile dir and still have the correct profiledir as a sourceprofiledir however it will see the null profile dir and instead create a random profiledir folder and use that ## Steps to reproduce -  First create new Firefox Profile Win+R and then type Firefox -P enter new profile details Run code below.  (C#)  private IWebDriver driver;   public void SetupTest()         {             string path = Environment.GetFolderPath(Environment.SpecialFolder.ApplicationData) + @"\Mozilla\Firefox\Profiles";                      string[] pathsToProfiles = Directory.GetDirectories(path, "*.NewfolderName",                  SearchOption.TopDirectoryOnly);  ```           if (!allProfiles.ExistingProfiles.Contains("NewfolderName"))         {             throw new Exception("NewfolderName firefox profile does not exist, please create it first.");             //to create a FF profile press win+R and the type in FireFox -p         }          if (pathsToProfiles.Length != 0)         {             FirefoxProfile profile = new FirefoxProfile(pathsToProfiles[0]);         profile.SetPreference("browser.tabs.loadInBackground", false);         driver = new FirefoxDriver(profile);          }         else         {             driver = new FirefoxDriver();         } ```  }  The workflow is fairly simple,  1. Check profiledir paths and store as strings 2. check if profiledir we want to use exists? , if not prompt user to create 4. Now we know profiledir exists we want to create a new Webdriver profile with the dir of choice "NewfolderName" 4.  If not then create standard Firefox Driver using normal temp profile.

column3: Python selenium tab feature works fine in Firefox but not in Chrome
column4: ## Expected Behavior - new links to be opened in new tabs ## Actual Behavior - it is working fine in firefox, but not in chrome as expected ## Steps to reproduce -  from selenium import webdriver from selenium.webdriver.common.keys import Keys import time  browser = webdriver.Chrome('C:\data\books oae\apex library\chromedriver') #Firefox()   browser.get('https://trello.com/login') time.sleep(10) emailElem = browser.find_element_by_id('user') emailElem.send_keys('test123@gmail.com') passwordElem = browser.find_element_by_id('password') passwordElem.send_keys('test12345') passwordElem.submit()  body = browser.find_element_by_tag_name("body") body.send_keys(Keys.CONTROL + 't')  browser.get('https://todoist.com/Users/showLogin') time.sleep(10) emailElem = browser.find_element_by_id('email') emailElem.send_keys('test123@gmail.com') passwordElem = browser.find_element_by_id('password') passwordElem.send_keys('test12345') passwordElem.submit()  body = browser.find_element_by_tag_name("body") body.send_keys(Keys.CONTROL + 't')  browser.get('https://asana.com/#login') time.sleep(10) emailElem = browser.find_element_by_id('login-email-login-modal') emailElem.send_keys('test123@gmail.com') passwordElem = browser.find_element_by_id('login-password-login-modal') passwordElem.send_keys('test12345') passwordElem.submit()

column3: IE browser doesn't close despite reporting that the session was deleted
column4: ## Expected Behavior - 1. Run the test 2. The test completes 3. The node reports:      `INFO - Executing: [delete session: 729e2...]`      `INFO - Done: [delete session: 729e2...]` 4. The browser closes ## Actual Behavior - 1. Run the test 2. The test completes 3. The node reports:      `INFO - Executing: [delete session: 729e2...]`      `INFO - Done: [delete session: 729e2...]` 4. The browser remains open ## Steps to reproduce -  I am running a Selenium grid. Here's my configuration: - Hub   - iMac9,1 - OS 10.11.3   - selenium standalone server v2.52.0     - started with `java -jar selenium-server-standalone-2.52.0.jar -role hub` - Node   - HP 11-d010nr - OS Windows 8.1   - selenium standalone server v2.52.0     - started with `java -jar selenium-server-standalone-2.52.0.jar -role node -hub http://the-imac.local:4444/grid/register -nodeConfig config.json`*   - IEDriverServer (64 bit) - Client   - iMac7,1 - OS 10.10.5   - JavaScript (Node) web driver installed via `npm install selenium-webdriver` (v2.52.0)  *Contents of config.json:  ``` json {     "capabilities": [{         "browserName": "internet explorer",         "platform": "WINDOWS"     }],     "configuration": {} } ```  The test is a simplified version of one of the included example tests:  ``` javascript var webdriver = require('selenium-webdriver'),  var driver = new webdriver.Builder()     .forBrowser('internet explorer')     .build();  driver.get('http://www.google.com/ncr'); driver.quit(); ```  The same test run with `forBrowser('firefox')` behaves as expected.

column3: SafariDriver send_keys to file input produces ElementNotVisibleException
column4: ## Expected Behavior -  Whenever I try to upload a file using the send_keys method(path) method it works flawlessly with the chromedriver and firefox driver and uploads the file. When doing the exact same thing using the SafarDriver it produces an ElementNotVisibleException.  The HTML is as follows:  ``` html  ``` ## Actual Behavior -  Instead of uploading the file Selenium throws this exception: selenium.common.exceptions.ElementNotVisibleException: Message: InvalidStateError: DOM Exception 11 (WARNING: The server did not provide any stacktrace information) ## Steps to reproduce -  Following code is used to upload the file  ``` python element = self.wait.until(EC.presence_of_element_located((method, locator))) element.send_keys("/path/to/file.jpg") ```  I have also tried doing it using the file input on http://www.tinyupload.com. This gave me the same exception.

column3: Selenium Grid maxSession ignored
column4: ## Expected Behavior -  When I start a grid hub and node with maxSession 1, then make multiple simultaneous requests to the hub with webdriver, no more than one of those requests should be fulfilled at a time. ## Actual Behavior -  Making 5 simultaneous requests for a firefox session from the above setup results in 5 open firefox windows all processing at the same time. ## Steps to reproduce -  I'm building a node.js application using the [selenium-webdriver](https://www.npmjs.com/package/selenium-webdriver) and [selenium-server-standalone-jar](https://www.npmjs.com/package/selenium-server-standalone-jar) NPM modules.  The latter is just an include for selenium-server-standalone-2.52.0.jar.  The application follows this process: ### 1) Start a selenium grid hub running locally  ``` var jar = require("selenium-server-standalone-jar"),     hub = new require("selenium-webdriver/remote").SeleniumServer(jar.path, {         loopback: true,         port:     4444,         args:     [ "-role hub", "-hubConfig " + config_path ]     }); ```  That hub config file looks like this:  ``` {     "host": null,     "port": 4444,     "newSessionWaitTimeout": -1,     "throwOnCapabilityNotPresent": true,     "nodePolling": 5000,     "cleanUpCycle": 5000,     "timeout": 300000,     "browserTimeout": 0,     "maxSession": 1 } ``` ### 2) Start a selenium grid node running locally  ``` var hub = new require("selenium-webdriver/remote").SeleniumServer(jar.path, {         loopback: true,         port:     5555,         args:     [ "-role node", "-nodeConfig " + config_path ]     }); ```  The node config looks like this:  ``` {     "capabilities": [         {             "browserName": "firefox",             "maxInstances": 1,             "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"         }     ],     "configuration": {         "maxSession": 1,         "port": 5555,         "host": "127.0.0.1",         "register": true,         "registerCycle": 5000,         "hubPort": 4444,         "hubHost": "127.0.0.1"     } } ```  So at this point I have a hub running with maxSession=1 and a node running with maxSession=1 and maxInstances=1 (for Firefox). This isn't how the application will function long term, I'm just trying to get Selenium Grid to demonstrate that it CAN limit sessions. ### 3) Start 5 child processes, each with its own webdriver using the hub server  I use child_process.exec to split off multiple child processes, each executing cucumber.js.  Before each cucumber scenario, I create a new webdriver which uses the grid hub as its server, and after each scenario the webdriver is closed.  As mentioned above, I would expect only one of these child process webdrivers to be able to work at a time, but instead all do.  This presents a scaling problem for me; 5 browser windows is fine, but 50 probably would not be.  I need to be able to limit grid and the maxSession config parameter doesn't seem to be working.

column3: As of Selenium 2.48.0, the findElement method on iOS driver no longer respects implicit timeout
column4: ## Expected Behavior -  When I search for an element that doesn't exist, the findElement method call should terminate after the implicit timeout interval has expired, throwing NoSuchElementException. ## Actual Behavior -  The findElement method call does not time out directly. Instead, the driver ends up shutting itself down with WebDriverException (timeOutBetweenCommand) ## Steps to reproduce -  Assemble an iOS automation configuration with the latest driver and Selenium Java 2.48.0 or newer. Run a test that acquires an iOS driver session and searches for an element that doesn't exist. The findElement method call will not time out as expected.  Revise your configuration to specify Selenium Java 2.47.0 and run your test again. The findElement method call now times out as expected.

column3: Selenium grid not respecting the requested chrome version
column4: ## Expected Behavior -  When I have a grid set up with 1 node connecting to it with chrome version 29 and another node connecting to the grid with chrome version 33, then when I run the test and request version 29, I expect to get access to node thats labeled with version 29. ## Actual Behavior -  The GRID hands out a node which has 'chrome' node, regardless of the version of the 'chrome'. I.e. When I create a test which requires chrome version 29, I might get chrome 33. ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Bring up the grid 2. Register a node with random version of chrome(config.json below)  ``` json {   "capabilities": [     {       "browserName": "chrome",       "maxInstances": 1,       "version": "random",       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"   ... ``` 1. Register a node with chrome 29(config.json below)  ``` json {   "capabilities": [     {       "browserName": "chrome",       "maxInstances": 1,       "version": 29,       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"    }   ... ``` 1. Create a test which registers chrome version 29  ```     def include_chrome29_driver(       conf = {}       conf[:http_client] = client_with_increased_timeout       conf[:browser] = local_browser       conf[:desired_capabilities] = Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.chrome("chromeOptions" => {"args" => args})       conf[:desired_capabilities].version = "29"       Capybara.register_driver :"chrome29" do |app|         Capybara::Selenium::Driver.new(app, conf)       end     end ``` 1. Run the test - most likely you will get the node with chrome version "random", because it was registered first. Version is ignored

column3: Link not working: Selenium Downloads - Previous Releases
column4: ## Expected Behavior -  When clicking "Previous Releases", browser should show some list of old versions allowing the user to download previous (old) releases from some archive server. ## Actual Behavior -  Browser is redirected to https://github.com/seleniumhq/selenium-google-code-issue-archive, where not old releases, but old issues are show. ## Steps to reproduce -  Load URL "https://code.google.com/p/selenium/downloads/list?can=1&q=" or navigate to "Selenium Downloads" - "Previous Releases".

column3: Caught org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: Exposing privileged or cross-origin callable is prohibited
column4: ## Expected Behavior -  Using firebug addon in Firefox I try to export har files using a JavascriptExecutor like below from the webdriver:  ``` JavascriptExecutor js = (JavascriptExecutor) driver;  js.executeScript("window.NetExport.triggerExport('abcd')"); ```  This used to work but in recent Firefox versions I get the following error:  `Caught org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: Exposing privileged or cross-origin callable is prohibited ` I tried to get around this by setting a preference:  `profOpt.setPreference("security.fileuri.strict_origin_policy", false); `  but it doesn't help.  I can see it work in Firefox versions up to version 33 but not the more recent ones

column3: getCurrentURL of current frame not return the URL of the frame
column4: ## Expected Behavior -  Until recent releases of chromedriver it was possible to get the current URL of selected frame ## Actual Behavior -  At the moment the method there is no way to getCurrentURL of the frame but only on the main window. ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Go to URL with some iframe 2. Select the iframe 3. Use method like:    currentUrl() {          return browser.driver.getCurrentUrl();      }    to get current URL

column4: ## Expected Behavior -  The Id Should resolve in IWebElement object or it should be resolved in " Var " or " object " types. ## Actual Behavior -  It throws exception. ## Steps to reproduce -  We have a TxTexTControl - " Active x Control" which resides in out Asp.Net page. when we try access the element  by the following lines . It thorws exception  here TxTexTControl is ID of the control.  driver.FindElement(By.Id("TxTextControl"));  or  ((IJavaScriptExecutor)driver).ExecuteScript("return document.getElementById('TxTextControl');") Exceptions :  threw an exception of type 'OpenQA.Selenium.StaleElementReferenceException'

column3: Command "pause" does not pause on Selenium IDE 2.9.0 when running a script with "pause" in the last line
column4: ## Expected Behavior -  The command "pause" should pause even if it stays in the last line of a script. ## Actual Behavior -  The command "pause" does not pause when it stays in the last line of a script. ## Steps to reproduce -  Browser: Firefox 38.6.0 Selenium IDE: 2.9.0 1. I run a simple script which opens a page and pause 5 seconds. ![script on ide](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17423521/13243424/ad8bdd0c-da39-11e5-9901-ec1d92a4d26e.png) 2. But I observed that "pause" command did not pause even if it showed passed. ![running result on ide](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17423521/13243497/2f60a100-da3a-11e5-8bc1-6cfdabe6e0f1.png)

column3: Migrate to IArrayLike to match upstream Closure library changes.
column4: ## Expected Behavior -  The Closure library is advocating improvements to type-safety by migrating goog.array.ArrayLike to IArrayLike  Please see: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1eNpI_02NYb8K-x014Jo8iO6wjlpQQttDO3mVYZUXVtQ  goog.array.ArrayLike is an obsolete alternative to IArrayLike. Unlike IArrayLike, goog.array.ArrayLike can not carry the content value type.  To encourage better typing, goog.array.ArrayLike is being removed. ## Actual Behavior -  old ## Steps to reproduce -  Pure refactoring, just need to pass current tests.  I'll submit a PR for this.

column3: On a screenshot with scroll, the Bootstrap Navbar overlaps a selected element
column4: ## Expected Behavior -  The Bootstrap element Navbar is a fixed element on top of the page. ## Actual Behavior -  When a screenshot with scroll is made, the Navbar overlaps a selected element, which makes the element no longer visible or clickable.  ## Steps to reproduce - 1. You have a Bootstrap Navbar on the top of your webpage.  2. In a page with lot of content, scroll down to check some elements on the bottom of the page.  3. Try to access to an element near the top of the page, which is not currently visible 4. The element couldn't be found, a screenshot is made, the Navbar overlaps the element.   The problem appears on a Slave with Windows Server 2008 (Webdriver: 2.52.0 and FF 44.0.2). On our localhost (Windows 7, Webdriver: 2.52.0 and FF 44.0.2) this problem cannot be reproduced.   ![navbarelementhidden](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6990209/13255347/17430bba-da46-11e5-8811-de36b47af7d1.png)
